questions.text:
Match the following gas cylinders with their respective pin indices.
  1. 2, 5
  2. 7
  3. 3, 5
  4. 1, 5
  5. No pin index
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-A, 2-E, 3-B, 4-C.

Pin Index Safety System (PISS) is a unique configuration of holes and pins which match precisely to eliminate the connection of a wrong cylinder to equipment, thus preventing delivery of wrong gas to a patient. It incorporates two holes in specific positions on the cylinder valve below the outlet port. The cylinder can only be connected to a pressure regulator or yolk, with the corresponding matching pair of pins.

Oxygen cylinders are black cylinders with white shoulders. The pin index of the oxygen cylinder is 2,5. The maximum pressure in the oxygen cylinder is around 2000 psi. The critical temperature of oxygen is -119 ºC, hence it is present in the gaseous form at room temperature.

Helium is stored in brown-colored cylinders and has no pin index. Helium-oxygen mixture, together known as heliox, is used to improve gaseous exchange in acute exacerbation of asthma and COPD. The helium-oxygen mixture in 79%-21% ratio is sometimes used in anesthetic practice to provide relief from upper airway obstructions due to subglottic edema, foreign bodies, and tracheal tumors. It is only a temporary measure that is used until definitive care is provided. 

The cylinder with a blue body and white shoulder is the Entonox cylinder. Its PIN index is 7. Entonox is 50:50 mixture of nitrous oxide and oxygen, popularly used as labor analgesia in maternity suites.

Blue cylinders are used to store nitrous oxide. The pin index of these cylinders is 3, 5.

Related Pearl: Coding of gas cylinders

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the deposits that would be seen in amyloidosis?

choices.text: Deposits look like amorphous eosinophilic material under normal light with H&E stain.
Congo red stain imparts green birefringence when viewed under polarized light.
Perl's Prussian blue gives the deposits a dark blue color.
Congo red stain imparts pink color to deposits under normal light.

questions.solution:
Perl's Prussian blue stain is used in hemochromatosis to stain liver tissue, which shows hepatocellular iron. Iron is stained blue with this stain.

Amyloidosis refers to extracellular deposits of fibrillar proteins. 

Abnormal fibrils are produced by the aggregation of misfolded proteins. The fibrillar deposits bind a wide variety of proteoglycans and glycosaminoglycans, including heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate, and plasma proteins, notably serum amyloid P component (SAP). Amyloid appears as an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline, extracellular substance.

It could be classified as systemic, localized, and hereditary amyloidosis. Microscopically, all types of amyloid deposits are made up of continuous, nonbranching fibrils. A characteristic cross-β-pleated sheet conformation is visualized on X-ray crystallography and infrared spectroscopy.

The stain used for amyloid deposits is congo red staining, which imparts pink to red color to the amyloid under ordinary light and apple-green birefringence under polarised microscopy.

The image shows a congo-red stained biopsy specimen with the following:

(A) focal positive staining (orange-red) of amorphous extracellular material

(B) apple-green birefringence under polarized light 

The next best step is to determine the type of precursor protein by immunohistochemistry, immunoelectron microscopy, or extraction and biochemical analysis using mass spectrometry.

Amyloid deposits and Paget cells observed in Paget disease are stained by Alcian blue.

questions.text: What is the appearance of colonies produced by Salmonella on Wilson and Blair medium?

choices.text: Jet-black colonies with a metallic sheen
Transparent colonies with a green center

questions.solution:
Jet-black colonies with a metallic sheen are produced by Salmonella on Wilson and Blair medium.

Salmonella typhi reduces sulphite to sulphide in the presence of glucose and produces jet-black colonies with a metallic sheen due to the production of H2S on the Wilson and Blair bismuth sulphite medium. The Wilson and Blair medium is selective for Salmonella species. It is a type of selective and indicator media. It also serves as a differential media. While S. typhi forms large black colonies with a metallic sheen, Salmonella paratyphi A produces green colonies due to the absence of H2S production.

An image of Wilson and Blair medium is given below:


On thiosulfate-citrate-bile salt-sucrose agar (TCBS) agar:

  • Vibrio cholerae forms yellow colonies. 

 

  • Vibrio vulnificus may form colorless colonies.
  • Vibrio parahemolyticus forms transparent colonies with a green center.

questions.text:
A positive rheumatoid factor test result may be seen in patients with which of the following conditions?
  1. Tuberculosis
  2. Infective endocarditis
  3. Hepatitis B
  4. Hepatitis C
  5. Systemic lupus erythematosus
questions.solution:
A positive rheumatoid factor (RF) test result may be seen in patients with any of the listed conditions.

Antibodies against the Fc fragment of immunoglobulin G (IgG) are called rheumatoid factors. IgM RF has been found in 75–80% of patients with rheumatoid arthritis. IgG and IgA isotypes of RF have also been identified. However, RF is not specific for rheumatoid arthritis and can also be found in the following conditions:

  • Primary Sjögren’s syndrome
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Subacute bacterial endocarditis
  • Hepatitis B and C
  • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener’s granulomatosis)
  • Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis
  • Tuberculosis
  • Infective endocarditis

questions.text: A patient who was started on varenicline for smoking cessation now presents with insomnia and disturbed sleep. Which of the following is the best course of action?

choices.text: Reduce the dose of varenicline and watch for symptom improvement.
Switch the patient to nicotine chewing gum.
Switch the patient to nicotine nasal spray.

questions.solution:
Since varenicline is the most effective drug in smoking cessation, and the patient has presented with a non-serious adverse effect, the best course of management would be to reduce the dose of varenicline or avoid the evening dose and watch for symptom improvement.

Since all three medications used for smoking cessation can be effective at lower doses as well, it is better to try dose reduction as a primary measure in patients with non-serious adverse effects.

Nicotine is the principal constituent of tobacco responsible for its addictive behaviour. One of the newest agents introduced to aid in smoking cessation is varenicline. Varenicline works by blocking the effects of nicotine on the brain. It blocks α-4, β-2 nicotinic acetylcholine receptor subtypes, inhibits dopaminergic activation produced by smoking through their partial agonism, and decreases the craving and withdrawal syndrome that occurs with cessation attempts. It prevents nicotine stimulation of the mesolimbic dopamine system associated with nicotine addiction, thus helping to occlude the "rewarding" effect of smoking.

Varenicline is prescribed only to patients 18 years or older. Varenicline is taken orally at a dose of 0.5 mg OD on days 1 to 3, which is then increased to 0.5 mg BD on days 4 through 7 and 1 mg twice daily after day 8 for 11 weeks. Therapy should start one week before the target quit date. It can be continued for another 12 weeks (1 mg BD) to maintain abstinence.

The adverse effects include nausea, which can be mitigated by starting at lower doses and gradually increasing the dose. Other symptoms include disturbed sleep, sleepwalking, agitation, drowsiness, and constipation; it may also increase the risk of pancreatitis. Varenicline has also been implicated in specific skin syndromes such as Stevens-Johnson syndrome, erythema multiforme, and photosensitivity. Varenicline can cause renal failure and kidney stones; therefore, renal function must be monitored.

The FDA has issued a warning about mood and behavioral changes associated with its use, and there is some evidence of increased cardiovascular risk.

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the steps involved in excitation-contraction coupling of smooth muscle cells.

 

  1. Myosin phosphorylation
  2. Increased influx of Ca2+ into the cell
  3. Activation of calmodulin-dependent myosin light chain kinase
  4. Increased myosin ATPase activity and binding of myosin to actin
  5. Contraction
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of events involved is:

  • Binding of acetylcholine to muscarinic receptors
  • Increased influx of Ca2+ into the cell
  • Activation of calmodulin-dependent myosin light chain kinase
  • Myosin phosphorylation
  • Increased myosin ATPase activity and binding of myosin to actin
  • Contraction
  • Dephosphorylation of myosin by myosin light chain phosphatase
  • Relaxation or sustained contraction due to the latch bridge and other mechanisms

questions.text: A 14-year-old male patient presents with pain around the knee joint. His radiographic image is given below. All of the following statements are true regarding his condition, except that _____.

choices.text: It is the most common primary malignant bone tumor.
First-line agents used in neoadjuvant therapy are doxorubicin and cisplatin.
Wide excision is used in the management.

questions.solution:
The given scenario and the X-ray image showing sunburst appearance and Codman's triangle in the proximal tibia are suggestive of osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the bone, with bimodal age of distribution peaking in adolescence and during the 7th decade.

The most common site involved is the distal femoral metaphysis, which mainly presents with pain and swelling. Other sites commonly involved are the proximal tibia, proximal femur, and humerus.

X-rays are diagnostic showing Codman’s triangle (new bone formation in response to periosteal elevation) and a ‘sunburst’ appearance when the periosteum does not have enough time to lay down a new layer. 

Wide excision and reconstruction are preferred if the tumor is resectable and there are no skip lesions. It is done after starting neoadjuvant chemotherapy for 8-12 weeks. Chemotherapeutic agents used are doxorubicin, cisplatin, ifosfamide, and methotrexate.

questions.text: Gonadal mosaicism is implicated in the inheritance pattern of which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
Gonadal mosaicism is implicated in the inheritance pattern of osteogenesis imperfecta.

Gonadal mosaicism is a mutation that occurs only in egg or sperm cells and the individual will be phenotypically normal. These individuals with gonadal mosaicism can transmit the disease-causing mutation to the offspring through their mutated gametes. The inheritance pattern shows autosomal dominant disorder, where some patients do not have phenotypically affected parents. The disorder can result from a new mutation in the egg or the sperm from which the zygote was formed. The siblings may or may not be affected. 

In some cases, mosaicism can result from a mutation that occurs after the formation of the zygote, during early (embryonic) development. If the mutation affects only the gonadal cells, the gametes carry the mutation, but the somatic cells of the individual are completely normal. A phenotypically normal parent who has gonadal mosaicism can transmit the disease-causing mutation to the offspring through their mutated ova/sperm. Therefore, there is a possibility that more than one child of such a parent can be affected.

Osteogenesis imperfecta is an example of a condition in which phenotypically normal parents can have more than one affected child.

 

An alternate way of solving this question would have been to just pick the condition that is autosomal dominant, and not autosomal recessive.

questions.text:
What would you advise regarding the vaccination against pneumococcal infection for a child who is HIV positive?

PCV - Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine

choices.text: The national schedule for PCV should be followed as usual
The vaccine is administered if the CD4 count > 800
A single dose primary vaccination should be administered
Pneumococcal vaccines should not be administered

questions.solution:
Even in children with HIV infection, the national schedule for PCV should be followed as usual.

Regardless of the presence of underlying medical conditions (e.g., children with HIV infection, sickle cell disease, or who are otherwise immunocompromised), PCV should be given according to the national schedule. PCV is safe and well-tolerated among HIV-infected children. Children with HIV infection require a booster dose to sustain protection.

Pneumococcal vaccines include:

  • Pneumococcal conjugate vaccines (PCV): 10-valent (PCV10) and 13-valent (PCV13)
  • Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV): 23-valent polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23)

The Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV) 13: It includes purified capsular polysaccharides of 13 serotypes of Streptococcus pneumoniae conjugated to a nontoxic variant of diphtheria toxin. Both PCV10 and PCV13 are preservative-free and their recommended storage temperature is 2-8°C. The vaccine must not be frozen.

WHO recommends 3 primary doses or 2 primary doses plus one booster of the PCV vaccine. In India, 2 primary doses at 6 and 14 weeks and 1 booster is given at 9-12 months.

Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine - PPSV23: It contains polysaccharide antigen from 23 types of pneumococcal bacteria and is available for adults and children over 2 years of age. Children under 2 years of age and immunocompromised individuals do not respond well to the vaccine. It is recommended for selected groups such as:

  • Post splenectomy
  • Sickle-cell disease
  • Chronic diseases of heart, lung, liver, or kidney
  • Generalized malignancies
  • Organ transplants

questions.text:
Which of the following enzymes catalyze a reversible reaction in the pentose phosphate pathway?
  1. Ribose-5-phosphate ketoisomerase
  2. 6-Phosphogluconate dehydrogenase
  3. Ribulose-5-phosphate 3-epimerase
  4. Transketolase
  5. Transaldolase
questions.solution:
6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase is involved in the irreversible oxidative phase of the pentose phosphate pathway. Transketolase, Transaldolase, Ribose-5-phosphate ketoisomerase, and Ribulose-5-phosphate 3-epimerase are involved in the reversible non-oxidative phase.

The pentose phosphate pathway, also known as the HMP shunt pathway, is an alternative route for the metabolism of glucose. It contributes in two major ways:

  • Formation of NADPH for the synthesis of fatty acids and steroids and maintenance of reduced glutathione for antioxidant activity
  • Formation of ribose for the synthesis of nucleic acid and nucleotides

The enzymes for this pathway are found in the cytosol. There are two phases:

  1. Irreversible oxidative phase: Glucose-6-phosphate is dehydrogenated and decarboxylated to form ribulose-5-phosphate.
  2. Reversible nonoxidative phase: Ribulose-5-phosphate is converted back to glucose-6-phosphate.

Clinical significance:

  • Protection against hemolysis: NADPH is utilized for the reduction of oxidized glutathione. Reduced glutathione removes H2O2, thereby preventing oxidative damage to RBCs and hemolysis. Thus, deficiency of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase results in hemolytic anemia.
  • Formation of glucuronate: Glucose-6-phosphate gives rise to glucoronate via the uronic acid pathway. Glucoronate is important as a precursor for proteoglycans and as a conjugate for substances like steroid hormones and drugs for their excretion in bile or urine. A deficiency in the uronic acid pathway results in essential pentosuria.
  • Fructose and galactose metabolism: Fructose bypasses the regulatory step in the HMP pathway and undergoes rapid glycolysis in the liver. This results in the increased fatty acid synthesis and VLDL secretion. Galactose formed from glucose is an essential constituent of lactose, glycolipids, proteoglycans, and glycoproteins. Deficiencies of enzymes in these reactions lead to metabolic diseases like essential fructosuria, hereditary fructose intolerance, and galactosemia.
  • Formation of amino sugars: Amino sugars are formed from glucose and are important components of glycoproteins, glycosphingolipids, and glycosaminoglycans.

questions.text: Insertion of a nasogastric tube would be least suitable in which of the following situations?

choices.text: To aspirate blood from the stomach in a patient who has undergone esophageal variceal banding
To do gastric decompression in a patient with suspected small intestinal obstruction
To administer enteral medication in a patient who is comatose
To administer nutritional support for a patient who is unable to tolerate oral intake but has functional GI tract

questions.solution:
Insertion of a nasogastric tube would be least suitable to aspirate blood from the stomach in a patient who has undergone esophageal variceal banding.

Indications for NG tube :

  • Gastric decompression in intestinal obstruction
  • Aspiration of gastric fluid
  • Nutritional support
  • Administration of medication

Contraindications:

Absolute:

  • Severe midface trauma
  • Recent nasal surgery

Relative:

  • Coagulation abnormality
  • Esophageal varices
  • Recent banding of esophageal varices
  • Anastomoses in the stomach and esophagus

Instruments tray used for nasogastric tube insertion: 

Nasogastric tubes play a standard role in treating intestinal obstruction and can also be used to provide nutritional support. The commonly used method to determine the length of a nasogastric tube is the NEX method (the tip of the nose to ear to xiphisternum). The approximate length to be inserted is 55cms. 

Ideally, Ryle's tube is inserted in the sitting position with the neck slightly flexed. Confirmation of the correct position is done by the following:

  • Auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air
  • An abdominal radiograph is the best way to confirm the location of the tube

The ideal location for an NG tube placed for suction is within the stomach because placement past the pylorus can cause damage to the duodenum. The ideal location for an NG feeding tube is postpyloric to decrease the risk of aspiration.

questions.text: A nursing mother was prescribed progestasert for contraception. When should you advise her to get it replaced?
questions.solution:
Progestasert would require annual replacements.

Progestasert is a T-shaped device carrying 38 mg of progesterone in a silicon oil reservoir in the vertical stem. It releases 65 μg of progesterone/day. The progesterone released causes the formation of a thick plug of mucus at the cervical os. This prevents entry of the sperms in addition to the local contraceptive effect of IUCDs.

There is lesser incidence of menstrual problems like menorrhagia and dysmenorrhoea compared to copper-containing intrauterine devices. However, it is expensive and requires yearly replacement.

questions.text: Performing a ferric chloride test on the urine sample of a patient with phenylketonuria would result in the formation of which of the following colors?
questions.solution:
Performing a ferric chloride test on the urine sample of a patient with phenylketonuria would result in the formation of green color.

The FeCl3 test is used to detect urinary phenylpyruvate. In a test tube with 1 mL of fresh urine, 3-4 drops of 10 gm% ferric chloride is added. A positive test reveals a transient green color due to the formation of a ferric phenol complex. 

Phenylpyruvate, phenyl lactate, phenylacetate, and phenyl acetyl glutamate are products of alternative pathways of phenylalanine catabolism.

questions.text: The peripheral smear of a patient with CLL shows the following characteristic cells. These are produced due to _________.

choices.text: Accumulation of immunoglobulin chains within the cell
Accumulation of eosinophilic material within the cell
Accumulation of GAG within the cell

questions.solution:
The given image shows smudge cells in CLL, and these are produced due to tumor cell disruption during smearing.

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL)/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma (SLL):

CLL and SLL differ only in the degree of peripheral blood lymphocytes. CLL is the most common leukemia of adults in the western world. The median age of diagnosis is 60 years. The most common genetic anomalies seen are deletions of 13q14.3, 11q, and 17p and trisomy 12q. Loss of tumor-suppressor genes in chromosome 13 results in overexpression of the anti-apoptotic protein BCL2.

The growth of CLL/SLL cells is confined to the proliferation centers (pathognomonic for CLL/SLL), where the tumor cells receive critical factors from the surrounding environments, such as NF-κB for cell survival, MYC for cell growth, and Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) signaling pathway.

The tumor cells express CD19, CD20, CD23, and CD5. Smudge cells are also characteristic of CLL. Clinical features include easy fatiguability, weight loss, anorexia, generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatomegaly, and hemolytic anemia. CLL/SLL has a tendency to transform to a more aggressive diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL); this is called Richter syndrome.

The peripheral smear in CLL shows small round lymphocytes (indicated by arrow) with condensed chromatin and scant cytoplasm. Some of these cells may get disrupted while preparing the smears, producing smudge cells (indicated by arrowhead).

questions.text:
You see the senior resident ordering the following for a patient with end-stage kidney disease. What is the electrolyte abnormality that he is trying to correct?
  1. Intravenous calcium gluconate 
  2. Regular insulin with dextrose 
  3. Salbutamol nebulization
questions.solution:
The most likely electrolyte abnormality that is being corrected using the above is hyperkalemia.

Hyperkalemia is defined as a serum potassium level of more than 5.5 mEq/L. It can cause drastic conduction changes. It can be diagnosed by a sequence of changes affecting the ST-T segments and QRS complex. ST-T segment changes reflect a change in repolarization, while QRS complex changes reflect a change in depolarization.

The ECG changes that can be seen in hyperkalemia depend on the extent of hyperkalemia. 

S. No. Serum potassium level ECG change
1 5.5–6.5 mEq/L Tall, peaked T waves with 'tented' or 'pinched' shape
2 6.5–7.5 mEq/L Loss of P waves
3 7.0–8.0 mEq/L Widened QRS complex
4 > 8.0 mEq/L Sine wave

Drugs that cause hyperkalemia include the following:

  • Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors
  • Angiotensin receptor blockers, e.g. losartan 
  • Mineralocorticoid receptor blockers like spirinolactone, eplerenone, and drospirenone
  • Epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) blockers like amiloride, triamterene, trimethoprim, pentamidine, and nafamostat

The most common cause of hyperkalemia is kidney failure. 

Treatment of hyperkalemia involves the following:

  1. Administer intravenous calcium gluconate, which raises the threshold and reduces excitability. It is cardioprotective.
  2. Administer regular insulin with dextrose. The insulin will reduce the serum potassium concentration by causing an intracellular shift. The dextrose will counteract the hypoglycemic effects of insulin.
  3. Provide salbutamol nebulization, which will also shift potassium inside the cell.
  4. Remove potassium with calcium-based resins, diuretics, or hemodialysis.

questions.text: In congenital rubella syndrome, when there is no viral culture data, you should advise contact precaution for:
questions.solution:
In congenital rubella syndrome, contact precaution is advised for 1 year unless nasopharyngeal and urine cultures are repeatedly negative after 3 months of age.

Contact Precautions are intended to prevent the transmission of infectious agents which are spread by direct or indirect contact with the patient or the patient’s environment. While caring for patients on contact precautions, wear a gown and gloves for all interactions that may involve contact with the patient or potentially contaminated areas in the patient’s environment.

Rubella or German measles is a serious infection in pregnancy that causes abortions or severe defects in the fetus if affected in the first trimester. Transmission of the virus occurs through nasopharyngeal secretions (droplets transmission). The mother usually has a fever and generalised body rash. The rash is maculopapular in nature that begins from the face and spreads to the trunk and extremities later. The incidence and severity reduce as the pregnancy advances and is rare after 20 weeks of gestation. 

There is no specific treatment for rubella virus infection in mothers. Post-exposure passive immunization can be beneficial if given within 5 days of exposure to droplets. The incidence of this disease has reduced due to the availability of MMR vaccines. MMR vaccines can be administered only to non-pregnant females as it is a live, attenuated virus. Pregnancy should be avoided for at least 1 month after vaccination.

Triad of Gregg is seen in babies with congenital rubella syndrome. The features include:

  • Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)
  • Cataract
  • Sensorineural Hearing loss (SNHL)

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text:
Which of the following diseases are listed as priority diseases as per the WHO's Research and Development blueprint?
  1. COVID-19
  2. Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever
  3. Ebola virus disease
  4. Nipah virus disease
  5. Zika
  6. Disease X
questions.solution:
All of the above-mentioned diseases are listed as priority diseases as per the WHO's Research and Development blueprint

As the number of potential pathogens is very large, and the resources for disease research and development (R&D) are limited, the WHO has this list of priority diseases for optimal utilization of these resources in public health emergency context. A WHO tool distinguishes which diseases pose the greatest public health risk due to their epidemic potential and/or whether there are no or insufficient countermeasures.

At present, the priority diseases are:

  1. COVID-19
  2. Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever
  3. Ebola virus disease and Marburg virus disease
  4. Lassa fever
  5. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) and Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)
  6. Nipah and henipaviral diseases
  7. Rift Valley fever
  8. Zika
  9. “Disease X” - Disease X represents the knowledge that a serious international epidemic could be caused by a pathogen currently unknown to cause human disease. 

It is important to note that this list is not exhaustive and that it does not indicate the most likely causes of the next epidemic.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is referred to your center for evaluation of short stature. The child's parents are found to be first cousins. Further evaluation led to the diagnosis of Laron-type dwarfism. What is the best-suited management for her condition?

choices.text: Recombinant human growth hormone releasing hormone

questions.solution:
Laron-type dwarfism, also known as GH-insensitivity syndrome, is characterized by GH-receptor anomalies. Treatment is by subcutaneous injections of recombinant insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) (a growth-promoting hormone).

Laron-type dwarfism is an autosomal recessive disorder. The primary clinical symptom associated with this condition is short stature. The recombinant human growth hormone therapy is often ineffective in Laron syndrome. Only some cases with partial growth hormone insensitivity may show a response at high doses.

questions.text: While doing an Apgar scoring on a newborn, you would assign a score of 1 for all of the following findings, except:
questions.solution:
Active motion of extremities/well-flexed extremities is assigned an APGAR score of 2, not 1.

questions.text: The consultant asks you to add chlordiazepoxide to the charts of a patient with alcohol withdrawal. What route of administration should you mention for this drug?

choices.text: Loading dose administered as IV infusion and subsequent doses as subcutaneous injection

questions.solution:
Chlordiazepoxide should be administered orally. Only oral preparations of chlordiazepoxide are available.


Treatment of Alcohol Withdrawal

  • For patients showing withdrawal symptoms, Chlordiazepoxide 25–50 mg every 2–4 hours can be administered orally. 
  • For patients with delirium tremens, 50–100 mg of chlordiazepoxide should be administered every 4 hours.
  • If oral administration of drugs is not possible, intravenous lorazepam (0.1 mg/kg) can be given.

questions.text: Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in a patient with serotonin syndrome?
questions.solution:
Patients on MAO inhibitor + SSRI can develop serotonin syndrome, which is characterized by fever, clonus, hyperreflexia, and tremors.

Serotonin syndrome can occur with any drug that increases 5-HT levels (e.g., MAOIs, SSRIs, SNRIs, TCAs, tramadol, ondansetron, triptans, linezolid, MDMA, and dextromethorphan). Coadministration of these drugs results in increased serotonin and norepinephrine levels, which are responsible for the autonomic symptoms of serotonin syndrome.

It is characterized by 3 A’s:

  • Neuromuscular hyperActivity- clonus, hyperreflexia, hypertonia, tremor, and seizure
  • Autonomic stimulation - hyperthermia, diaphoresis, diarrhoea 
  • Agitation

Treatment: Cyproheptadine (5-HT2 receptor antagonist).

questions.text: Common carotid artery bifurcates at the level of _______.
questions.solution:
The bifurcation of the common carotid artery is at the upper border of the thyroid cartilage, at the level of the C3-C4 junction.

The course of the common carotid artery (CCA):

  • The right and the left common carotid arteries differ in their origin:
    • The right CCA arises from the brachiocephalic artery
    • The left CCA arises directly from the arch of the aorta
  • In the neck, it is enclosed within the carotid sheath along with the internal jugular vein and vagus nerve.
  • It ascends upwards up to the upper border of the thyroid cartilage (C3-4 junction) and divides into internal and external carotid arteries.

Clinical significance of carotid bifurcation:

  • Chassaignac/carotid tubercle/transverse process of C6 vertebra: The pulsations of the common carotid artery can be felt by compressing the artery against this tubercle. 
  • Site of carotid body tumor
  • The most common site for carotid atherosclerosis. It can lead to stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA).
  • In carotid endarterectomy, the presence of high bifurcation predisposes to injury to the cranial nerves, commonly the hypoglossal nerve or marginal mandibular nerve. In such patients, carotid stenting is usually preferred to carotid endarterectomy.

 

Carotid body tumors present at the bifurcation of the CCA and cause the external carotid artery (ECA) and internal carotid artery (ICA) to spread out, or splay, which is called 'Lyre sign' as seen on carotid angiography.

Related Pearl: Internal carotid artery branches

Part
Course
 Branches
Cervical part
Originates from the bifurcation of the common carotid artery. It has a dilation at the lower end which is known as carotid sinus. It ascends in front of the transverse process of the upper three cervical vertebrae.
 No branches given
Petrous part
Passes through the carotid canal in the petrous part of the temporal bone
  • Caroticotympanic branch
  • Artery to the pterygoid canal
Cavernous part
Runs in the cavernous sinus
  • Branch to the trigeminal ganglion
  • Meningeal branch
  • Branch to the cavernous sinus
  • Hypophyseal branches
Cerebral part/ Supracavernal part
Enters subarachnoid space by piercing arachnoid mater and divides into the anterior and middle cerebral arteries.
  • Ophthalmic artery
  • Anterior choroidal artery
  • Posterior communicating artery

The petrous, cavernous and intracranial parts of the internal carotid artery are called the carotid siphon because of its sigmoid course.

questions.text: You notice the following clinical findings in a patient with psoriasis. This lesion is known as
questions.solution:
A hypopigmented ring surrounding individual psoriatic lesions is known as the Woronoff ring.

It is usually associated with treatment, most commonly UV radiation or topical corticosteroids. The pathogenesis of the Woronoff ring is not well understood, but may result from the inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis.

Other options:

Option A: Herald patch is the first and most common lesion seen in pityriasis rosea. The image below shows a Herald patch:


Option B: Halo nevi are acquired melanocytic nevi circumferentially surrounded by a depigmented patch. They are commonly associated with vitiligo. The image below shows a halo nevus:


Option C: Target lesions are seen in erythema multiforme. They are associated with multiple concentric zones. The image below shows target lesions (white arrows):

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT)?
  1. It typically occurs 5–10 days after the initiation of heparin therapy.
  2. A negative result in enzyme-linked immunoassay excludes the diagnosis of HIT.
  3. The most specific diagnostic test for HIT is the serotonin release assay.
  4. Platelet transfusions can be given if platelet level is below 40000/μL.
  5. Warfarin should not be used until platelet levels return to normal.
questions.solution:
Statements that are true for heparin-induced thrombocytopenia are as follows:

  1. It typically occurs 5–10 days after the initiation of heparin therapy.
  2. A negative result in enzyme-linked immunoassay excludes the diagnosis of HIT.
  3. The most specific diagnostic test for HIT is the serotonin release assay.
  4. Platelet transfusions should not be given to patients with HIT.
  5. Warfarin should not be used till platelet levels return to normal.

HIT is a life-threatening complication of exposure to heparin. It occurs more often with unfractionated heparin than with low-molecular-weight (LMW) heparin. It is common in surgical patients and is more common in women than in men.

HIT results from an autoantibody directed against endogenous platelet factor 4 (PF4) in complex with heparin. These antibodies bind simultaneously to the heparin-PF4 complex and to platelet Fc receptors, activating the platelets and generating platelet microparticles. This can cause catastrophic arterial and venous thrombosis.

Features:

  • Thrombocytopenia: Platelet count of ≤100,000/μL or a decrease of ≥50% in platelet count 
  • Platelet count falls 5–10 days after starting heparin.
  • Venous thrombosis is more common than arterial thrombosis.

Investigations:

  1. ELISA to detect antibodies against heparin-PF4 complexes (highly sensitive)
  2. Platelet activation assays
  3. Serotonin release assay (most specific)

Treatment:

  1. Stop all heparin.
  2. Give an alternative anticoagulant, such as lepirudin, argatroban, bivalirudin, fondaparinux, or rivaroxaban.
  3. Do not give platelet transfusions.
  4. Warfarin should not be used until platelet levels return to normal.

 

Patients with HIT, particularly those with associated thrombosis, have increased thrombin generation, which can lead to the consumption of protein C. If these patients are given warfarin without a concomitant parenteral anticoagulant to inhibit thrombin or thrombin generation, the further decrease in protein C levels induced by the vitamin K antagonist can trigger skin necrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes does not belong to class 5 of enzyme classification as per the IUBMB system of classification (International Union of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology)?
questions.solution:
Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase is a ligase - class 6.

Class 5 enzymes are isomerases.

questions.solution:
In the Darrow-Yannet diagram marked C, there is hypo-osmotic volume expansion with an increase in both ECF & ICF volumes, which is consistent with SIADH.

In SIADH, excessive secretion of ADH leads to excess water being retained in the body. So, ECF volume rises. ECF osmolality decreases. ECF fluid enters ICF until osmotic equilibrium is re-established. So, ICF volume rises, ICF osmolality decreases.

questions.text: When does premenstrual syndrome  typically occur?

choices.text: 1–3 days prior to menstruation and spontaneously resolves 3 days after menses
5–7 days prior to menstruation and spontaneously resolves 3 days after menses
1–3 days prior to menstruation and spontaneously resolves after menses
7–14 days prior to menstruation and spontaneously resolves after menses

questions.solution:
Premenstrual syndrome (premenstrual tension) is a functional disorder and is recognized by cyclical changes that are associated with ovulatory cycles. It is usually seen in middle-aged women, and occurs 1-2 weeks before menstruation and resolves after menses. 

The classical symptoms include abdominal cramps, increasing breast tenderness, abdominal bloating, headache, sleeplessness, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, and mood swings. The diagnosis is made on the basis of a carefully elicited history. Asking patients to document their symptoms in the form of a menstrual diary can also aid in diagnosis. 

Treatment includes counseling and therapy for psychological symptoms, medical treatment with danazol and GnRH analogs for breast tenderness, and treatment for pelvic pain and bloatedness.

questions.text: A patient with suspected thoracic outlet syndrome is being examined. Hyperabduction of the arm on the affected side causes a reduction in the radial artery pulsation. What is this test known as?
questions.solution:
Hyperabduction maneuver to demonstrate a fall in radial pulse volume is known as Wright's test.

This reduction in volume is due to compression of the artery by the pectoralis minor tendon. An axillary bruit may be heard on auscultation.

Related Pearl: Thoracic outlet syndrome and its tests:

Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is a neurovascular syndrome caused due to the compression of the lower trunk of brachial plexus (C8 and T1) and subclavian vessels in the thoracic outlet between the clavicle, the first rib, and scalene muscles.

Clinical features due to compression of:

  • Brachial plexus: Pain and paraesthesia along the ulnar aspect of the arm.
  • Subclavian vessels: Cyanosis, cold fingers, pallor and Raynaud's phenomenon.

Provocative tests: Adson's test, Halstead's maneuver, Wright's test, Roos test.

Adson’s test: The examiner locates the radial pulse while arm is held in extension, external rotation, and slight abduction. The patient is instructed to take a deep breath and turn head towards the test arm while extending the neck. This manoeuvre will tense the anterior and middle scalenes. If there is outlet obstruction, the radial pulse will get diminished or absent on that side. 

Halstead maneuver (reverse Adson's): The examiner palpates the radial pulse and applies downward traction on the tested extremity while the patient’s neck is hyperextended and rotated to the opposite side. Diminished or absent pulse indicates a positive test.

Wright’s hyperabduction test: The examiner palpates the radial pulse and hyper-abducts the arm. The patient takes a deep breath and may rotate or extend his neck for additional effect. Absence of pulse indicates a positive test.

Roos test: The patient abducts the shoulders to 90 degrees and flexes the elbow to 90 degrees. The patient is made to open and close the hand repeatedly for three minutes. The test is positive if the patient is unable to complete the test or experiences cramping, pain, numbness, on the affected side.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man, with a known doxycycline allergy, presented with painful swellings on both sides of the groin, as shown in the image. Which of the following is suitable to treat his condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of painful swellings and the image of enlarged lymph nodes in both groins indicate inguinal adenitis, or buboes, in this patient. These findings are suggestive of lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). The first-line therapy for LGV is doxycycline for 21 days. But, since this patient is allergic to doxycycline, erythromycin for 21 days, which is considered the second-line agent, can be used as an alternative.   

LGV is a sexually transmitted disease caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis.

It occurs in three stages:

  • The primary stage lasts for about 3–30 days after infection, and the lesion is a single, non-indurated, shallow ulcer or pustule or papule that may be painless. It heals rapidly, without any scar formation.
  • The secondary stage occurs about 2-6 weeks after the primary stage and manifests as painful lymphadenopathy that may be unilateral or bilateral and enlarged, tender, painful glands in the groin called buboes. A groove-like depression may be observed above and below the inguinal ligament due to enlargement of femoral or inguinal lymph nodes; this is called the groove sign.
  • The tertiary stage follows chronic untreated infection. It is associated with stricture formation and fibrosis and fistulae of the anogenital region. Chronic disfiguring granulomatous fibrosis and scarring of the vulva with esthiomene formation are also observed in this stage.

The given image shows esthiomene, a feature of LGV.  

Related Pearl: Comparison of Genital Ulcers

  Genital herpes  Syphilitic chancre (Hard chancre) Donovanosis/ granuloma inguinale Chancroid (soft chancre) LGV

Painless lymphadenopathy

Painless papule or nodule erodes into beefy red granulomatous ulcer with rolled edges.

No lymphadenopathy, pseudobubos are seen

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy

Painless genital ulcer.

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy

Treatment Acyclovir/famcyclovir or valacyclovir Penicillin/Ceftriaxone

Azithromycin/Doxycycline

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding subcenter?

choices.text: The risk of cold chain failure is highest at the subcenter and village level
A subcenter is set up for every 5000 population in normal areas
Delivery facilities will be available at type B subcenters only, not type A
A subcenter is set up for every 1000 population in hilly areas

questions.solution:
One sub-center is established for every 3000 population in hilly, tribal, and backward areas.

One subcentre is established for every 5000 population in normal areas. The risk of cold chain failure is greatest at the sub-center and village levels. Hence, vaccines are not stored at the sub-center level and are supplied only on the day of use. Type A sub-center will provide all recommended services except delivery services which will be made available at Type B subcenter/ MCH subcenter.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient was brought to the casualty following blunt trauma to the abdomen. His vitals are stable and examination reveals a positive Kehr's sign. What is the investigation of choice for the evaluation of this patient?
questions.solution:
A positive Kehr's sign in a patient with a history of blunt abdominal trauma is suggestive of splenic injury. CECT is the investigation of choice for evaluation of this patient as he is hemodynamically stable.

Blunt trauma to the spleen results in torsion of short gastric vessels in the gastrosplenic ligament leading to subphrenic hematoma. The irritation at the left hemidiaphragm by subphrenic hematoma leads to a positive Kehr's sign.

Initial investigation for abdominal injury in patients who are hemodynamically unstable is FAST (focused assessment with sonography in trauma) to explore for free fluid. In all hemodynamically stable patients, CT is the investigation of choice for identifying and characterizing splenic injuries.

Grades of splenic injury:

Grade Injury
I Subcapsular hematoma (<10% of surface area) Or Laceration, <1 cm of parenchymal depth
II Subcapsular hematoma (10-50% of surface area) Or Laceration, 1-3 cm of parenchymal depth which does not involve the trabecular vessels
III

Subcapsular Hematoma > 50% of surface area or expanding

  • ruptured subcapsular or parenchymal hematoma,
  • intraparenchymal hematoma >5 cm or expanding Or
    Laceration, >3 cm parenchymal depth or involving
    trabecular vessels
IV Laceration involving segmental or hilar vessels leading to major devascularization (>25% of the spleen)
V Shattered spleen
Or
A hilar vascular injury with complete devascularization.

 

The management approach depends on the grade of injury:

Grade I and Grade II injuries: Usually, they are hemodynamically stable so they can be managed non-operatively.  It includes adequate bed rest, and serial abdominal CECT monitoring of vitals has to be done. If any shift to a high-grade injury, angioembolisation can be done.

If the angioembolisation fails, a spleen-sparing technique called splenorraphy can be done.

Grade IV and V injuries: Usually, they are hemodynamically unstable so splenectomy is done.

Grade III injury: If they are hemodynamically stable, they are managed as grades I and II while those are hemodynamically unstable, they are managed as grades IV and V.

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Spleen Injury Scale

Related Pearl: Indications for Selective Non-Operative Management (SNOM) in splenic trauma

Indications :

  • Patient younger than 55 years
  • Grade I, II, or III (in selective cases) splenic injury
  • Physiologic stability, as indicated by normal blood pressure, lack of tachycardia, absence of physical examination findings indicating shock, and absence of metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image below
questions.solution:
The image is of the Priestley-Smith retinoscope. It is a mirror retinoscope and has a plane mirror at one end and concave at the other. It has a central hole of about 2.5mm anteriorly and 4mm posteriorly.

Retinoscopy is an objective method used to determine the error of refraction by applying the method of neutralization. It is also called skiascopy or shadow test. 

Principle: When light is reflected from a mirror into the eye, the direction in which light will travel across the pupil will depend upon the eye's refractive state. Distance: Usually, the doctor sits at a distance of 1 meter or an arm's length. Types of retinoscopes:

  • Priestley–Smith retinoscope
  • Streak retinoscope

The image given below shows a retinoscopy being performed on a patient.

The image below shows Jackson’s cross cylinder (flip-cross technique) which is used to refine the power and axis of the cylindrical lens.

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the steps involved in the processing of the primary transcript to mRNA.
  1. Primary transcript
  2. Lariat formation
  3. Cut at 3' end of intron
  4. Nucleophilic attack at 5' end of intron
  5. Ligation of 3' end of exon 1 to 5' end of exon 2
questions.solution:
The steps involved in the processing of the primary transcript to mRNA

  • Primary transcript
  • Nucleophilic attack at 5' end of intron
  • Lariat formation
  • Cut at 3' end of intron
  • Ligation of 3' end of exon 1 to 5' end of exon 2

After synthesis, eukaryotic RNA undergoes extensive post-transcriptional modifications including 7-methylguanosine capping, polyadenylation forming poly A tail, and splicing

  • 5' Capping: This is the first of the processing reactions for pre mRNA. The cap is a 7-methylguanosine attached backward to the 5'-terminal end of the mRNA, forming an unusual 5'→5' triphosphate linkage.
  • Poly-A tail is added after transcription by the nuclear enzyme polyadenylate polymerase, using ATP as the substrate. These tails help stabilize the mRNA, facilitate its exit from the nucleus, and aid in translation.
  • Maturation of eukaryotic mRNA usually involves the removal of introns & joining of exons together to form the mature mRNA. The process of removing introns and joining exons is called splicing. snRNA facilitates the removal of introns by forming base pairs with the consensus sequences at each end of the intron.

questions.text: Annual Mammography to screen for breast cancer would be considered as
questions.solution:
Screening is a type of secondary prevention.

It is done to detect the disease in its early stages before it becomes clinically apparent.

Related Pearl: Lead Time in Screening

Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of disease. Early treatment reduces the severity by reversing the disease process.

questions.text: A young male patient with a history of a motor vehicle accident is unable to pass urine. Blood is seen at the meatus. USG indicates a distended bladder and his retrograde urethrogram appears as below. How should you manage this patient?

choices.text: Insert a small size Foley's catheter

questions.solution:
A young patient with urinary retention, blood at the meatus, following a history of a motor vehicle accident, and the retrograde urethrogram showing contrast leakage at the membranous urethra is diagnostic of a membranous urethral rupture. Management of this patient should be done by inserting a suprapubic catheter. 

Urethral injuries in men usually occur after catheterization or during cystoscopy. Injuries following external trauma are rare, but mainly affect the bulbar or the membranous urethra.  Membranous urethral rupture usually occurs following a road traffic accident, crush injury, or a fall. It is associated with pelvic fracture and extraperitoneal bladder rupture. Clinical features include urinary retention, blood at the meatus, and a high-riding prostate on digital examination. Bruising is seen over the pubic area, scrotum, and penis.

Management is by inserting a suprapubic catheter. If there is an associated bladder rupture, the bladder will not be seen on the ultrasound, and management in such a case is by exploration, repair, and placement of a suprapubic catheter.

questions.text: The CT of a patient with a vertebral hemangioma would demonstrate _______.

choices.text: Corduroy sign in the axial section and Polka dot sign in the sagittal section
Corduroy sign in the sagittal section and Polka dot sign in the axial section
Both Corduroy sign and Polka dot sign in the sagittal section
Both Corduroy sign and Polka dot sign in the axial section

questions.solution:
In patients with vertebral hemangioma, corduroy sign is seen in the sagittal and coronal section and polka dot sign is seen in the axial section of CT scans.

Hemangioma is typically a benign tumor of the vertebral body. This tumor is mostly clinically silent and is usually detected incidentally. The vertebral body is the most common location for hemangioma. Atypical location of hemangioma is the posterior elements of the vertebra and is indicative of an aggressive lesion. Symptomatic hemangiomas usually present with pain, neurologic compromise, or fractures.

Radiographs show large lesions with vertical striations and coarse, thick trabeculae, giving a corduroy appearance in sagittal and coronal sections. It is also known as the jail bar sign.

On an axial computed tomography (CT) scan, hemangioma shows a classic polka dot appearance. MRI is the standard for diagnosing hemangiomas.

Treatment: Most hemangiomas do not require treatment. Vertebroplasty is useful in aggressive hemangiomas. 

The below CT image shows characteristic polka dot appearance (left) and corduroy appearance (right):

The name corduroy comes from the similarity to the corduroy cloth (seen in the image below) in appearance.

questions.solution:
Hysterosalpingography (HSG) in bilateral hydrosalpinx shows bilateral dilated fallopian tubes with no free spill, as shown in the image below.

Both fallopian tubes are patent with a spill into the peritoneal cavity in normal HSG.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding cardiovascular changes in pregnancy is false?
questions.solution:
Diastolic BP decreases during pregnancy.

Physiological changes in pregnancy

Cardiac output remains elevated throughout (maximum in the immediate postpartum period). This raise is due to the increased blood volume and to meet the increased oxygen requirements due to the pregnancy.

Clinical examination

  • Pulse rate: Increases. 
  • Pedal edema- although it can be a sign of cardiac disease, it is also a normal physiological change in pregnancy. 
  • The resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min
  • Diastolic BP: Decreases
  • Jugular venous distension and venous hum
  • The heart is displaced upwards and to the left
  • Mammary soufflé: Continuous murmur at 2nd to 4th intercostal space
  • S1 M increased and widely split
  • S2 P increased; S2 split
  • Occasional but prominent S3 at Mitral areaMurmurs
    • Ejection systolic murmur at the left sternal border.
    • Continuous murmur at 2nd-4th intercostal space (known as mammary souffle)

ECG changes

  • Left axis deviation (due to elevation of the diaphragm)
  • T wave inversion, Biatrial enlargement.
  • Mild ST changes in the inferior leads.
  • Premature atrial and ventricular contractions are relatively frequent.

Electrocardiography

  • T wave inversion, biatrial enlargement
  • Dysrhythmias
  • As the diaphragm is elevated in advancing pregnancy, there is a left-axis deviation in the electrocardiogram (ECG), and mild ST changes may be seen.
  • Atrial and ventricular premature contractions are relatively frequent
  • Tricuspid regurgitation
  • Increased left atrial end-diastolic dimension 
  • Increased left ventricular mass

X-ray:

X-Ray shows a larger cardiac silhouette (due to benign pericardial effusion and shifted apex)

Clinical indicators of heart disease during pregnancy-

Symptoms:

  • Progressive dyspnea or orthopnea
  • Nocturnal cough
  • Hemoptysis
  • Syncope
  • Chest pain 

Clinical signs:

  • Cyanosis
  • Clubbing of fingers
  • Persistent neck vein distention
  • Systolic murmur grade 3/6 or greater
  • Diastolic murmur
  • Cardiomegaly
  • Persistent tachycardia and/or arrhythmia
  • Persistent split-second sound
  • Fourth heart sound
  • Criteria for pulmonary hypertension

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding finasteride?

choices.text: New hair growth will be lost when finasteride is discontinued
Can be used safely in pregnant women
Causes reduction in volume of prostate

questions.solution:
Finasteride is highly teratogenic and pregnant women should not be exposed to the drug because of the potential for inducing genital abnormalities in male fetuses.

Finasteride is a competitive inhibitor of the 5α-reductase enzyme, thus inhibiting the conversion of testosterone into its active form DHT (Dihydrotestosterone), which is responsible for androgenic action in the prostate gland. It produces an effect on long-term use (nearly 6 months) by reducing prostatic epithelial cell proliferation, thereby reducing the size of the prostate and improving urine flow.

 

Finasteride inhibits type 2 5α‐reductase within the hair follicle, reducing the production of DHT. Hence it is used in the treatment of male pattern hair loss. But, new hair growth will be lost when finasteride is discontinued, similar to minoxidil.

Adverse effects of finasteride are:

  • Decreased libido
  • Erectile dysfunction
  • Ejaculation disorder, and decreased ejaculate volume.

questions.text: Which of the following biochemical assays would you advise to identify the vitamin deficiency that may manifest as neonatal seizures?
questions.solution:
Pyridoxine deficiency can cause refractory seizures in the neonatal period and infancy. Measurement of RBC transaminase provides an index of vitamin B6 nutritional status. 

These seizures are often multifocal clonic, usually starting during the first few hours of life. It involves a mutation in the ALDH7A1 gene, causing deficiency of an enzyme involved in the degradation of alpha-aminoadipic semialdehyde. Other mutations associated with congenital B6 deficiency includes PNPO deficiencies.

questions.text: Citrate is least likely to play a role in which of the following complications of massive blood transfusion?

choices.text: Decreased O2 carrying capacity of blood

questions.solution:
Decreased O2 carrying capacity of blood is due to reduced 2, 3 DPG levels.

Citrate is responsible for hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia, and metabolic alkalosis.

Related Pearl: Complications of a Massive Transfusion

Massive transfusion (MT) is defined as the replacement by transfusion of 10 units of pRBCs in 24 hours or more than 4 units of pRBCs in one hour.

Complications from massive transfusion include:

Complication Mechanism
Hypothermia As blood products are normally stored between 1°C and 6°C
Coagulopathy

MT with PRBCs alone causes a dilutional coagulopathy (vs consumptive coagulopathy caused by massive hemorrhage)

Can be prevented by starting early transfusion of FFP, platelets, pRBCs in a 1:1:1 ratio
Acidosis/ Alkalosis

Mild acidosis - increased CO2 levels in stored blood by 21-35 days

Metabolic alkalosis - citrate gets metabolized to bicarbonate

Metabolic acidosis - due to tissue hypoperfusion
Hyperkalemia/ Hypokalemia

Initially - Hyperkalemia, as stored blood has high K+ levels due to inactivated Na/K/ATPase pump

Later - Hypokalemia, due to intracellular potassium uptake and metabolic alkalosis
Hypocalcemia Stored blood is anticoagulated with citrate, which binds calcium.
Hypomagnesemia Infusion of large volumes of magnesium-poor fluids and binding of magnesium to citrate
Impaired O2-carrying capacity of hemoglobin Decreased 2, 3 DPG
Volume overload Due to massive transfusion

questions.text: To perform which of the following would you be facing the patient's feet?
questions.solution:
The fourth Leopold maneuver (also known as pelvic grip) is performed while facing the patient’s feet. It is used to detect the degree of descent. 

Leopold's maneuvers are used to assess fetal pole, lie, presenting part, engagement, and attitude of fetal head:

First Leopold (fundal grip):

  • Performed while facing the patient’s face
  • Assesses the uterine fundus
  • Helps in identification of fetal lie and determination of fetal pole at the fundus
  • Breech gives the sensation of a large, irregular mass 
  • Head feels hard and round and is more mobile

Second Leopold (lateral grip): 

  • Performed while facing the patient’s face
  • Assesses the fetal orientation
  • Palms are placed on either side of the maternal abdomen, and gentle but deep pressure is exerted
  • Back is felt on one side as a hard, resistant structure
  • Fetal extremities are felt on the other side as numerous small, irregular, mobile parts
  • Fetal orientation can be determined by noting whether the back is directed anteriorly, transversely, or posteriorly
  • The position of the anterior shoulder is mainly assessed by this grip

Pawlik's grip (third Leopold):

  • Performed while facing the patient’s face
  • Assesses the presenting part in respect to the true pelvis
  • Thumb and fingers of one hand grasp the lower portion of the maternal abdomen, just above the symphysis pubis
  • If the presenting part is not engaged, it can be grasped distinctly

Pelvic grip (fourth Leopold):

  • Assesses the engagement and attitude of the fetal head and also determines the degree of descent
  • Examiner faces the mother's feet, and the fingertips of both hands are positioned on either side of the presenting part
  • Fingers exert inward pressure and then slide along the axis of the pelvic inlet
  • The only grip performed facing the feet

questions.text: Administration of which of the following combinations is associated with an effect that is greater than the individual effects of the components?
questions.solution:
Combinations that are associated with an effect that is greater than that of the individual drugs are known as supra-additive drug combinations. Sulfamethoxazole + trimethoprim as an antibiotic agent is a supra-additive drug combination.

Additive drug combination: The effect of the two drugs is in the same direction and simply adds up

  • Aspirin+ paracetamol: as analgesic/antipyretic
  • Nitrous oxide + halothane: as a general anesthetic
  • Amlodipine + atenolol: as antihypertensive
  • Glibenclamide + metformin: as hypoglycaemic
  • Ephedrine + theophylline: as a bronchodilator

Supra-additive drug combination: The effect of the combination is greater than that of the individual drugs

  • Acetylcholine + physostigmine
  • Levodopa + carbidopa/benserazide
  • Adrenaline + cocaine/desipramine
  • Sulfamethaxozole + trimethoprim
  • Enalapril + hydrochlorothiazide
  • Tyramine + MAO inhibitor

questions.text:
Accidentally administering excess atropine to a patient would manifest as:
  1. Delirium
  2. Flushed face
  3. Hypothermia
  4. Increased thirst
  5. Miosis
questions.solution:
Excess atropine would manifest as delirium, flushing, and increased thrist. Hyperthermia and mydriasis are seen in atropine toxicity, not hypothermia and miosis.

Atropine is an anticholinergic drug. It acts through reversible, competitive inhibition of the postsynaptic muscarinic acetylcholine receptors. It is indicated in the treatment of organophosphate/muscarinic poisoning, in bradycardia, and to reduce salivary secretions.

The adverse effects of atropine are due to the antimuscarinic effects, including xerostomia, blurring of vision, photophobia, tachycardia, flushing, warm, dry skin, constipation, urinary retention, anhidrosis, delirium, and coma. Intoxication with atropine results in all the above symptoms along with convulsions, and circulatory collapse due to respiratory failure. Death may occur secondary to respiratory paralysis.

Below is an image of a mnemonic to remember the symptoms of atropine overdose.

Treatment of atropine intoxication includes administration of a short-acting barbiturate or diazepam to control convulsions. Physostigmine is used as an antidote to atropine poisoning to treat delirium and coma. Other measures for symptomatic management are respiratory support and control of hyperthermia.

 

Related Pearl: Specific antidotes for poisoning

questions.text: Which of the following is least suitable for the creation of pneumoperitoneum for laparoscopy?
questions.solution:
Oxygen is least suitable for the creation of pneumoperitoneum as there is a risk of fire on cautery use.

Laparoscopic surgeries can be done under general anesthesia or local anesthesia; however, general anesthesia is preferred. Air or the gases - carbon dioxide (CO2) or nitrous oxide (N2O), can be used for the creation of pneumoperitoneum for performing laparoscopic surgeries.

Carbon dioxide (CO2) gas is usually used and the maximum pressure is in the range of 14–15 mm Hg. But N2O is used if the procedure is done under local anesthesia. Insufflation with N2O is stopped at a pressure of 10 mmHg or when 2L of gas is insufflated.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a patient with carpal tunnel syndrome,which of the following tests is least relevant?
questions.solution:
Neer's test is used in the diagnosis of impingement syndrome/painful arc syndrome.

Clinical tests in carpal tunnel syndrome include the reproduction of sensory symptoms such as paresthesias and pain by performing the following tests:

  • Durkan's test - By applying direct median nerve compression for about 30 seconds.
  • Tinel's test (sign) - By percussing the median nerve.
  • Phalen's test - By holding the wrist in flexion for about 60 seconds.

The following image shows Phalen's test:

The diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome is usually clinical. Nerve conduction studies can be done in patients with atypical symptoms to confirm the diagnosis in case of atypical presentation of carpal tunnel syndrome. The tests will show slowing of nerve conduction across the wrist.

Carpal tunnel syndrome usually presents at an age of 40–50 years. The common risk factors are pregnancy, rheumatoid disease, renal failure, and gout.

Most of the patients present with burning pain, tingling, and numbness in the distribution of the median nerve. The symptoms worsen with activity and at night. Hanging the arm over the side of the bed and shaking the arm relieve the pain.

Night pain and pregnancy-related symptoms can be reduced by using splints to prevent wrist flexion. Temporary relief from pain can be attained using steroid injection and is a diagnostic tool also.

In patients with an intermediate and chronic syndrome, an early carpal tunnel release can be performed. This surgery is beneficial in most patients, and maximum improvement is seen in 6 months after the release.

 

Other options:

Neer's test: In patients with a positive Neer's impingement sign, injection of 10% lidocaine into subacromial space, and repeating the test demomstrates pain reduction. 

Related Pearl: Compression neuropathies

Syndrome

Pronator teres syndrome

Median nerve (proximally compressed beneath ligament of Struthers, bicipital aponeurosis, or origins of pronator teres)

Radial tunnel (Arcade of Frohse) syndrome

Posterior Interosseous nerve (in proximal forearm)

Lower trunk of brachial plexus

Mortons Metatarsalgia Interdigital plantar nerve
