questions.text: What is the amount of urinary protein excretion in a normal individual?

choices.text: Urinary Protein excretion does not occur in normal individuals

questions.solution:
The amount of urinary protein excretion in a normal individual is <150 mg/day.

Type of Proteinuria

  Total proteinuria (mg/day)

Albuminuria (mg/day)

Normal-range

 

<150  

Mainly Tamm-Horsfall protein (70–75 mg/day) 

<30
Moderately increased 150–500  30–300 
Severely increased >500  >300  
Orthostatic proteinuria 150–500   —

Normally, the following mechanisms prevent proteinuria:

  • The glomerular basement membrane acts as a barrier to prevent the loss of negatively charged and large proteins.
  • Reabsorption of small proteins in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT).

Various types of proteinuria:

  1. Glomerular - increased filtration of proteins due to disruption of basement membrane
  2. Tubular - damage to tubules prevents protein reabsorption in the PCT
  3. Overflow - excess production of low-molecular-weight proteins such as light chains
  4. Postrenal - infections or stones can lead to secretion of IgA and IgG by the urinary tract

questions.text: On performing an X-ray on a patient with the first episode of acute gout, which of the following are you most likely to see?
questions.solution:
In an acute attack of gout, only soft tissue swelling will be seen in the X-ray.

The other options, Martel’s sign/G sign/Rat-bite erosion, joint space narrowing, and secondary osteoarthritis, are all characteristic of chronic gout.

Treatment of acute attack:

  1. Colchicine
  2. NSAIDs
  3. Glucocorticoids

Treatment of chronic gout (always started under the cover of NSAIDs)

  1. Uricosuric drugs (probenecid or sulfinpyrazone)
  2. Allopurinol

Preventive measures:

  1. Low purine diet
  2. Increased fluid ingestion
  3. Decreased alcohol intake
  4. Weight loss
  5. Avoiding diuretics

questions.text:
Rituximab is approved for the treatment of which of the following conditions?
  1. Hodgkin’s lymphoma 
  2. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia 
  3. Rheumatoid arthritis 
  4. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis 
  5. Takayasu arteritis
questions.solution:
Rituximab is approved for use in the treatment of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, not in Hodgkin's lymphoma. Takayasu arteritis is also not an approved indication for rituximab usage. 

FDA-approved indications for rituximab: 

  1. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
  2. Non-Hodgkin lymphoma
  3. Microscopic polyangiitis
  4. Granulomatous polyangitis
  5. Rheumatoid arthritis
  6. Pemphigus vulgaris (moderate to severe)

Rituximab is a chimeric monoclonal antibody targeted against the CD20 receptor that is present on the surface of B lymphocytes.

Ofatumumab and obinutuzumab are the other monoclonal antibodies directed against CD20 receptors. They are also approved for use in CLL.

questions.text: You are evaluating a COPD patient and decide to use Gold's criteria to classify his airflow limitation. What is the best way to record his spirometry values for the same?

choices.text: Perform spirometry after administration of an adequate dose of at least one long-acting inhaled bronchodilator in order to minimize variability.
Perform spirometry after administration of an adequate dose of at least one short-acting inhaled bronchodilator in order to minimize variability.
Perform spirometry after administration of an adequate dose of at least one long-acting oral bronchodilator in order to minimize variability.
Perform spirometry after administration of an adequate dose of at least one short-acting oral bronchodilator in order to minimize variability.

questions.solution:
Perform spirometry after administration of an adequate dose of at least one short-acting inhaled bronchodilator in order to minimize variability.

The severity of COPD assessed by the Global Initiative for Lung Disease (GOLD) is graded as follows:

GOLD Stage

Severity

Spirometry

I

Mild

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥80% predicted

II

Moderate

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥50% but <80% predicted

III

Severe

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥30% but <50% predicted

IV

Very severe

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 <30% predicted

According to GOLD 2020 guidelines, COPD patients are classified into Group A, B, C, or D based on the severity of dyspnea and the frequency of exacerbations. Dyspnea may be assessed using the Modified MRC Dyspnea Scale or COPD Assessment Test (CAT score).

Exacerbation history MMRC 0/1 or CAT score <10 MMRC ≥2  or CAT score of ≥10
0 or 1 not leading to hospitalization A (less symptoms, less risk)
Any short or long-acting inhaled bronchodilator		 B (more symptoms, less risk)
LAMA or LABA
≥2 or ≥1 leading to hospitalization C (less symptoms, more risk)
LAMA		 D (more symptoms, more risk)
LAMA or LAMA + LABA (if highly symptomatic) or LABA + ICS (if eosinophil > 300/microL)

ICS - inhaled corticosteroids
LAMA - Long-acting muscarinic antagonists
LABA - Long-acting beta agonists

Modified MRC (mMRC) Dyspnea Scale:

  • 0- Breathless only with strenuous exercise
  • 1- Breathless when hurrying on a level or walking up a hill
  • 2- Walks slower than peers or has to stop for breath when walking on level
  • 3- Stops for breath after walking about 100 m or for a few minutes
  • 4- Breathless at rest

questions.text: Starting ART immediately would benefit newly diagnosed HIV patients with which of the following opportunistic infections?
questions.solution:
Newly diagnosed HIV patients with Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infection would benefit from immediately starting antiretroviral therapy (ART).

NACO recommends that ART should not be started in the presence of an active other infection. In general, other infections should be treated or stabilized before starting ART. However, MAC infection and progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) are exceptions in which commencing ART may be the preferred treatment

Related Pearl: Opportunistic Infections/HIV related conditions and ART initiation

Clinical scenario Action 
Any undiagnosed active infection with fever Diagnose and treat first; start Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART) when stable
Tuberculosis (TB) Start TB treatment first; start ART as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months. For those with CD4 less than 50/cmm, start ART within 2 weeks Caution is needed for PLHIV with TB meningitis, since immediate ART is associated with more severe adverse events than initiating ART 2 months after the start of TB treatment

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP)

 Treat PCP first; start ART when PCP treatment is completed
Invasive fungal diseases: Oesophageal candidiasis, penicilliosis, histoplasmosis Start treatment for oesophageal candidiasis first; start ART as soon as the patient can swallow comfortably. Treat penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis first; start ART when the patient is stabilized or opportunistic infection treatment is completed.
Cryptococcal meningitis Treat cryptococcal meningitis. ART initiation should be deferred until there is evidence of sustained clinical response to anti-fungal therapy and after 4 weeks of induction and consolidation treatment with amphotericin B containing regimen.
Bacterial pneumonia Treat pneumonia first; start ART when treatment is completed
Malaria Treat malaria first; start ART when treatment is completed
Acute diarrhoea which may reduce absorption of ART Diagnose the cause and treat diarrhoea first; start ART when diarrhoea is stabilized or controlled
Non-severe anaemia (Hb< 9 g/dl) Start ART if no other causes for anaemia are found (HIV is often the cause of anaemia) 
Skin conditions such as PPE and seborrhoeic dermatitis, psoriasis, HIV-related exfoliative dermatitis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems) 
Suspected Mycobacterium Avium Complex (MAC), Cryptosporidiosis and Microsporidiosis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems)
Cytomegalovirus retinitis Start treatment for CMV urgently and start ART after 2 weeks of CMV treatment 
Toxoplasmosis Treat toxoplasmosis; start ART after 6 weeks of treatment and when the patient is stabilized

questions.text: In twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome, an overdistended bladder and congestive cardiac failure are findings you would expect to see in:

choices.text: Recipient twin and donor twin, respectively
Donor twin and recipient twin, respectively

questions.solution:
An overdistended bladder and congestive cardiac failure are seen in the recipient twin in twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS).

Polyhydramnios (amniotic fluid index [AFI]: >25cm) and neural tube defects can be seen in any pregnancy, more so in pregnancies associated with diabetes mellitus and any form of multifetal pregnancy. Neural tube defects are also associated with folic acid deficiency. 

Selective growth restriction can also be seen in monochorionic twins, but it is a sequela to TTTS. Thus, the specific and the best answer to this question would be TTTS. 

Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome:

TTTS is a type of fetal syndrome that can arise when monozygotic twinning results in two amnionic sacs and a common surrounding chorion. This leads to anatomical sharing of the two fetal circulations through anastomoses of placental arteries and veins. It depends on the degree to which they are hemodynamically balanced. In those with significant pressure or flow gradients, a shunt will develop between fetuses. This chronic feto-fetal transfusion results in twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS).

In this syndrome, blood is transfused from a donor twin to its recipient sibling. This leads to the donor becoming anemic with restricted growth. On the contrary, the recipient may suffer from polycythemia and circulatory overload. This circulatory overload may manifest as hydrops.

Other features:

Donor twin  Recipient twin 
Oliguria Polyuria
Anemia Polycythemia
Oligohydramnios Polyhydramnios
Activation of renin-angiotensin system (RAAS) Activation of atrial natriuretic peptide
(ANP)
Decreased renal blood flow Increased renal blood flow
Non-visible bladder

Overdistended bladder
Renal failure

Congestive cardiac failure (CCF),
Circulatory overload, Hypertension  
 

Hydrops twin (late cases)
Hyperviscosity syndrome, Hyperbilirubinemia


The Quintero staging is as follows:  

  • Stage I: Amniotic fluid discordant + Urine visible in donor's bladder.
  • Stage II: Stage I + no visible urine in donor's bladder.
  • Stage III: Stage II + abnormal Doppler studies of the umbilical artery, ductus venosus, or umbilical vein.
  • Stage IV: Frank ascites or hydrops in either twin.
  • Stage V: Demise of either fetus.

Treatment:

  • Laser photoablation of the placental vascular anastomoses is the preferred treatment for severe TTTS—Quintero stages 2 to 4.
  • Septostomy is seldom done. 
  • Amnioreduction is a treatment modality that involves needle drainage of excessive amniotic fluid.
  • Selective feticide is done only if the growth disturbances develop before 20 weeks.
  • Of all, selective fetoscopic laser photocoagulation (SFLP) by Solomon technique is the preferred treatment modality as it is associated with better survival rates and a reduced likelihood of recurrence.

The donor twin is also known as pump twin / stuck twin, and the manifestation is termed as polyhydramnios -oligohydramnios syndrome or poly-oli syndrome. So, the incidences of isolated oligohydramnios or polyhydramnios in twins are rare. 

Related Pearl: Twinning

questions.text: Nystagmus to the side of the lesion occurs in
questions.solution:
Serous labyrinthitis results in nystagmus to the side of the lesion.

Vestibular nystagmus has a slow and fast component. By convention, the latter denotes the direction of nystagmus. Paretic lesions such as purulent labyrinthitis, trauma to the labyrinth, and sectioning of the 8th nerve cause nystagmus to the healthy side. Serous labyrinthitis, which is an irritative lesion, leads to nystagmus on the same side of the lesion.

Nystagmus is a rhythmical, involuntary, and oscillatory movement of the eyes. It can be horizontal, vertical, or rotatory. It can be of two types:

  • Vestibular (peripheral) nystagmus due to a lesion of the labyrinth or eighth cranial nerve.
  • Central nystagmus is due to a lesion in the vestibular nuclei, brainstem, or cerebellum.

The following features can be used to differentiate between peripheral and central nystagmus. 

Nystagmus Peripheral lesion Central lesion
Latency 2-20 seconds No latency
Duration Less than one minute More than one minute
Direction Fixed Changes
Fatiguability Fatiguable Nonfatiguable
Associated symptoms Severe vertigo None or slight

questions.text: The phase of skin graft uptake in which the cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses is known as:
questions.solution:
The phase of skin graft uptake in which the cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses is known as inosculation. It is the period during which the graft is most at risk for failure. 

Split skin graft survives the transplantation surgery by the following process:

  • The graft survives the first 48 hours because of the imbibition of plasma from the wound bed.
  • After 48 hours, fine anastomotic connections are made, which leads to the inosculation of blood.
  • Neovascularization is the process by which new blood vessels formed will directly invade the graft and restore the pink color of the skin.

Related Pearl: Skin Grafting : Phases of Graft Uptake

Skin graft uptake occurs in three phases:

  1. Imbibition (Plasmatic circulation): During the first 48 hours, the graft is nourished with plasma exudate from the host bed capillaries.
  2. Inosculation: Cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses.
  3. Neovascularization: Blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into the graft.

Sensations return to the graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 to 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months. Pain returns first, followed by light touch and temperature returning later.

Note: Some books give that the 3 phases are imbibition, revascularisation (inosculation+neovascularisation) and organisation (fibrin layer holds the graft in place and this is replaced with fibroblasts by day 7).

questions.text: Which of the following is used as a fixative as well as a stain to demonstrate fat in the tissue, including frozen sections?
questions.solution:
Osmic acid/ Osmium tetroxide can be used as a fixative as well as a stain to demonstrate fat in the tissue including those of frozen sections.

Osmium tetroxide is used to stain lipids in electron microscopy. It dissolves in fats and is reduced by organic materials to elemental osmium, an easily visible black substance. Osmium is a heavy metal and electron-dense. It will appear opaque and can be visualized in electron microscopy. Apart from this, it is well suited to reveal the details of myelin in nerves as it binds to lipids strongly.

 

Oil red O stains lipid/ fats and gives a characteristic orange/red appearance. It is used in the unfixed frozen sections as the fixation of fats with other routine processes may lose the lipid content. 10% Neutral buffer formaldehyde (NBF) is the preferred fixative in histopathological sections staining with Oil red O. Zenker's fixative and Helly's fixative are best avoided during staining with ORO.

Oil red O stains the lipid in the vacuoles in the pulmonary vasculature. It can be useful in identifying fat emboli in lung tissue, diagnosing renal cell carcinoma, and sebaceous gland tumors of the skin.

The image below shows microscopy of an oil red O-stained bronchoalveolar lavage sample from a patient with acute lung injury.

The image shows the lipid vesicles in the adipocytes stained using oil-red-O staining.

 Other stains used for lipids or fats:

  • Nile blue sulfate. The preferred fixative is formal calcium.
  • Sudan black B is used in the frozen section. The preferred fixative is 10% NBF. Sudan Black B stains the lipids blue-black.
  • Sudan IV imparts a orange-red colour to the contained lipids.

Related Pearl: Special stains used for staining Lipid

  • Oil Red O
  • Sudan Black or Sudan IV
  • Osmium tetroxide.

The image shows Oil Red O staining of lipid.

questions.text: Superior laryngeal nerve injury would result in

choices.text: Loss of sensation of mucosa below vocal fold

questions.solution:
In SLN injury, the cricothyroid muscle is paralyzed.

Cricothyroid is used only in high-pitch vocalization, normal speech will not be affected. SLN also provides sensory supply to the mucosa above(not below) vocal cords, hence its lesion would lead to increased susceptibility to aspiration.

If a patient presents with aspiration, it rules out the glossopharyngeal nerve as an option since it doesn't provide either sensory or motor supply to the larynx and therefore its lesion wouldn't cause aspiration.

If a patient has normal vocalization it rules out RLN and high vagal injury. RLN supplies all the intrinsic muscles of the larynx except cricothyroid, therefore an RLN lesion would lead to disordered vocalization. 

Related Pearl: Nerves of Larynx

questions.text: What is the nature of the data seen in the graphical plot below?
questions.solution:
In the image, the tail of the distribution is towards the positive direction and thus it is positively skewed or right-skewed distribution.

To further understand and correlate the data representation with that of a corresponding box and whisker plot, have a look at the following images:

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

Related Pearl: Box and Whisker Plot

  • A box and whisker plot is used to show variation in a set of data.
  • They can summarize data from various sources and display it in a single graph.
  • A box and whisker plot is usually based on median, quartiles and percentiles.
  • It is also called a box plot.
  • In the box plot as shown in the image, a simple box is divided into two by the median value. Above and below it are the whiskers. The top and bottom ends of the whiskers are the highest and lowest value of that group. 
  • A box plot can help in identifying outliers and the interquartile range (IQR), as shown in the image below.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is the rate-limiting enzyme in the synthesis of fatty acids?
questions.solution:
Acetyl-CoA carboxylase is the rate-limiting enzyme. But acetyl-CoA carboxylase is not a part of the multienzyme complex.

The six enzymes in the fatty acid synthase complex are as follows:

  • Ketoacyl synthase
  • Malonyl/acetyl transacylase
  • Dehydratase
  • Enoyl reductase
  • Ketoacyl reductase
  • ACP
  • Thioesterase.

Fatty acid synthesis occurs in the cytosol. It involves the formation of palmitate from acetyl-CoA. This process occurs in the liver, kidney, brain, lung, breast, and adipose tissue. Acetyl-CoA and CO2 act as the substrate and palmitate is the end product.

Acetyl-CoA is carboxylated to form malonyl-CoA by ATP and acetyl-CoA carboxylase as the initial step. This enzyme requires biotin and is the regulatory enzyme in fatty acid synthesis. 

Malonyl-CoA is acted upon by the fatty acid synthase complex (FAS). FAS consists of six enzymes with an acyl carrier protein arranged in a homodimer in an "X-shape". Acyl carrier protein (ACP) contains pantothenic acid.

Thioesterase is the last enzyme in the fatty acid synthase complex. It catalyzes the final release of the newly formed fatty acid. 

Note- Thiokinase catalyzes the only energy-requiring step in fatty acid oxidation. In the presence of ATP and coenzyme A, thiokinase catalyzes the conversion of a fatty acid to acyl-CoA. Acyl-CoA is the active form of fatty acid. This step uses one high-energy phosphate and forms AMP and PPi.

Related Pearl: Types, Location and Properties of Fatty acid oxidation

Types of Oxidation

Location

Properties

Associated Disease

Beta oxidation

Mitochondria

A catabolic process by which two-carbons are cleaved from the fatty acid molecule and released as acetyl CoA starting from the carboxyl end.

The chain is broken between the α(2) and β(3) carbon.

1 round of beta-oxidation yield 1FADH2, 1NADH, and 1 Acetyl CoA.

  

Alpha oxidation

Peroxisome

The presence of the 3-methyl group of phytanic acid prevents degradation by beta-oxidation.

The chain is broken between the terminal carboxyl group and α(2) carbon removing that carbon as CO2. The remaining chain is activated with CoA and then undergoes β-Oxidation.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Classic Refsum's Disease

Defective enzyme- Phytanoyl Coa hydroxylase.

Clinical features include:

Ichthyosis, Retinitis pigmentosa, Decreased vision, Peripheral neuropathy, Ataxia

 

Omega oxidation

Endoplasmic Reticulum

An alternative pathway to beta-oxidation occurs in microsomes.

Involves the oxidation of the ω carbon (terminal methyl group) resulting in dicarboxylic acid.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

  

Peroxisomal Beta oxidation

Peroxisome

Very-long-chain fatty acids undergo preliminary β-oxidation in peroxisomes up to octanoyl CoA. The shortened fatty acids undergo further β-oxidation in the mitochondria.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Zellweger (cerebrohepatorenal) syndrome

A rare inherited absence of peroxisomes in all tissues.

They accumulate C26—C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissue and also exhibit a generalized loss of peroxisomal functions. The disease causes severe neurologic symptoms, and most patients die in the first year of life.

questions.text: Which of the following tests of significance and data group for which it is used, is incorrectly paired?

choices.text: ANOVA - test difference between 3 different groups
Student's t test - test difference between 2 independent groups
Chi square test - test difference between two quantitative variables
Paired t test - test before and after data

questions.solution:
Chi-square test is a nonparametric test that assesses the significance of association between two qualitative variables.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is started on hydrochlorothiazide for the treatment of hypertension. Which of the following complications is he least likely to develop?
questions.solution:
Thiazide diuretics are associated with hypercalcemia, not hypocalcemia.
 
Adverse effects of thiazide diuretics like hydrochlorothiazide:
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hyponatremia
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Rashes
  • Headache
  • Gastrointestinal upset
  • Dizziness
  • Erectile dysfunction

Related Pearl: Effect of diuretics on excretion of electrolytes

Osmotic diuretics ↑↑ ↑ ↑

Thiazides ↑ ↑↑ ↓

Aldosterone antagonists ↑ ↓ Insufficient data

Acute effects of thiazides on Ca2+ excretion are variable but when administered chronically, it decreases Ca2+ excretion.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding ethambutol?

choices.text: Does not require dose modification in patients with renal failure
Ethambutol decreases arabinogalactan biosynthesis by inhibiting arabinosyltransferase III
Loss of red-green discrimination may occur as a side effect
Optic nerve recovers when ethambutol intake is stopped

questions.solution:
The major route of excretion of Ethambutol is via the renal route. Hence it requires dose reduction in renal disease. 

Ethambutol can cause retrobulbar neuritis and red-green color blindness. Optic neuritis resulting in decreased visual acuity and loss of ability to differentiate red from green is the most serious adverse effect of ethambutol. It is a dose-dependent adverse effect that can be unilateral or bilateral. The intensity of the visual difficulty is related to the duration of therapy. Tests of visual acuity and red-green discrimination before the start of therapy and periodically thereafter are recommended. Recovery usually occurs on stopping ethambutol.

Ethambutol is used for the treatment of TB, disseminated MAC, and in M. kansasii infection. It inhibits arabinosyltransferase III, thereby disrupting the transfer of arabinose into arabinogalactan biosynthesis which in turn disrupts the assembly of the mycobacterial cell wall. Resistance occurs due to mutations in the embB gene.

Since 80% of the drug is eliminated through the kidney unchanged, its dosing should be decreased in renal failure to avoid toxicity. Therefore, in renal failure, ethambutol should be given 15-25 mg/kg three times a week, instead of daily.

Other side effects are pruritus, joint pain, GI upset, abdominal pain, malaise, headache, dizziness, mental confusion, disorientation, possible hallucinations, and decreased renal excretion of uric acid.

Related Pearl: Key points on the first line drugs used in the treatment of TB

Drugs Isoniazid Rifamycins Pyrazinamide Ethambutol
Mechanism of action

Bactericidal

Blocks mycolic acid synthesis.

Bactericidal (maximum)

Inhibition of RNA polymerase, leading to the inhibition of RNA synthesis.

Bactericidal

Inhibition of fatty acid synthase-I, leading to the inhibition of the cell membrane.

Bacteriostatic

Inhibition of arabinosyl transferase, leading to a reduction in arabinogalactan needed for the cell wall.
Location of Mycobacteria Intracellular +  Extracellular Intracellular +  Extracellular  Intracellular  Extracellular
Metabolism Liver  Liver (maximum)  Liver  Kidney
Unique side effects

Shoulder hand syndrome and CNS side effects.

 Orange urine, sweat, and tears. Flu-like symptoms with intermittent dosing.

The most hepatotoxic drug. It also causes hyperuricemia.

Optic neuritis and hence, not preferred in children.
Mechanism of resistance

Kat G mutation- the most severe form of resistance.

Inh a gene overexpression-  confers cross-resistance with ethionamide.

Mutation in rpoB- the gene coding for the β subunit of RNA polymerase.

 Mutation of the Pnca gene.

Mutations in the embB gene.

questions.text: A dental examination of a body reveals that all molar cusps are so worn that the crown is a flat plane. The likely age of the patient is:
questions.solution:
The molar crowns of the teeth are usually worn flat to a single plane by the age of 50 to 60 years. If all molar cusps are so worn that the crown is a flat plane, the age is likely to be above 50 years. 

Lambdoid suture starts closing endocranially at 25-35 years and completes fusion by 45-50 years. Endocranial fusion occurs before ectocranial fusion.

Between 30-35 years, lipping starts on the ventral margin of the glenoid cavity of the scapulae. By 35-40 years there is irregular lipping around the clavicular facet and inferior surface of the acromion process. Around 45 years there is localized bony atrophy and at 50 years, cristae scapulae occur (Ridge/crest on scapula).

Completely edentulous upper and lower jaws usually indicate an age of over 70 years.

The sagittal suture is used for age determination, even though age estimation by skull sutures is not considered to be very reliable. The last skull suture to fuse is the squamous temporal suture, which fuses after 80 years of age.

questions.text:
The milk ring test is found to be positive for a sample of milk. The organism responsible is best cultured using ________.

BCYE: Buffered Charcoal Yeast Extract
questions.solution:
Milk ring test (MRT) is positive for Brucella. It is best cultured in Castaneda medium.

The MRT is used for the detection of infected animals in dairy farms. A sample of whole milk is mixed with a drop of Brucella antigen and incubated at 70 °C for 40–50 min.

If antibodies are present in the milk, the bacilli are agglutinated and rise with the cream to form a blue ring at the top, leaving the rest of the milk unstained (MRT positive). If antibodies are absent, the solution remains uniformly blue (MRT negative).

questions.text: Which of the following Alpha subunit of GPCR and its downstream action is incorrectly paired?
questions.solution:
Go causes Ca2+ channel inhibition.

G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) are cell membrane receptors that span across the membrane 7 times. They also serve as receptors for various peptide hormones, neurotransmitters, amino acids, etc.

Subtypes of GPCRs are distinguished by their alpha subunits. The important subtypes of GPCRs are Gs, Gp, Gq, and Go.

GPCRs act via various second messengers. The important ones with their action on the effector are:

  • Gs causes activation of adenylyl cyclase and results in Ca2+ channel opening.
  • Gi causes inhibition of adenylyl cyclase and results in K+ channel opening.
  • Go causes Ca2+ channel inhibition.
  • Gq causes activation of phospholipase C, which generates the second messengers inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG). The water-soluble IP3 diffuses to the cytosol and mobilizes Ca2+ from endoplasmic reticulum depots.

The given below image shows the effects of phospholipase C after activation by Gq

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Liddle syndrome is false?

choices.text: It is inherited in a autosomal dominant manner.
Spironolactone can be used for management.
It is caused by a gain of function mutation of ENaC gene.
Hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypertension is seen.

questions.solution:
Spironolactone is not effective in the management of Liddle syndrome as it is an aldosterone-receptor antagonist.

It is an autosomal dominant condition caused by a gain of function mutation in the ENaC gene. This gene codes for the epithelial sodium channels present in the kidney. The mutation leads to increased sodium retention and results in a state of pseudo-hyperaldosteronism. The following findings are seen in Liddle syndrome:

  • Hypertension
  • Hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis
  • Normal-low aldosterone
  • Low renin 

Treatment is with diuretics that directly block the ENaC channels, like amiloride and triamterene. Spironolactone is not effective as it is an aldosterone-receptor antagonist.

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.text: All of the following are techniques that you can use for delivery of the head in breech presentation, except for ___.
questions.solution:
Ritgen maneuver can be used to assist with the delivery of the head in normal labor, not in breech presentation.

When the head distends the vulva and perineum enough to open the vaginal introitus to a diameter of >5 cm, a gloved hand may be used for supporting the perineum in order to avoid expulsive delivery and to avoid perineal lacerations.

If the expulsive efforts are inadequate, the Ritgen maneuver is employed for assisted delivery of the head. This is accomplished by pushing the chin upward with the fingers of the right hand (positioned over the anococcygeal region) while the left hand exerts pressure on the occiput. Hence, the head is delivered by extension. 

The image below demonstrates the Ritgen maneuver:

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: Which of the following cannot be sterilized using a hot air oven?
questions.solution:
Inoculation loop must be sterilized by heating it over a flame until it is red hot, not using a hot air oven.

 

Hot air oven:

It is a method of sterilization by dry heat.

  • Holding period of 160°C for 2 hours is used to sterilize glassware, sharp instruments, liquid paraffin, dusting powder, etc.
  • Cutting instruments in ophthalmic surgery: 2 hours at 150°C.
  • Spores of Clostridium tetani act as a control.

questions.text: All of the following structures pass through the lesser sciatic foramen, except?
questions.solution:
Nerve to quadratus femoris passes through the greater sciatic foramen.

The tendon of obturator internus passes through the lesser sciatic foramen.

Structures passing through both the greater and lesser sciatic foramen:

  • Pudendal nerve
  • Internal pudendal vessels
  • Nerve to obturator internus

Related Pearl: Structures Passing Through the Sciatic Foramens

Structures passing through the greater sciatic foramen

The piriformis is the key muscle of this region. It emerges from the pelvis, and fills the foramen almost completely.

Structures passing above the piriformis

  • Superior gluteal nerve
  • Superior gluteal vessels

Structures passing below the piriformis

  • Inferior gluteal nerve         
  • Inferior gluteal vessels
  • Sciatic nerve                                              
  • Posterior cutaneous nerve of thigh
  • Nerve to quadratus femoris                  
  • Pudendal nerve
  • Internal pudendal vessels                                  
  • Nerve to obturator internus

Note: The last three structures, after a short course in the gluteal region, enter the lesser sciatic foramen, where the pudendal nerve and internal pudendal vessels run in the pudendal canal.

Structures passing through the lesser sciatic foramen

  • Tendon of obturator internus
  • Pudendal nerve
  • Internal pudendal vessels
  • Nerve to obturator internus

questions.text: All of the following are branches of the structure marked in the image, except _______.
questions.solution:
The marked structure can be identified as the superior mesenteric artery, as it lies anterior and superior to the left renal vein. The left colic artery is a branch of the inferior mesenteric artery, not the superior mesenteric artery.

The superior mesenteric artery originates from the abdominal aorta at the level of the L1 vertebra.

Branches of the superior mesentric artery:

  • Jejunal branches
  • Ileal branches
  • Middle colic artery
  • Right colic artery
  • Ileocolic artery
  • Inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery

Clinical note: Nutcracker syndrome

  • It occurs due to left renal vein entrapment, i.e., the compression of the left renal vein between the abdominal aorta and the superior mesenteric artery,
  • The compression occurs in the sagittal plane, appearing as if a nutcracker is crushing a nut (the left renal vein).

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding the usage of yellow kits used for the management of STI, as per NACO?
  1. A single dose of Tab. Cefixime 400 mg should be given stat 
  2. Tab. Metronidazole 500 mg should be given as TDS for 14 days 
  3. A single dose of Tab. Doxycycline 100 mg should be given stat
  4. Should be prescribed to females with lower abdominal pain syndrome
  5. Male partners of patients receiving yellow kit should be treated with kit 1/grey kit
questions.solution:
The correct statements are:

  • A single dose of Tab. Cefixime 400 mg should be given stat 
  • Tab. Metronidazole 400 mg should be given as BD for 14 days 
  • Tab. Doxycycline 100 mg should be given as BD for 14 days 
  • Used in females for lower abdominal pain syndrome
  • Male partners of patients receiving yellow kit should be treated with kit 1/grey kit

Yellow kit/Kit 6:

Patients who have been prescribed the yellow kit predominantly present with lower abdominal pain. Other symptoms seen are

  • Fever
  • Vaginal Discharge
  • Menstrual irregularities like heavy or irregular vaginal bleeding
  • Dysmenorrhoea, dyspareunia, dysuria and tenesmus
  • Lower backache
  • Cervical motion tenderness

Contents and course: 

  • Tab. Cefixime 400 mg OD stat + Tab. Metronidazole 400 mg BD X 14 days + Doxycycline 100 mg BD X 14 days
  • Male partner(s) is additionally treated with the Grey kit/Kit 1
  • The patient is asked to follow up on the 3rd, 7th, and 14th days.

 

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text:
Match the following characteristic clinical appearances with the corresponding syndromes.
  1. Eagle-Barrett Syndrome
  2. Potter syndrome
  3. Treacher-Collins syndrome
  4. Down's syndrome
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-D, 2-A, 3-B, 4-C.

Down syndrome occurs due to trisomy of chromosome 21 leading to multisystem manifestations. There is a wide range of presentations. A few key features include characteristic facies such as flat face, epicanthal folds, small head, flat nasal bridge, upward slanting palpebral fissures, brushfield spots, small nose, protruding tongue, and small and lowset ears. Congenital heart defects can also be present. This patient has a normal karyotype.

The following image shows a child with Down syndrome:

Prune Belly Syndrome is also known as - Eagle-Barrett Syndrome, Triad Syndrome, Obrinsky Syndrome, and Frohlich Syndrome.

Prune Belly Triad -

  • Cryptorchidism
  • Abdominal Wall Defects
  • Genitourinary Defects

Features of Prune Belly Syndrome:

  • Flabby, Hypotonic & Thin Abdominal Wall - Due to deficient abdominal wall muscles
  • Urethral Obstruction in fetal life.
  • Predominantly seen in males

Associated defects:

  • Posterior urethral valve
  • Vesicoureteric Reflux
  • Limb Anomalies and scoliosis

Treatment :

  • Ureteric dilatation - not until an obstruction occurs
  • Bilateral orchidopexy - for cryptorchidism.
  • Abdominal wall reconstruction - performed in conjugation with orchidopexy at 6-12 months of age through abdominoplasty.

Potter Syndrome:

  • Bilateral Renal Agenesis leads to oligohydramnios, in turn causing pulmonary hypoplasia.
  • Resultant characteristic Potter Facies -
    • Widely separated eyes with epicanthic fold
    • Small, low-set ears
    • Flat & broad nose
    • Receding Chin
  • Limb Anomalies
  • Wrinkled Skin

Interestingly, the cause of death is pulmonary insufficiency from pulmonary hypoplasia, not renal failure.

 

 
 

Treacher Collins syndrome/ Mandibulofacial dysostosis refers to a condition resulting from the hypoplasia of the zygoma and mandible.

Ocular features:

  • Indistinct inferior orbital margin
  • Coloboma of the lower eyelid
  • Anti-mongoloid slant of palpebral fissures

Systemic features

  • Macrostomia with a high-arched palate
  • External ear deformity
  • Bird-like face

The image below shows features of Treacher Collins syndrome.

questions.text:
Which of the following patients would you classify as ASA-PS II?

American Society of Anesthesiologists - ASA

choices.text: A 38-year-old well-controlled hypertensive with a history of MI 4 months prior
A 22-year-old non-smoker with a history of minimal alcohol consumption and no comorbidities
A 62-year-old smoker with an HbA1c of 5.8 and BP of 122/82 mmHg
A 48-year-old non smoker with HbA1c of 7.8 and BP of 116/80 mmHg

questions.solution:
A 62-year-old smoker with an HbA1c of 5.8 and BP of 122/82 mmHg should be classified as ASA-PS II.

The American Society of Anesthesiologists classification (ASA-PS) is used to classify physical status. An integral part of the pre-anesthetic evaluation is assessing a patient's risk for undergoing anesthesia and surgery. This helps the anesthetist make informed clinical decisions and helps the patient understand their risks. 

After classifying patients based on this risk assessment, those who require more intensive postoperative monitoring can be identified. In addition, patients who are at high risk for complications can be identified and alternative interventions considered. 

The ASA-PS is the most commonly used risk assessment. However, it is important to note that it describes only the patient's preoperative status and not the risks associated with the specific procedure that the patient will undergo. 

Other options:

 

  • A 48-year-old non-smoker with HbA1c of 7.8 and BP of 116/80 mmHg - ASA-PS-III as poorly controlled DM
  • A 22-year-old non-smoker with a history of minimal alcohol consumption and no comorbidities - ASA-PS-I
  • A 38-year-old well-controlled hypertensive with a history of MI 4 months prior - ASA-PS-III

Related Pearl: American Society of Anesthesiologists’ Physical Status Classification of Patients

American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status (ASA-PS) classification is used to define relative risk before conscious sedation and surgical anaesthesia and strongly correlates to perioperative risk.

ASA-PS Classification:

Class Definition Examples, including, but not limited to:
I A normal healthy patient Healthy, non-smoking, no or minimal alcohol use
II A patient with mild systemic disease Current smoker, well-controlled DM and HTN
III A patient with severe systemic disease Poorly controlled DM or HTN, history (>3 months) of MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD or stents.
IV A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life Recent (< 3 months) MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD/stents
V A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation Ruptured abdominal, thoracic aneurysm, massive trauma, intracranial bleed with mass effect
VI A declared brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes  

Related Pearl: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

  1. Obstructive sleep apnea
  2. History of snoring
  3. Obesity
  4. Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery
  5. Previous head and neck radiation
  6. Head and neck trauma
  7. Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck
  8. Rheumatoid arthritis
  9. Down syndrome
  10. Scleroderma
  11. Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

  1. Mallampati scores (III and IV)
  2. Thyromental distance less than 6 cm
  3. Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  4. Increased neck circumference >17 inches in men or >16 inches in women
  5. Upper lip bite test: Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth
  6. Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates ease with intubation.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

• Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
• Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
• Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
• Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

questions.text: Pyknosis refers to ________.
questions.solution:
Pyknosis refers to nuclear shrinkage and increased basophilia, which occurs during the process of cellular necrosis.

The sequence of events in necrosis is as follows: cellular swelling → pyknosis → karyorrhexis → karyolysis. 

Necrosis is defined as the spectrum of morphological changes that follow cell death due to the progressive degradative action of enzymes.

Morphological changes that occur in necrosis are as follows:

Cytoplasmic changes:

  • Increased eosinophilic staining on H&E specimens
  • Moth-eaten appearance of the cytoplasm - due to vacuolated cytoplasmic organelles formed by enzymatic degradation
  • Glassy and homogenous cytoplasm - due to loss of glycogen in the cytoplasm

Nuclear changes:

  • Pyknosis - nucleus first shrinks and becomes more condensed
  • Karyorrhexis - fragmentation of the pyknotic nucleus
  • Karyolysis - nucleus fades away, leaving behind only the cell membrane or empty cells

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman was admitted to the ICU with suspected severe systemic mycoses. The appearance of the causative organism, as seen on culture from the lesion at 37°C, is shown in the image below. What is the preferred drug for the management of her condition?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the characteristic 'pilot wheel appearance' on culture shown by Paracoccidioides brasiliensis. It causes South American blastomycosis/ paracoccidioidomycosis. Amphotericin B is recommended for the management of severe systemic disease.

Amphotericin B is recommended for moderate to severe disease, central nervous system disease, immunosuppressed patients, or pregnant patients. Itraconazole is recommended for mild-to-moderate disease and step-down therapy.

P. brasiliensis is a thermally dimorphic fungus. It causes paracoccidioidomycosis, a chronic granulomatous disease affecting the lungs, skin, mucosa, and lymph nodes. The characteristic feature is the presence of ulcerative granulomas in the buccal and nasal mucosa.

On culture at 37°C, large oval cells with multiple buds encircling the mother cell are seen. This is known as the Mariner’s or pilot wheel appearance. On culture at 25–30°C, it is found in mycelial phase.

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text: Sequentially arrange the structures of the renal hilum from anterior to posterior.

choices.text: Renal artery, renal vein, renal pelvis
Renal vein, renal artery, renal pelvis
Renal pelvis, renal artery, renal vein
Renal vein, renal pelvis, renal artery

questions.solution:
Hilum of the kidney contains the following structures from anterior to posterior:

  • Renal vein
  • Renal artery
  • Renal pelvis

questions.text: What is the method of sterilization used for Loeffler's serum?
questions.solution:
Loeffler's serum is sterilized by inspissation.

Inspissation involves the application of a temperature of 80-85° C for half an hour for three consecutive days in an inspissator. This method is used for the sterilization of media containing eggs or serum. Another medium for which this method is used is the Lowenstein-Jensen medium as it contains egg. 

Other Options:

Autoclaving: Heat at 121°C for 15 minutes at a pressure of 15 psi (most commonly used).

Tyndallization: This method is used for media containing sugars or gelatin. It involves steaming at 100°C for 20 minutes for 3 successive days. This method may not kill the spores of certain anaerobes and thermophiles. 

Plasma sterilization is a new method of sterilising heat-sensitive articles. Radiofrequency energy is applied to create an electromagnetic field. Into this, hydrogen peroxide vapours are introduced, which generates a plasma state containing free radicals of hydrogen and oxygen. This state renders the articles sterile by denaturing all microorganisms. Arthroscopes, urethroscopes, etc., are sterilised by plasma sterilisation.

Related Pearl: Methods of sterilisation

Method of disinfection or sterilisation Material
Red Heat Inoculating wire loop, tip of forceps
Incineration Contaminated clothes, animal carcasses, plastics like polythene
Hot air oven Glasswares, scalpels, forceps, cutting instruments, test tubes
Inspissator Heat labile culture media containing egg, sugar or serum
Autoclave Culture media, dressings, gloves, aprons, all instruments except sharps, suture materials except catgut
Isopropyl alcohol Clinical thermometers, stethoscopes, probes
Methyl alcohol Fungal spores

Beta propiolactone/

formaldehyde

 Fumigation of operating theatres, wards and labs
2% gluteraldehyde Cystoscopes, bronchoscopes, fibre-optic endoscopes, plastic ETT, face masks
Plasma sterilisation Arthroscopes, urethroscopes
Ethylene oxide Heart lung machines, respirators, dental equipments, sutures, books, clothings
Filtration (Seitz filters) Bacterial vaccines, intravenous solutions
5% cresol, hot air oven Sharp instruments

Ionising radiation

(Cold air sterilization)

Chlorhexidine Disinfecting surgeon’s hands prior to surgery
Iodophor Disinfecting surgical site prior to surgery
70% ethanol Disinfectant skin prior to venepuncture or immunisation
Thiomersal Preservative in vaccine
Silver sulfadiazine Cleanse burn wounds
Hypochlorite Cleanup of blood spill from a patient with hepatitis B or C
Hydrogen peroxide Cleanse wounds

questions.text: During the assessment of a fetus, a vibroacoustic stimulation test is performed. 10 seconds following the vibroacoustic stimulation, the fetal heart rate accelerates by 25 bpm for 20 seconds and prolonged fetal movements are noted. This should be considered as indicative of ______.
questions.solution:
Fetal heart rate acceleration of at least 15 bpm for at least 15 seconds, occurring within 15 seconds of vibroacoustic stimulation, along with prolonged fetal movements, is considered a normal response.

Monitoring of the fetal heart rate acceleration in response to vibroacoustic stimulation has been recommended as a substitute for fetal scalp blood sampling. An electronic artificial larynx placed approximately 1 cm from or directly onto the maternal abdomen is used for the stimulation of the fetus, following which the fetal heart rate response is studied.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure.
questions.solution:
The marked vessel is the basilar artery. 

Branches of the basilar artery:

  1. Numerous pontine branches
  2. Labyrinthine artery
  3. Anterior inferior cerebellar artery
  4. Superior cerebellar artery
  5. Posterior cerebral artery

Note: Labyrynthine artery is usually a branch of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery, but variations in its origin include basilar artery, superior cerebellar artery and occasionally posterior inferior cerebellar artery.

questions.text: A child is brought to your clinic with complaints of diarrhea and abdominal pain. The stool microscopy image is given below. Eggs were non-bile stained and floated in the saturated salt solution. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history, along with the given image, indicate that the most likely causative organism would be Hymenolepis nana. Praziquantel given as a single dose of 25 mg/kg is the drug of choice.

Praziquantel stimulates Ca2+ influx and causes spastic paralysis of the organism. Niclosamide and nitazoxanide are other drugs that can be used.

H. nana (dwarf tapeworm) is the smallest tapeworm, and man is its definite host. It occurs more commonly in children, and the patient acquires this infection by ingesting food or water contaminated with its eggs. The adult worm resides in the small intestine. Patients are usually asymptomatic, but in heavy infections, they present with nausea, anorexia, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and irritability. Pruritus may also be present due to an allergic response. The eggs are non-bile stained and float in the saturated salt solution. They have a thin colorless outer membrane and thread-like polar filaments on stool microscopy.

 

The image given below shows the egg of Hymenolepis nana.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

Related Pearl: Parasites with bile-stained eggs

The following are the parasites with bile-stained eggs. (mnemonic: FaT CAT)

  • Fasciola hepatica (sheep liver fluke)
  • Fasciolopsis buski (giant intestinal fluke)
  • Trichuris trichiura (whipworm)
  • Clonorchis sinensis (chinese liver fluke, oriental liver fluke)
  • Ascaris lumbricoides (round worm)
  • Taenia solium (pork tapeworm)
  • Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm)

Related Pearl: Helminth eggs that float in saturated salt solution

The following are the helminths whose eggs float in a saturated salt solution. (mnemonic: THE FAN)

  • Trichuris trichiura
  • Hymenolepis nana
  • Enterobius vermicularis
  • Fertilized eggs of Ascaris lumbricoides
  • Ancylostoma duodenale
  • Necator americanus.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female singer presents to you with weakness of voice after having multiple recordings in the studio. On laryngoscopy, you notice a characteristic triangular gap near the posterior commissure. This appearance of the glottis is due to the weakness of which of the following muscles?
questions.solution:
The weakness of the interarytenoid has the characteristic triangular gap near the posterior commissure.

Phonasthenia is the weakness of voice due to fatigue of laryngeal muscles. It is seen in abuse or misuse of voice or may follow laryngitis.

The weakness of muscles leads to a phonatory gap. The shape of the gap depends on the muscles involved:

  • Thyroarytenoid alone: elliptical space
  • Interarytenoid alone: triangular space
  • Both thyroarytenoid & inter arytenoid: Keyhole appearance.

Treatment is voice rest and vocal hygiene. Period of voice rest after excessive use of voice is also imperative.

questions.text: A patient with cirrhosis and ascites presents to you. The gross appearance of his liver is as shown below. Which of the following is true regarding the likely characteristic microscopic appearance?

choices.text: Pericentral hepatocytes will be atrophic/necrotic, and periportal hepatocytes will be viable.
Periportal hepatocytes will be atrophic/necrotic, and pericentral hepatocytes will be viable.
Both periportal and pericentral hepatocytes are equally necrotic/atrophic.
Neither periportal, nor pericentral hepatocytes are affected.

questions.solution:
The gross image of the liver shows a nutmeg appearance, which is seen in heart failure. Microscopic findings would be that pericentral hepatocytes are atrophic/necrotic and periportal hepatocytes are viable.

Nutmeg liver refers to the mottled appearance of the liver, resembling the cut section of nutmeg. This appearance occurs as a result of hepatic venous congestion following right heart failure. The dark centrilobular zones reflect sinusoidal congestion. Congestion is seen around the central veins, usually from right-sided heart failure. The pale periportal zones reflect normal or fatty liver tissue.

The liver derives its blood supply from the portal venous system and the hepatic artery. The portal triad constitutes the following:

  • Branches of the hepatic artery
  • Portal vein 
  • Bile duct

The blood from the portal vein and the hepatic artery flow through the intervening sinusoids and drains into the central vein. The central veins from adjacent lobules form interlobular veins, which then unite as hepatic veins and finally drain into the inferior vena cava. 

The hepatic lobule is divided into three zones:

  • Zone 1 is the periportal area 
  • Zone 2 is the intermediate zone
  • Zone 3 is the area closest to the central vein

Right-sided cardiac failure leads to passive congestion of the liver. Left-sided cardiac failure leads to hypoperfusion and hypoxia of hepatocytes around central veins. The combination of hypoperfusion and retrograde congestion causes centrilobular hemorrhagic necrosis, leading to this mottled appearance of the liver, which is known as nutmeg liver.

questions.text: All of the following ocular findings are associated with Dorsal-Midbrain (Parinaud's) syndrome, except

choices.text: Paresis of downward gaze with preserved upward gaze

questions.solution:
Parinaud's syndrome refers to supranuclear vertical gaze disorder. Here there is a loss of up-gaze and the downward gaze is usually preserved.

Parinaud's syndrome/dorsal midbrain syndrome is caused by damage to the posterior commissure. Classically, signs of hydrocephalus are seen due to aqueductal stenosis.

Causes:

  • Pineal region or midbrain tumors (most common cause)
  • Neurocysticercosis
  • Stroke
  • Multiple sclerosis

Features include the following:

  • Loss of up-gaze (downward gaze is usually preserved)
  • Convergence–retraction nystagmus on attempted upgaze
  • Downward ocular deviation- Setting-sun sign
  • Lid retraction- Collier's sign
  • Pseudo-Argyll–Robertson pupil- Accommodative paresis ensues and pupils become mid-dilated and show light-near dissociation
  • Bilateral papilledema
  • Skew deviation
  • Pseudoabducens palsy

questions.text: The ability to detect a false null hypothesis will decrease if

choices.text: Alpha increases / Chance of type I error increases
the size of the difference between the sample mean and the hypothesized population mean increases

questions.solution:
The ability of a test to avoid false negative error (type II or β error) is called the Power of the Test (“the ability of a test to reject a null hypothesis when it is false”). The test's power decreases if the sample size decreases.

It is expressed as 1 - β.

Thus,

A test’s power will increase if

  • β error decreases
  • The width of the Confidence interval (i.e., the margin of error) decreases
  • Sampling error decreases
  • Sample size increases

Related Pearl: Concepts in Hypothesis Testing

Probability value (p value)

  • A probability value is the probability of an outcome given the hypothesis.
  • It is not the probability of the hypothesis given the outcome, although the probability of the given hypothesis is not ignored.
  • If the probability of an outcome is sufficiently low, we have evidence that the hypothesis is false.
  • It is also called the p value.

The Null Hypothesis and Alternative Hypothesis

  • The hypothesis that an apparent effect or outcome is only due to chance is a null hypothesis.
  • In other words, a null hypothesis is one where there is no difference between the specified sample and population and any observed difference is due to chance or some other error.
  • A null hypothesis is represented by H0.
  • If the null hypothesis is rejected as false, then there is an alternative or experimental hypothesis (HA), which is logically accepted.

Criterion or Significance Level (α)

  • If the probability value of an outcome is sufficiently low, then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • This point below which we would define the probability value as being low enough to reject the null hypothesis is called the criterion or significance level or α (alpha) level.
  • When the null hypothesis is rejected, the effect or outcome is said to be statistically significant.
  • By convention (but not always), the level of α is 0.05, i.e., if the probability value of an outcome is less than or equal to 0.05 (p value ≤ 0.05), then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • If it is greater than 0.05, then the null hypothesis is accepted.
  • Although by convention the level of α is 0.05, it can be lower but cannot be any higher.

Type I Error

  • The interpretation of p value ≤ 0.05 is that an investigator can be 95% sure that the result was not obtained by chance.
  • It also means that there is a 5% probability that the result was obtained by chance.
  • From this, we can deduce that the null hypothesis might indeed be true even though we rejected it.
  • This is a type I error. In other words, when an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it is a type I error or false positive error.
  • It is also called an alpha (α) error as it is related to the criterion α.
  • The lower the α level, the lower the rate of a type I error being made.
  • Thus, it can be said that α is the maximum tolerable probability that a type I error is being made and that the p value is the probability that a significant difference is declared when there is none.

Type II Error

  • The error that is made by rejecting an alternative hypothesis when it is true or failing to reject a null hypothesis when it is false is called a type II error.
  • It is also called a false negative error and more commonly, as a beta (β) error.
  • If the null hypothesis is false, then the probability of a type II error is β.
  • The power of a statistical test is indicated by 1–β.

Power of a Test

  • The power of a test is the ability of a statistical test to avoid a type II error, which depends on its ability to detect a false null hypothesis.
  • It is equal to 1–β, which is the probability that a false null hypothesis will be rejected.
  • By convention, a test is required to have a power of 0.8 (or a β of 0.2) to be acceptable. This is to say that a study that has less than 80% chance of detecting a false null hypothesis is unacceptable.
  • Type I errors are easily reduced by reducing the criterion α.
  • A test's power will increase in the following conditions:
    • If α increases, but this will increase the chance of a type I error.
    • If the difference between the sample mean and hypothesized mean increases. This is also called effect size.
    • If sampling error decreases.
    • If the sample size (n) increases.

questions.text: A person presents to the hospital with fever and chills. A fever profile is ordered and is found to be negative for malaria and dengue. rk39 test is found to be positive. What is the site of action of the drug that is considered the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a person with fever with chills and a positive rK39 test are suggestive of kala azar. The treatment of choice of this condition is amphotericin B. It acts on the cell membrane of fungi.

Amphotericin B is a polyene compound obtained from Streptomyces nodosus. Polyene compounds have a high affinity for the ergosterol, which is present in the fungal cell membrane. It binds to the ergosterol and is inserted into the cell membrane, forming a micropore. Recent evidence suggests that the amphotericin B forms aggregates that sequester ergosterol from lipid layers, much like a sponge, resulting in fungal cell death. Amphotericin B is the least toxic among polyenes and is used systemically for fungal infections. Nystatin and hamycin have high systemic toxicity and are used only for local and topical action.

Kala azar or visceral leishmaniasis is a protozoal infection, mainly affecting the reticuloendothelial system. It is caused by the Leishmania donovani complex that includes L. donovani and L. infantum. These organisms are transmitted by sandflies. 

Clinical features of kala azar: 

  • Moderate- to high-grade fever with chills and rigors
  • Splenomegaly and hepatomegaly
  • Anemia
  • Lymphadenopathy
  • Pedal edema, ascites, due to hypoalbuminemia
  • Epistaxis, gastrointestinal bleed, and retinal hemorrhages, due to thrombocytopenia

The gold standard test for the diagnosis is the demonstration of amastigotes in the smears of tissue aspirates. Another commonly used modality is the detection of antibodies to a recombinant antigen called rK39 by rapid immunochormatographic test. 

Amphotericin B is the first-line drug used in India. Other drugs useful in treating the condition are sodium stibogluconate, meglumine antimoniate, paromomycin, and miltefosine.

questions.text: Which of the following CD markers is least specific to B cells?
questions.solution:
CD14 is expressed on monocytes.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Okazaki fragments?

choices.text: It is synthesized in short fragments of 1-5kb size
It is synthesised on the leading strand
Upto 1000 Okazaki fragments may be synthesized for each replication fork

questions.solution:
Okazaki fragments are synthesized on the lagging strand, not the leading strand.

DNA polymerase δ synthesizes Okazaki fragments, which are short, newly synthesized DNA fragments that are formed on the lagging template strand during DNA replication. They are complementary to the lagging template strand.

Primase synthesizes RNA primers to start the replication. Upto 1000 Okazaki fragments may be synthesized for each replication fork

Related Pearl: Enzymes Involved in DNA Replication

Prokaryotic DNA replication enzymes and their function:

Enzyme Function
DNA Polymerase I (Pol I) Gap filling following DNA replication, repair, and recombination
DNA polymerase II (Pol II) DNA proofreading and repair
DNA polymerase III (Pol III)

Processive, leading strand synthesis, DNA proofreading
DnaG

Primase 
Helicase ATP-driven processive unwinding of DNA.

questions.text: What is the protein affected in the condition characterized by the following clinical appearance?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of the patient in the given image is plexiform neurofibromatosis. The protein affected is neurofibromin.

Neurofibromatosis (NF) is an autosomal dominant disorder. NF type 1 (NF-1) is the most prevalent type and is caused by loss of function mutation of the NF-1 gene.

NF1 is clinically diagnosed when any 2 of the following 7 features are present:

  1. Six or more café-au-lait macules
  2. Axillary or inguinal freckling
  3. Two or more iris Lisch nodules
  4. Two or more neurofibromas or 1 plexiform neurofibroma
  5. A distinctive osseous lesion such as sphenoid dysplasia
  6. Optic gliomas
  7. A first-degree relative with NF-1

 

The image below shows multiple café-au-lait spots distributed over the body.

The image below shows neurofibromatosis: axillary freckling and café-au-lait spots.

Other options - 

  • The protein Merlin is affected in neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF-2). It is a disorder characterized by the growth of noncancerous tumors in the nervous system. The most common tumors associated with NF-2 are called vestibular schwannomas or acoustic neuroma.
  • Tuberin is affected in tuberous sclerosis (TS). It is also known as tuberous sclerosis complex or Bourneville disease. It is a neurocutaneous disorder (phakomatosis) characterized by the development of multiple benign tumors of the embryonic ectoderm (e.g. skin, eyes, and nervous system). It is an autosomal dominant condition.
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia (AT) is an autosomal recessive multisystem genetic disorder caused by a mutation in the ATM gene, which encodes for the ATM protein. AT systemic manifestations include cutaneous telangiectasias, radiosensitivity, immune deficiency with recurrent sinopulmonary infections, and a tendency to develop lymphoid malignancies.

questions.text:
You should recommend only 1 booster Td dose to a pregnant woman if pregnancy occurs within _____ years of the last pregnancy and 2 Td doses were received.
(Choose the best possible option)
questions.solution:
You should recommend only 1 booster Td dose to a pregnant woman if pregnancy occurs within 3 years of the last pregnancy and 2 Td doses were received.

The Tetanus and adult diphtheria (Td) vaccine is a combination of tetanus and diphtheria with a lower concentration of diphtheria antigen (d) as recommended for older children and adults. The MoHFW recommends the replacement of the TT vaccine with the Td vaccine for all age groups, including pregnant women. A dose of 0.5 mL is administered via the intramuscular route in the upper arm.

Scheduled to be administered at 10 and 16 years of age.

For pregnant women :

  • Td-1: early in pregnancy
  • Td-2: 4 weeks after Td-1
  • Td (Booster): if pregnancy occurs within 3 years of the last pregnancy and 2 Td doses were received.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about dobutamine is false?

choices.text: It is contraindicated in patients with congestive heart failure.
It is administered as a continuous infusion as it has a short half-life of just 120 seconds.
The rate of infusion required to increase cardiac output typically is between 2.5 and 10 μg/kg per minute.
Dobutamine may increase the size of a myocardial infarct by increasing myocardial O2 demand.

questions.solution:
Dobutamine is not contraindicated in congestive heart failure.

Indications for dobutamine include short-term treatment of cardiac decompensation that may occur

  • Following cardiac surgery. 
  • In patients with congestive heart failure or acute myocardial infarction. 

Dobutamine increases cardiac output and stroke volume, usually without a marked increase in heart rate. It resembles dopamine, but has no action on dopamine receptors. It is a full agonist at beta-receptors. It is administered as a continuous infusion as it has a short half-life of just 120 seconds. The rate of infusion required to increase cardiac output typically is between 2.5 and 10 μg/kg per min.

Like the other inotropic agents, dobutamine may increase the size of a myocardial infarct by increasing myocardial O2 demand.

questions.text: During which phase of the cardiac cycle does maximum blood flow through the left coronary artery occur?
questions.solution:
Maximum flow through the left coronary artery occurs in diastole. The maximum blood flow occurs after the end of the isovolumetric relaxation phase when the intraventricular pressure falls to the lowest and the pressure gradient is conducive for a rapid flow. 

The graph plotting the blood flow in the left and right coronary arteries during various phases of the cardiac cycle is as below. The two vertical dashed lines denote the period between which the systole occurs. As evident, the peak of left coronary flow occurs during the diastole.

The clinical significance of this information is that the coronary circulation gets compromised during increased heart rate which cuts short the duration of diastole more than systole.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding Schwabach's test?

choices.text: Test is performed with the meatus occluded
Bone conduction of the patient is compared with that of examiner

questions.solution:
Meatus is not occluded while performing the Schwabach test.

In Schwabach's test, the bone conduction of the patient is compared with that of the normal hearing person (examiner), but unlike the absolute bone conduction test, the EAC is not occluded. Inferences are as follows:

  • Normal - same as the examiner
  • Conductive deafness - lengthened than that of the examiner
  • Sensorineural deafness - shortened than that of the examiner

TUNING FORK TESTS:
I) Rinne’s test:

A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the patient’s mastoid, and when he stops hearing, it is brought beside the meatus. If he can still hear it, air conduction is better than bone conduction.

  • Positive - when the air conduction (AC) is longer or louder than bone conduction (BC). Seen in normal persons and persons with sensorineural deafness.
  • Negative - when the bone conduction is better than air conduction. Seen in patients with conductive deafness.

II) Weber test:

A vibrating tuning fork is placed in the middle of the forehead or the vertex, and the patient is asked in which ear the sound is heard.

  • Normal - heard equally in both ears
  • Conductive deafness - lateralized to the worse ear
  • Sensorineural deafness - lateralized to the better ear.

III) Absolute Bone Conduction test:

Here, the patient’s bone conduction is compared with that of the examiner. The external auditory meatus of both the patient and the examiner should be occluded (by pressing the tragus inwards) to prevent the ambient noise from entering through the AC route.

  • Normal - same as the examiner.
  • Conductive deafness - same as the examiner.
  • Sensorineural deafness - reduced than that of the examiner.

Related Pearl: Tuning fork tests

Tests Normal
Conductive 
loss
Sensorineural

Schwabach Normal Lengthened Shortened

questions.text: The spinal X-ray of a patient with chronic back pain is shown below. What could be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows the winking owl sign, which is seen in spinal metastases. It refers to the appearance of the spine when a pedicle is absent. 

The usual appearance of the pedicle representing two eyes on the AP projection is lost, as one pedicle is destroyed. It then appears like one eye is open and the other is winking or shut. Potentially, all bony metastasis can do this. However, breast cancer and lung cancer are commonly associated with this condition.

The 2 images given below show X-rays with a winking owl signs on different sides.
