questions.text: As per the MoHFW guidelines for use of paracetamol following vaccinations, all of the following are correct, except that ______.

choices.text: Number of paracetamol syrup bottles available for a session should be 10% more than the total number of doses of pentavalent and DPT expected to be administered in the session.
Paracetamol syrup should be regularly administered to all children following DPT/ Pentavalent vaccination to prevent onset of fever.
One bottle of syrup paracetamol  should be dispensed only to children who have been administered pentavalent or DPT in the vaccination session.
If paracetamol suspension is supplied in place of syrup, the bottle should be shaken for 10 seconds before use and this should be demonstrated to the parent.

questions.solution:
Paracetamol syrup should not be regularly administered to all children following DPT/ Pentavalent vaccination. Paracetamol syrup should be administered only if there is fever following vaccination (axillary temperature>38oC/ 100.4oF or child feels hot to touch).

The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW) guidelines for use of paracetamol following vaccinations recommend the following:

  • The number of paracetamol syrup bottles available for a session should be 10% more than the total number of doses of pentavalent and DPT expected to be administered in the session.
  • One bottle of syrup paracetamol should be dispensed only to children who have been administered pentavalent or DPT in the vaccination session.
  • If paracetamol suspension is supplied in place of syrup, the bottle should be shaken for 10 seconds before use and this should be demonstrated to the parent.
  • Paracetamol syrup should be administered only if there is fever following vaccination (axillary temperature>38oC/ 100.4oF or child feels hot to touch). The age-wise dose of paracetamol syrup (125 mg/ 5 mL) in infants is: (@10–15 mg/kg body weight)
    • 6 weeks - 6 months - 2.5 mL
    • 6 - 24 months - 5 mL
    • 2 - 4 Years - 7.5 mL
    • 4 - 6 years - 10 mL 
      • Paracetamol is not recommended in children weighing <2 kg
      • Maximum of four doses in 24 hours, with a gap of at least four hours between two doses

questions.text: Intrinsic resistance of gram-negative bacteria to linezolid is mediated by __________.
questions.solution:
The intrinsic resistance of gram-negative bacteria to linezolid is mediated by endogenous efflux pumps.

Linezolid is a bacteriostatic agent used to treat resistant gram-positive bacteria, such as methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE). It has excellent oral bioavailability. Prolonged therapy is associated with myelosuppression as well as ocular and reversible peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: By when does the fetal kidney start producing urine?
questions.solution:
Fetal kidneys start producing urine at 12 weeks (8–11 weeks), and by 18 weeks, they produce 7 to 14 mL per day.

Ultrafiltrate of maternal plasma contributes to the formation of amniotic fluid during early pregnancy.

Amniotic fluid formation varies with the stage of pregnancy:

  • Early pregnancy: Ultrafiltrate of maternal plasma 
  • Second trimester: Extracellular fluid that diffuses through the fetal skin and thus reflects the composition of fetal plasma
  • After 20 weeks: Fetal urine, since keratinization of fetal skin prevents diffusion across the skin

questions.text: Below is the graph of CD4 count in HIV patients. From the graph below, the median is most likely to lie between:
questions.solution:
The given data should be converted into a numerical table. Small approximations can be made while converting into numerical form.

CD4 Count Number of people
<100 5
100 - 200 10
200 - 300 25
300 - 400 35
400 - 500 20
>500 5

Since it is an even distribution of 6 frequency range, (25+35)/2= 30, which lies in the range 300-400.

The median divides the frequency distribution in half when all the scores are listed in order. When a distribution has an odd number of elements, the median is the middle value. When the distribution has an even number of elements, the median is the average of the two middle scores. The median here is the mean of the 50th & 51st observations when arranged in ascending order. Since both lie within the range of 300-400, the median is also between 300-400.

 

 

Related Pearl: The Median in Biostatistics

  • The median is the central element in a distribution when all the elements are arranged in order.
  • In a distribution that has an odd number of elements, the median is the middle value.
  • In a distribution that has an even number of elements, the median is the average of the middle values, i.e., the arithmetic mean of the two middle values.
  • The median is not sensitive to extreme values, i.e., outliers and thus it is preferred measure of location for very skewed distributions.
  • The drawback of the median is that it doesn’t respond to the actual values of the elements but only to the number of values above or below it.
  • The median is the same as the 50th centile.
  • It is sometimes symbolized by Mdn.
  • The median can be arrived at in ordinal, interval and ratio data scales.

Related Pearl: The Mean (Arithmetic) in Biostatistics

  • The mean is also called the average or arithmetic mean.
  • It is the sum of all elements in the distribution divided by the number of all the elements in it.
  • It is usually denoted by μ in a population and by x̄ (x-bar) in a sample.
  • The formula for sample mean is given as:

where the sigma sign denotes summation and n is the total number of elements.

  • The arithmetic mean responds to the exact value of every element in the distribution.
  • This makes it over-sensitive to extreme values, i.e., outliers thus making it an inappropriate measure for skewed distributions.
  • The advantage of the arithmetic mean is that if repeated samples are taken from the same populations, they will have very similar means, i.e., the measure of central tendency that best resists the influence of fluctuation between samples is the mean.
  • The mean can be calculated only on quantitative data on an interval or a ratio scale.

Related Pearl: The Mode in Biostatistics

  • The mode is most frequently occurring observed value in a distribution.
  • A distribution with a single mode is called unimodal.
  • If two values occur with the highest frequency, then the distribution is bimodal.
  • If more than two values occur with the highest frequency, then the distribution is multimodal.
  • The mode is the preferred measure of central tendency for nominal data.
  • It is sometimes symbolized by Mo.
  • Mode can be arrived at from all data scales, i.e., nominal, ordinal, ratio and interval.

questions.text: An alcoholic patient with cirrhosis is being taken up for surgery. Which of the following induction agents will be the safest to use in this case?
questions.solution:
Isoflurane and sevoflurane are induction agents of choice in a patient with liver disease.

Hepatic arterial blood flow is reduced in cirrhosis. Sevoflurane and isoflurane are known to maintain hepatic blood flow and improve oxygen delivery to the liver. Other factors to avoid that decrease hepatic arterial blood flow are hypotension, high mean airway pressure, and excessive sympathetic activation.

In the case of liver disease, cis-atracurium may be preferred as a neuromuscular blocking agent because it is not metabolized by the liver. However, if the patient is unstable with active bleeding, rapid sequence induction can be performed using ketamine/etomidate and succinylcholine.

Other options-

Option (A): Methoxyflurane is a hepatotoxic and highly nephrotoxic drug. Its use gradually declined after the 1970s. 

Option (B): Thiopentone, also known as thiopental, is a barbiturate that is excreted primarily via the liver. Hence, it would lead to toxicity if used in patients with liver disease.

Option (D): Ketamine is a dissociative anesthetic agent that accumulates in the liver and undergoes rapid metabolism. It is also known to cause hepatotoxicity, which presents as an elevation in liver enzymes. These two reasons make ketamine unsuitable for use in patients with liver disease.

Related Pearl: Inhalational anaesthetic agents

Inhalational agent of choice: 

Indication Anesthetic gas
1. Induction  Sevoflurane
2. Daycare surgery Sevflurane>Desflurane
3. Elderly  Desflurane
4. Cardiac surgery Isoflurane
5. Renal disease Desflurane
6. Liver disease  Sevoflurane > Desflurane 
7. Neurosurgery    Sevoflurane>Isoflurane
8. Asthmatics Sevoflurane
9. Obese patients Desflurane

 

Feature Drug
Most potent       Methoxyflurane > Halothane 
Least potent      Nitrous oxide > Desflurane 
Most epileptogenic   Enflurane
Most nephrotoxic Methoxyflurane 
Most hepatotoxic Halothane

questions.text:
Match the following food adulterants with the respective conditions they result in
  1. BOAA
  2. Sanguinarine 
  3. Pyrrolizidine alkaloids
  4. Clavine alkaloids

 

  1. Painful cramps in limbs, and peripheral gangrene
  2. Gradual spastic paralysis of lower limbs
  3. Acute bilateral non-inflammatory swelling of legs, diarrhea, dyspnea, cardiac death
  4. Rapidly developing ascites, jaundice
questions.solution:
The correct match is: 

  • BOAA - Lathyrism
  • Sanguinarine - Epidemic dropsy
  • Pyrrolizidine alkaloids - Endemic ascites
  • Clavine alkaloids - Ergotism 
Disease   Food Substance  Toxic Principle  Clinical features
Neurolathyrism Lathyrus sativus /Khesari dal  BOAA (beta oxalyl amino alanine) Gradual spastic paralysis of lower limbs
Epidemic dropsy  Argemone oil  Sanguinarine  Acute bilateral non-inflammatory swelling of legs, diarrhea, dyspnea, cardiac death
Ergotism Bajra, wheat/ Claviceps purpurea Clavine alkaloids Acute- Nausea, vomiting, drowsiness
Chronic- Painful cramps in limbs, and peripheral gangrene
Endemic ascites  Crotalaria/Jhunjhunia  Pyrrolizidine alkaloids  Rapidly developing ascites, jaundice

 

Lathyrism is a paralyzing disease of humans and animals. It is due to the consumption of Khesari dal/Lathyrus sativus. When the husk is removed, it looks similar to red gram dal or Bengal gram dal. It is more prevalent in parts of Madhya Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh, Odisha, and Bihar.

In humans, it is referred to as neurolathyrism because it affects the nervous system. It is characterized by gradually developing spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. In animals, it is referred to as osteolathyrism/odoratism because the pathological changes in the bones lead to skeletal deformities. It usually affects young males aged 15-45 years and it is manifested in stages: 

  • Latent stage
  • No-stick stage
  • One-stick stage
  • Two-stick stage
  • Crawler stage

BOAA (Beta oxalyl amino alanine) is the toxic compound causing Lathyrism. The water-soluble property of the toxin is used in removing it from the pulses by soaking it in hot water and rejecting the soaked water.  Parboiling can be used for detoxifying the crop on large-scale operations. Overnight soaking in lime water followed by boiling is also effective in destroying the toxin. Vitamin C in doses of 500-1000mg can be used for the prevention and treatment of lathyrism. The Prevention of Food Adulteration Act in India has banned Lathyrus sativus in all forms (whole/split/flour).

Epidemic dropsy is caused by the toxic compound sanguinarine, which is present in argemone oil extracted from argemone seeds. It is commonly used as an adulterant in mustard oil.

Epidemic dropsy results in sudden onset of swelling of lower limbs, diarrhea, and breathlessness. Some patients may develop hypersecretory glaucoma. It can lead to death due to cardiac failure.

Adulteration with argemone oil can be detected by the following tests:

  • Paper chromatography - most sensitive test
  • Nitric acid test 

The weed seeds of Crotalaria contain Pyrrozolidine alkaloids that are hepatotoxic. The millet Panicum milaire gets adultered or contaminated with weed seeds of Crotalaria, produces symptoms of endemic Ascites, which is rapidly developing ascites and Jaundice.

Preventive measures:

  • Sieving of millets at home
  • Deweeding of Jhunjhunia plants
  • Health education

Ergot or Claviceps purpurae is a field fungus. Food grains like bajra, rye, sorghum, and wheat have a tendency to get contaminated with this ergot fungus. It grows as a blackish mass and the seeds become black and irregular. These get harvested along with the food grains and consumption of this ergot-infested grain leads to ergotism.  

Acute cases present with nausea, vomiting, giddiness, and drowsiness for a period up to 24 to 48 hours after the ingestion of ergot grain. In cases of chronic consumption, they present with painful cramps in limbs, and peripheral gangrene due to vasoconstriction of capillaries. 

Ergot-infested grains can be removed easily by floating them in 20 percent saltwater. Floatation and handpicking can also be used in the removal of them. 0.05 mg per 100 grams of food material is the upper safe limit for ergot alkaloids. 

Related Pearl: Food adulteration diseases

Food Adulterant Toxin Disease
Dal Khesari dal (Lathyrus sativus) BOAA* Lathyrism
Oil Argemone mexicana (oil) Sanguinarine Epidemic dropsy
Millet Crotalaria seeds (Jhunjhunia) Pyrrolizidine alkaloids
(Hepatotoxic)		 Endemic ascites 
Bajra, wheat Claviceps purpurea Clavine alkaloids Ergotism

 * BOAA-Beta Oxalyl Amino Alanine

questions.text: A patient who is comfortable at rest, but has symptoms on less than ordinary physical activity, with marked limitation of physical activity, is classified as ________.
questions.solution:
A patient who is comfortable at rest, but has symptoms on less than ordinary physical activity, with marked limitation of physical activity, should be classified as NYHA class III.

NYHA class Description
I
  • No limitation of physical activity
  • Ordinary physical activity does not cause symptoms
II
  • Slight limitation of physical activity
  • Comfortable at rest, but ordinary physical activity causes symptoms
III
  • Marked limitation of physical activity
  • Comfortable at rest, but less than ordinary physical activity causes symptoms
IV
  • Unable to carry out any physical activity without symptoms or symptoms at rest

questions.text: Which of the following modes of transport follows transportation kinetics similar to that marked by the arrow in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image indicates a transportation process that shows a linear increase and does not get saturated at higher concentrations. Simple diffusion is not a carrier-mediated transport and hence, does not follow saturation kinetics.

Facilitated diffusion, primary active transport, and secondary active transport all involve integral membrane proteins and are called carrier-mediated transport. All carrier-mediated transport system follows saturation kinetics. The figure shows that as the concentration of the diffusing substance increases, the rate of simple diffusion continues to increase proportionately, but in the case of facilitated diffusion, the rate of diffusion cannot rise greater than the transport maximum (Tm). Tm is analogous to the maximum velocity (Vmax) level in enzyme kinetics.

 

Related Pearl: Characteristics of Carrier Mediated Transport

Properties Description
Stereospecificity For example- D-Glucose is transport by facilitated diffusion but not L-isomer. Simple diffusion in contrast will not distinguish between the two.
Saturation The transport rate increases as the concentration of the solute increases until the carriers are saturated (Tm).
Competition Structurally related solutes compete for transport sites on carrier molecules.

Related Pearl: Characteristics of different types of transport

Type Simple diffusion Facilitated diffusion Primary active transport Secondary active transport Cotransport Secondary active transport Countertransport
Electrochemical gradient Downhill Downhill Uphill Uphill Uphill
Carrier mediated No Yes Yes Yes Yes
Metabolic energy No No Yes Indirect Indirect
Na+ gradient No No -- Yes (same direction) Yes (opposite direction)

Inhibits Na+-K+ pump

questions.text: Which of the following statements about insulin glargine is false?

choices.text: It cannot be mixed with short acting insulins
It should be administered at the same time each day
It can be safely administered via the IV route as well

questions.solution:
Insulin glargine should be administered only via the subcutaneous route. 

It is a long-acting insulin with ~24 hours duration of action. Hence, it requires a once-daily dosing(option D) and can be administered at any time of the day. However, the catch is that it should be administered at the same designated time each day(option B) to serve as a part of an effective basal bolus regime. 

Insulin glargine forms a cloudy white precipitate when mixed with short-acting insulins(option A). Due to the acidic pH (4.0) of insulin glargine, it cannot be mixed with short-acting insulin preparations that are formulated at a neutral pH as it aggregates at a neutral pH into a cloudy white precipitate. This reduces the effectiveness of the insulin dose.

Related Pearl: Insulin Classification According to Duration of Action

questions.text: Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is a Dyball retractor.

Dyball retractor is used in major abdominal surgeries to retract deeper parts of the abdominal wall, bladder, or uterus while operating on the rectum and entering the rectovesical or rectouterine pouch. It has a lip at the bottom of the blade to prevent slippage. Care should be taken when it is used to retract the liver as it may damage the liver parenchyma.

Option B: The below image is that of a Langenbeck retractor. It is used for holding open wounds, as in an open appendicectomy. 

Option C: Goligher retractor is a self-retaining retractor used in operations on the sigmoid colon and rectum, such as anterior resection and the upper end of abdomino-perineal resection. The retractor is inserted with the side blades to separate the edges of the abdominal wall. The central blade is then inserted to keep the small bowel away from the operation site.

Option D: Travers retractor is a self-retaining retractor used for intermediate-type operations, such as:

  • Herniorrhaphy
  • Groin dissection for varicose veins
  • Femoral embolectomy

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is likely to present with a fallen fragment/ fallen leaf sign or a trapdoor sign on an X-Ray?
questions.solution:
A solitary bone cyst (unicameral bone cyst/ simple bone cyst) is likely to appear as a fallen fragment sign/ fallen leaf sign or as a trapdoor sign on an X-Ray.

Simple bone cyst always occurs during the first two decades of life, most often between 4-10 years of age with a 2:1 male preponderance. It is a benign unilocular cyst filled with straw-colored serosanguinous fluid. The commonest site is the proximal humerus. They are usually asymptomatic, but pathological fractures may occur through the cyst wall and may cause pain and swelling. The cyst may cause growth disturbances due to its proximity to the growth plate.

On X-ray, a bone fracture fragment may be seen resting in a dependent portion of the cyst. This is known as the fallen fragment/fallen leaf sign and it is pathognomonic of a simple bone cyst. The trapdoor sign is a variant of the fallen leaf sign. Here, a periosteal hinge keeps the fragment from falling dependently and allows it to change position with a change in the patient's position.

Treatment of simple bone cyst:

  • Small, asymptomatic lesions - serial observation with plain radiographs, as lesions will regress following skeletal maturity
  • Larger lesions (at risk of pathologic fracture) and symptomatic lesions - 
    • Curettage 
    • Aspiration and injection using:
      • Corticosteroids
      • Bone marrow aspirate
      • Demineralized bone matrix
  • Pathological fractures -
    • Upper limb: managed conservatively as the fracture may initiate cyst healing
    • Lower limb: curettage, bone grafting, and internal fixation

questions.text: Which of the following patients is best suited to undergo Rapid-Sequence Intubation (RSI)?

choices.text: A comatose patient with diabetic ketoacidosis and severe uncontrolled hypertension needing airway protection
An RTA victim with a large intracranial bleed with imminent herniation
A pregnant female with a full stomach  planned for surgery
A victim from a building fire with extensive third degree burns needing airway protection

questions.solution:
Among the given options, a pregnant female with a full stomach planned for surgery is the best-suited candidate for RSI.

Indications of Rapid sequence intubation:

RSI is done when the patient is at increased risk of pulmonary aspiration as in:

  • pregnancy
  • full stomach
  • intestinal obstruction
  • hiatus hernia
  • encephalopathy
  • morbid obesity
  • diabetic gastroparesis.

There are only relative contraindications to rapid-sequence inductions. As Rapid-Sequence Inductions are usually associated with increase in intracranial pressure, arterial blood pressure, and heart rate, the patients with an intracranial bleed and uncontrolled HTN would not be ideal candidates. As RSI entails the use of succinylcholine, the patient with extensive 3rd degree burns would also not be an ideal candidate.

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the following scoring systems in the ascending order of their respective maximum possible scores
  1. Glasgow coma scale
  2. Revised Trauma Score
  3. Abbreviated Injury Scale
  4. Injury Severity Score
questions.solution:
The respective possible score ranges are

  • Glasgow coma scale - 3-15
  • Revised Trauma Score - 0-12
  • Abbreviated Injury Scale - 1-6
  • Injury Severity Score - 3-75

Hence the ascending order of maximum possible scores would be - Abbreviated Injury Scale->Revised Trauma Score-> Glasgow coma scale-> Injury Severity Score.

The ISS is defined as the sum of squares of the highest Abbreviated Injury Scale grade in the three most severely injured body regions. Six body regions are defined, as follows: the thorax, abdomen and visceral pelvis, head and neck, face, bony pelvis and extremities, and external structures. Only one injury per body region is allowed. If any body-system has an unsurvivable injury (AIS = 6), the total score automatically becomes 75.

 The Injury severity score (ISS) ranges from 1 to 75, with severity groupings being defined as

  • Minor injury (less than 9),
  • Moderate injury (between 9 and 16),
  • Serious injury (between 16 and 25), and
  • Severe injury (more than 25)

Related Pearl: Trauma Scoring Systems

Revised Trauma Score  - Total score 0-12 :

  • Glasgow coma scale
  • Respiratory rate
  • Systolic BP

Glasgow coma scale  - Total score 3-15 :

  • Eye-opening
  • Verbal response
  • Motor response

Abbreviated Injury Scale: AIS severity code – 1(minimal severity) to 6 (presumably fatal)

Injury Severity Score – Total score 1 to 75. Calculated summing the squares of the AIS severity codes for the three most severely injured body regions

Score Severity of injury
3-8 Minor
9-16 Moderate
16-24 Serious
>25 Severe/ Critical

  

Mangled Extremity Severity score: Mnemonic - ELiSA

  • Energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s age

TRISS (Trauma and Injury Severity Score) : Mnemonic - IRMA

  • Injury Severity Score
  • Revised Trauma Score
  • Mechanism of Injury (blunt/penetrating)
  • Age

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury

Minimum value: 3

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the clinical presentation of colorectal cancers is incorrect?

choices.text: Left-sided colonic tumors usually present with altered bowel habits or rectal bleeding.
Colonic flexural tumors may present with vague chronic upper abdominal symptoms.
Proximal tumors typically present late, with iron-deficiency anemia or as a mass lesion.
Metastatic disease is a very uncommon presentation and is rarely seen.

questions.solution:
Metastatic disease is a common presentation of colonic cancer.

The most common site of distant metastasis of colorectal cancer is the liver. These metastases arise from hematogenous spread via the portal venous system. The risk of hepatic metastasis increases with tumor size and tumor grade.

The second most common site of distant metastasis is the lung. This is also due to hematogenous spread. Carcinomatosis (diffuse peritoneal metastases) occurs by peritoneal seeding.

Note: Regional lymph node involvement is the most common form of spread of colorectal carcinoma and usually precedes distant metastasis.

Right and left colon cancers can behave differently, as obstruction is more common with left-sided tumors than right-sided tumors. This is because of the caliber of the bowel and the consistency of the stool. Rectal bleeding is also more common with left-sided tumors.

Right colon cancers or proximal colon cancers usually present late with features of iron-deficiency anemia or as a mass lesion.

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory investigation findings is unlikely to be seen in a patient with hemolytic anemia?
questions.solution:
The presence of bilirubin in urine is not seen in hemolytic anemia.

In hemolysis, there is increased production of bilirubin. This leads to an increase in indirect bilirubin in the blood (option A). This results in the increased production of urobilinogen in the intestine which is excreted as fecal urobilinogen (option C). Excess urobilinogen is also reabsorbed into the blood and appears in increased amounts in the urine (option D). The increased levels of urine urobilinogen and the absence of urine bilirubin are characteristic of hemolytic jaundice.

Obstructive jaundice has the following features:

  • Increased serum direct bilirubin: Due to obstruction in the biliary tree, the bilirubin conjugates diffuse into the blood, causing conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
  • Increased urine bilirubin: Being water-soluble, conjugated bilirubin appears in the urine in excess amounts.
  • Absent urobilinogen: In complete obstruction of the CBD, conjugated bilirubin cannot enter the intestine and be metabolized by the intestinal flora. Hence, urobilinogen is not formed and is absent in the urine.

 

Related Pearl: Types of Jaundice

Type of jaundice Serum bilirubin Urine Urobilinogen Urine bilirubin
Pre-hepatic ↑ Indirect          ↑        -
Hepatic ↑ Direct and indirect   Normal/ ↓       +/-
Post-hepatic ↑ Direct          -        +

questions.text: Which of the following fluoroquinolones is associated with the lowest risk of QT prolongation?
questions.solution:
Ciprofloxacin has the lowest risk of QT prolongation.

Among the given options, moxifloxacin has the highest risk of QT prolongation. Levofloxacin, ofloxacin, and gemifloxacin have a relatively lower risk than moxifloxacin.

Other adverse effects of fluoroquinolones:

  • Clostridium difficile colitis

  • Mild headache, dizziness, and rarely, hallucinations, delirium, and seizure

  • Tendinitis and Achilles tendon rupture

questions.text: Which of the following ulcers is most likely to be the result of venous disease?
questions.solution:
The ulcer seen in image 1 is most likely to be the result of venous disease, as these are located over the characteristic gaiter area of the leg. Also, the ulcers are seen over a background of skin discoloration in a leg that appears shiny and tense, presumably a result of venous stasis.

Type of Ulcer Ischaemic / Arterial Venous Neuropathic Tuberculous  
Underlying condition

Peripheral vascular disease- mainly atherosclerosis, thromboangiitis obliterans, cervical rib, Raynaud's phenomenon

 Varicose veins, previous deep vein thrombosis Diabetes, peripheral neuropathy Tuberculosis lymph nodes, cold abscess from bone and joint tuberculosis
Location Toes, feet, legs, or even upper limb digits Lower limb, commonly on the medial side of the ankle, never above the middle third of the leg The plantar surface of the foot, toes Neck, axilla and groin
Characteristics

Deep, penetrates the deep fascia exposing the tendons, muscles, and underlying bone.

The ulcer is painful, tender, and hyperaesthetic. 

 Vertically oval, painless, the floor may have pale to no granulation tissue, induration, and tenderness at the base. Punched-out with regular calloused margins. 

Edges are thin, reddish blue, undermined; pale granulation tissue, scanty discharge on the floor, and slight induration at the base
Other features Features of ischemia in adjacent areas, like pallor, dry skin, brittle nails, loss of hair Inguinal lymph nodes enlarged, usually the vertical group, the ulcer is recurrent; forms again after healing Dry, cracked, insensate Regional lymph nodes are enlarged, non-tender, matted

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

The following image depicts an arterial ulcer.

A neuropathic ulcer is one that occurs as a result of peripheral neuropathy. In peripheral neuropathy, lack of sensation over the pressure points leads to cumulative microtrauma, minor wounds, or cuts that go unnoticed eventually developing into ulcers.

Features of a neuropathic ulcer include:

  • Painless ulcer
  • Punched out ulcer with regular margins.
  • Often located on the plantar surface of the foot
  • Ulcer margins show the presence of calluses.

It is approved for use in patients with stable angina.
It acts as an agonist at ATP-sensitive potassium channel.
Its adverse effects include hypotension and GI ulcers.

questions.solution:
Nicorandil dilates both arterial and venous vascular beds, leading to a decrease in afterload and preload of the heart. 

Nicorandil causes activation of K+-ATP channels. This leads to the hyperpolarization of the smooth muscle cells, leading to vasodilatation. It also has nitrate-like cGMP-dependent action. Adverse effects of nicorandil include headache and hypotension, similar to nitrates. Apart from this, it is associated with GI ulcers and perforations.

Related Pearl: Anti-anginal drugs

Anti-anginal drugs can be divided into the following categories:

  • Nitrates - dilates veins > arteries, reduces preload
  • Calcium channel blockers - blocks L-type calcium channels
    • Dihydropyridines - amlodipine, nifedipine
    • Non-dihydropyridines - verapamil, diltiazem
  • Beta-blockers - decreases heart rate, contractility and oxygen demand
  • Other drugs: 
    • Ranolazine - late Na+ channel blocker
    • Ivabradine - inhibit funny currents in SA node
    • Nicorandil - K+-ATP channel agonist
    • Trimetazidine - pFOX inhibitor
    • Fasudil - rho-kinase inhibitor

questions.text: Thoracic CT of a patient who had a history of road traffic accident is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given CT scan shows dark zones within the pleural cavity of the right lung, which is suggestive of a right pneumothorax and collapsed lung. Lung anatomy is not clearly seen and is masked by dark zones.

Pleural effusion refers to the presence of fluid within the pleural cavity. A hemothorax refers to the presence of blood within the pleural cavity. Empyema refers to the presence of pus in the pleural cavity. In all these cases, there is hyperdensity noted in the pleural cavity.

The below image shows empyema which appears hyperdense.

questions.text:
Which of the following findings would you expect to see in a patient with a positive Beck's triad?
  1. Absent X descent
  2. Absent y descent
  3. Electrical alternans in ECG
  4. Pulsus paradoxus
  5. Increase in amplitude of the QRS complexes
questions.solution:
A positive Beck's triad indicates a likely diagnosis of cardiac tamponade. X descent is prominent and the amplitude of the QRS complexes is decreased in cardiac tamponade.

Cardiac tamponade:

Accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space raises the intra-pericardial pressure, resulting in poor ventricular filling and a fall in cardiac output. The following are the  is characterized by the following features:

  • Hypotension
  • Pulsus paradoxus: Inspiratory fall of BP by >10 mm of Hg
  • Increased pulse rate
  • Prominent X descent, absent y descent
  • Muffled heart sound
  • Ewart’s sign (bronchial breathing at the angle of the left scapula)
  • Beck’s triad: Falling BP, raised JVP, small quiet heart or soft heart sound

Investigations:

  • X-ray chest: big globular heart
  • ECG: low voltage complexes, electrical alternans
  • ECHO: Echo free zone around the heart
  • Cardiac catheterization: a diastolic collapse of the right atrium and right ventricle

Treatment is drainage of fluid.

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding the nerve blocked by the procedure shown in the image below?
  1. Originates from nerve roots S2, S3, S4
  2. Carries only sensory fibers of the perineum
  3. Passes through Alcock's canal
  4. It passes above the piriformis
  5. Pinching of the lower vagina and posterior vulva can be used to confirm a successful block
questions.solution:
The image shows the technique of localizing the pudendal nerve and administering a pudendal nerve block transvaginally.

The pudendal nerve nerve originates from the ventral divisions of sacral nerve roots S2, S3, and S4. It carries both sensory and motor fibers to the perineum. It leaves the pelvis via the greater sciatic foramen below the piriformis to enter the gluteal region. It then accompanies the internal pudendal artery through the lesser sciatic foramen into the pudendal (Alcock’s) canal on the lateral wall of the ischio-anal fossa.

The pudendal nerve can be palpated over the ischial spine through the lateral wall of the rectum. It splits into 3 branches

    • Inferior rectal nerve
    • Perineal nerve
    • Dorsal nerve of the clitoris (or penis)

Pinching of the lower vagina and posterior vulva can be used to confirm a successful pudendal nerve block.

questions.text: Which of the following anthropophagy artifacts is incorrectly paired with the typical causative agents?

choices.text: Ant bites - Irregular wound edges with long grooves

questions.solution:
Artefacts due to animal and insect bites are referred to as anthropophagy artefacts and those produced by extensive ant bites resemble that of abrasion.

Marks produced by insects such as ants and cockroaches are dry, and brown with irregular margins. They are usually seen in moist parts of the body like ears, armpits, groin, scrotum, anus, etc. Often they appear like antemortem abrasions(Option D). As they become dry, they resemble brush burns and do not show vital reactions. Extensive linear ant bites around the neck resemble ligature abrasion.

Irregular wound edges with long grooves are findings that are typically seen in rodent bites. Dog bites are associated with deep impressions of teeth in a small area. The resulting individual puncture wounds may resemble stab wounds (Option C). Cat bites appear similar to knife wounds, especially in bones(Option B)

Artefact is any change or feature introduced in a body after death, which leads to misinterpretation of medicolegally significant antemortem findings.

Other important types of artefacts: 

  • Agonal artefacts -  Autolytic rupture of the stomach, also known as gastromalacia, is characterized by the postmortem release of gastric contents into the peritoneal cavity. It may be accompanied by a diaphragmatic rupture with evidence of gastric contents in the chest cavity. 
  • Resuscitation artefacts - Intracardiac injections show contusion and blood in the pericardium. Superficial skin burns and ring-like contusions can be caused by defibrillators. Pneumothorax after placing a subclavian or internal jugular vein catheter.
  • Artefacts by handling of the body - Contusion of the occipital region. Undertaker's fracture is a subluxation of the lower cervical spine due to the tearing of the intervertebral disc at C6-C7. 
  • Artefacts introduced during autopsy -  Air in the blood vessels due to pulling of dura may mislead to a diagnosis of air embolism. Other artefacts include fracture of the hyoid bone, injury to blood vessels, and visceral damage due to rough handling of the tissues during autopsy.

questions.text: As per the WHO guidelines, you should advise repeating the previous dose, if there is an interruption of the primary series of vaccination for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, only Ty21a requires repeating the previous dose if there is an interruption of the primary series. 

Even for Ty21a, if interruption between doses is <21 days, resume without repeating the previous dose. If >21 days, restart the primary series. 

The yellow fever vaccine is just a single dose. OPV & IPV both do not require repetition of doses in case of interrupted primary series. The vaccination can simply be resumed without repeating the previous doses. Other common vaccines which do not require a repetition in the event of interrupted primary series:

  • Hep B
  • DTP
  • Hib
  • PCV
  • Rotavirus
  • Measles
  • JE
  • Meningococcal vaccine
  • Rabies
  • Varicella

questions.text: The peripheral smear of a patient reveals the following finding (indicated by the arrow). The use of which of the following tubes for sample collection is likely to be responsible?
questions.solution:
The image shows platelet clumping. It is seen in blood samples collected with EDTA as the anticoagulant.

EDTA causes a reduction in the calcium content of the collected blood sample. This triggers in vitro platelet clumping and agglutination by antibodies (usually IgG).

When a low platelet count is obtained with an EDTA sample, the peripheral blood smear should be evaluated. The platelet count must also be determined in blood collected in sodium citrate (sky blue) or heparin (green) collection tubes or fresh fingerstick blood sample. Sample collected in a red tube cannot be used for peripheral smear preparation.

Related Pearl: Anticoagulants in Vacutainers and their Uses

questions.text: Which of the following disease-IVP finding pair is incorrect?

choices.text: Cobra/ Adder head appearance - Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter
Fish hook / Reverse J deformity - Retrocaval ureter
Handshake sign/ Hand-holding sign - Horseshoe kidney

questions.solution:
Adder head appearance/cobra head sign or the spring onion sign is seen in the ureterocele. 

It refers to dilatation of the distal ureter, surrounded by a thin rim to the ureteric wall and bladder mucosa. It is seen in patients with an adult-type ureterocele. The cobra head appearance indicates an uncomplicated ureterocele. 

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter is associated with a goblet appearance, best visualized via a retrograde urogram.

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text: The peripheral smear of a patient with suspected acute leukemia shows the following characteristic finding. What is the structure marked by the arrow known as?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Auer rods ,which are characteristically seen in acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

Auer rods are clumps of azurophilic granular material that appear as elongated needles, in the cytoplasm of leukemic blasts. They can be seen in the leukemic blasts of AML, with maturation and acute promyelocytic leukemia (known as acute myeloid leukemia M2 and M3, in the FAB classification, respectively) and in high-grade myelodysplastic syndromes and myeloproliferative syndromes.

Morphologically, the Auer "rods" come in all sizes and shapes. They have been described as needle-shaped with pointed ends (most common), comma-shaped, and diamond-shaped; others are long and rectangular. They are also used to distinguish the pre-leukemia myelodysplastic syndromes: refractory anemia with excess blasts 2 (RAEB2) (which has Auer rods) from RAEB 1 (which does not).

Related Pearl: WHO classification of Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)

The 5th edition of WHO (2022) classification classifies acute myeloid leukemia (AML) as follows:

AML with defining genetic abnormalities (gene or chromosome changes):

  • Acute promyelocytic leukemia with PML::RARA fusion
  • AML with RUNX1::RUNX1T1 fusion
  • AML with CBFB::MYH11 fusion
  • AML with DEK::NUP214 fusion
  • AML with RBM15::MRTFA fusion
  • AML with BCR::ABL1 fusion
  • AML with KMT2A rearrangement*
  • AML with MECOM rearrangement
  • AML with NUP98 rearrangement
  • AML with NPM1 mutation
  • AML with CEBPA mutation
  • AML, myelodysplasia-related#
  • AML with other defined genetic alterations

 AML, defined by differentiation:

  • AML with minimal differentiation
  • AML without maturation
  • AML with maturation
  • Acute basophilic leukaemia
  • Acute myelomonocytic leukaemia
  • Acute monocytic leukaemia
  • Acute erythroid leukaemia
  • Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia

Most AML with defining genetic abnormalities are diagnosed with < 20% blasts except AML with BCR: ABL1 and AML with CEBPA mutation that require at least 20% blasts for diagnosis.

*AML with KMT2A rearrangement is the new term that replaces “AML with t(9;11)(p22;q23); KMT2A-MLLT3

#AML with myelodysplasia-related changes has been renamed as AML, myelodysplasia-related (AML-MR).

Related Pearl: Pathological Cells/Bodies in Multiple Myeloma

  • Dutcher bodies - pale-staining, PAS-positive intranuclear inclusions within plasma cells containing Ig, which are more common in IgA myeloma (Image below). 

Russell bodies - They are globular intracellular accumulations of immunoglobulins (Ig). Russell bodies are distended endoplasmic reticulum. Plasma cells filled with multiple Russell bodies are called Mott cells.

  • Flame cells - Plasma cells with fiery red cytoplasm due to vermillion-staining, glycogen-rich IgA in cytoplasmic projections

questions.text: Therapy with sorafenib would be best suited for patients with
questions.solution:
Sorafenib is used in the advanced stages of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

HCC is the most common cause of primary liver cancer. It is more commonly seen in males and the peak age group is between 65-70 years. The main risk factor for HCC is cirrhosis and associated chronic liver damage due to chronic infection by hepatitis B or C virus (HBV or HCV) infection, alcohol abuse, metabolic syndrome, or hemochromatosis.

The incidence of HCC is increasing worldwide. This is contributed by the increase in HCV and HBV infections, along with lifestyle disorders like obesity. Obesity is associated with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). This progresses on to non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) causing cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma. Thus, NASH and NAFLD are risk factors for HCC.

Barcelona-Clinic-Liver Cancer (BCLC) Classification is the commonly used staging system. It stages the tumors as follows:

  • Very early HCC - Single, well-differentiated tumor <2cm 
  • Early HCC - Single tumor or a maximum of 3 nodules <3cm in diameter 
  • Intermediate HCC - Any other size or number confined to the liver 
  • Advanced HCC - Presence of cancer-related symptoms or tumors with macrovascular invasion (of any type, including branch, hepatic, or portal vein), lymph node involvement, or extrahepatic spread
  • End-stage disease - Severe liver dysfunction with impaired quality of life 

Treatment 

Very early HCC is treated by ablation. Early HCC with a single nodule is resected but when there are multiple nodules over 3 cm, ablation or transplantation are considered. Intermediate-stage HCC is treated by chemoembolization. TACE (Transarterial chemoembolization) is used for multinodular lesions.  

Advanced stages of the disease with macrovascular invasion are treated with systemic therapies. Lenvatinib and sorafenib are first-line drugs. Supportive care is given at the terminal stage of the disease.

Related Pearl: Liver tumors - commons

  • Most common tumor overall: Metastatic tumor
  • Most common primary benign tumor: Cavernous hemangioma
  • Most common primary malignant tumor: Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Most common primary malignant liver tumor of early childhood: Hepatoblastoma
  • Most common tumor associated with arsenic / vinyl chloride: Angiosarcoma
  • Most common tumor associated with oral contraceptive / anabolic steroid: Hepatic adenoma
  • Most common tumor rupture spontaneously causing hemoperitoneum: Hepatic adenoma

questions.text: What vaccination schedule would you advise for a 62-year-old diabetic man who seeks advice regarding vaccination against shingles?
questions.solution:
Zoster vaccine is given in two doses, administered intramuscularly 2 to 6 months apart.

Vaccination against shingles is recommended routinely for people aged 50 years and above. Zoster vaccine is an inactivated adjuvant subunit vaccine and is indicated for the prevention of herpes zoster (shingles) in individuals 50 years of age and older and in people aged 18 years and above with a risk of herpes zooster due to immunodeficiency and immunosuppression.


Limitations of vaccination:

  • It is not indicated for the treatment of zoster or post-herpetic neuralgia (PHN).
  • It is not indicated for the prevention of primary varicella infection (chickenpox).

It is not contraindicated in immunosuppressed and immunodeficient individuals.

Contraindications:

  • History of severe allergic reaction.
  • Acute episode of herpes zooster.

questions.text: A patient presented with a painless, well-circumscribed swelling near the wrist joint. There are no skin changes. Histopathological examination of the swelling revealed the following under low power (image above) and high power (image below), respectively. What are the correct descriptions of the 3 zones?

choices.text: 1 - Antoni B area, 2 - Antoni A area, 3 - Verocay Bodies
1 - Antoni A area, 2 - Antoni B area, 3 - Verocay Bodies
1 - Antoni A area, 2 - Verocay Bodies, 3 - Antoni B area
1 - Verocay Bodies, 2 - Antoni A area, 3 - Antoni B area

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a painless, well-circumscribed swelling near the wrist joint, along with the histological image showing Anoni A & B areas and Verocay bodies is indicative of a schwannoma. The correct match is 1 - Antoni B area, 2 - Antoni A area, 3 - Verocay Bodies.

Schwannomas are benign tumors that may arise directly from peripheral nerves and exhibit Schwann cell differentiation. They are commonly associated with mutations in the NF2 gene on chromosome 22. This results in the loss of expression of Merlin, the NF2 gene product. Schwannomas are simple to excise surgically as they are well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses that are loosely attached to the associated nerve but do not invade it. Grossly, they appear as firm gray masses. 

Microscopically, it consists of dense areas called Antoni A area, and loose areas called Antoni B area.

  • The dense eosinophilic Antoni A areas contain spindle cells that are arranged into cellular intersecting fascicles. Palisading of nuclei is seen, with the nuclear-free zones between them, called Verocay bodies.
  • The Antoni B areas contain spindle-shaped cells that are loosely arranged and separated by prominent myxoid extracellular matrix.

 

The symptoms associated with schwannoma arise due to local compression of the involved nerve or adjacent structures. The condition that is referred to as acoustic neuroma is, in fact, a schwannoma. If incompletely excised, the schwannomas can recur locally, but a malignant transformation is extremely rare.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is least consistent with a diagnosis of skull base fracture?
questions.solution:
Griesinger's sign is least consistent with a diagnosis of skull base fracture. Griesinger sign refers to edema of the postauricular soft tissues overlying the mastoid process as a result of thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein. It is considered a pathognomonic sign of dural sinus occlusive disease.

Signs in basilar skull fractures:

  • Hemotympanum: Pooling of blood behind the tympanic membrane, associated with fracture of the temporal bone. It is one of the earliest signs of basilar fracture.
  • Periorbital ecchymosis (raccoon eyes): Pooling of blood surrounding the eyes, associated with fractures of the anterior cranial fossa. 
  • Retroauricular or mastoid ecchymosis (Battle sign): Pooled blood behind the ears in the mastoid region is associated with fractures to the middle cranial fossa. 
  • CSF rhinorrhea or otorrhea: Double target sign, a double-ring pattern described with CSF-containing bloody fluid from the ear or nose, when dripped onto paper or linen.

Battle sign and raccoon eyes are both typically not present during the initial evaluation and are delayed by 6 hrs up to 3 days after head injury.

CSF leaks may be delayed hours to days after the initial trauma. Fluid suspicious for CSF is confirmed by testing for β2 transferrin. Most CSF leaks are conservatively managed. Persistent leaks >7 days have a heightened risk of meningitis and are often surgically repaired.

Nasopharyngeal airways and nasogastric tube insertion are relatively contraindicated in basilar skull fractures due to the risk for intracranial placement. NIPPV is avoided due to the risk of pneumocephalus. 

The image below shows the 'battle' sign.

 

The image below shows 'racoon' eyes.

Double target sign is seen patients with CSF rhinorrhea. The nasal discharge in a patient with CSF rhinorrhea after head trauma is mixed with blood. When this discharge is collected on a filter paper, it shows a double target sign with a central red spot and a peripheral lighter halo as seen in the image below. 

Related Pearl: Signs of base of skull fracture

Signs of Base of Skull Fracture

  • Bilateral periorbital haematoma (raccoon eyes)
  • Battle’s sign (bruising over mastoid)
  • CSF rhinorrhoea or otorrhoea
  • Haemotympanum or bleeding from ear

questions.text: Which of the following depicts the combination that would form Ceramide?
questions.solution:
Ceramide consists of sphingosine and a fatty acid.

Ceramide can be a component of a phospholipid, but it itself is not a phospholipid. Ceramide is present as a component of:

  •  The phospholipid, sphingomyelin (Sphingomyelin = ceramide + phosphoric acid + choline).
  •  And non-phosphorylated compound lipids like cerebrosides, globosides, and gangliosides (fatty acids esterified with alcohol + contain other groups).

Compound lipids are subclassified based on extra groups as:

  1. Phospholipids (containing phosphoric acid) - Ex: plasmalogens, dipalmitoyl lecithin, cardiolipin, sphingomyelin etc
  2. Non-phosphorylated lipids - Ex: cerebrosides, globosides, gangliosides, sulpholipids etc

 

Related Pearl: Types of Phospholipids

Phosphatidylethanolamine or cephalin

Phosphatidylinositol

Phosphatidylserine

Plasmalogens

Cardiolipin

Sphingomyeline

questions.text: All of the following diseases are transmitted by the vector shown in the image, except
questions.solution:
The image shows a Culex mosquito. It is identified by its unspotted wings and hunched back. The Culex mosquitoes are vectors or carriers for Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, and viral arthritis. 

Yellow fever is transmitted by Aedes mosquitos.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia

Eggs: 100-250. 

 Laid singly. Boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star-shaped clusters.

Larval stage

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to the undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Striped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artificial collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis, Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 

Called Nuisance mosquitoes

These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called tiger mosquitoes

Day biters

They get the tiger's name from the white stripes on its legs.

 Big, black, or brown mosquitoes with sparkling wings and legs. 

 

 

Culex mosquito keeps their bodies horizontal while feeding.

 Anopheles mosquito tends to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high.

Aedes mosquito has a striped body pattern.

questions.text: In an adult weighing 70 kg, how much fluid should be given for second-degree burns of 50%, sustained during a fire accident?

choices.text: 4.5 liters in first 12 hours, followed by 4.5 liters over the next 24 hours
4.5 liters in first 8 hours, followed by 4.5 liters over the next 16 hours
3.5 liters in first 8 hours, followed by 3.5 liters over the next 16 hours
3.5 liters in first 12 hours, followed by 3.5 liters over the next 24 hours

questions.solution:
3.5 liters in first 8 hours, followed by 3.5 liters over the next 16 hours

Formula for calculating fluid requirement: Percentage of burn x weight (kg) x 2 = volume in mL

So, substituting the values,

50 (percentage of burn) x 70 (weight in kg) x 2 = 7000 (volume in mL)

Volume in liters = 7

Half of the fluid is given in the first 8 hours, and the other half is given in the next 16 hours. So, for the first 8 hours, 3.5 litres should be administered, followed by another 3.5 liters over the next 16 hours.

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

Category of burn Age Amount of Ringer’s Lactate given for 24 hours (ml) Target urine output (ml/kg/hour)
2nd/3rd-degree burns Adults  2 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 0.5
<14 years 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1
< 1 year or <30kgs 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA + 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate 1
4th-degree burns / Electrical burns All ages 4 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1-1.5 (until urine clears)

Dextrose maintenance:

  • 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg
  • 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

  • Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

Muir and Barclay’s formula for colloids:

  • 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2
  • 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text: All of the following findings in a patient would suggest a lesion of the representational hemisphere except:
questions.solution:
Acalculia is an impairment of mathematical ability and occurs due to an impairment of the left frontal lobe, the categorical hemisphere.

In our human body, one hemisphere is specialized for sequential-analytic processes (the categorical hemisphere or dominant hemisphere) and another is specialized for visuospatial relations (the representational hemisphere or the non-dominant hemisphere).

Lesions in the representational hemisphere lead to:

  1. Astereognosis—the inability to identify objects by feeling them
  2. Agnosia- inability to recognize objects by a particular sensory modality even though the sensory modality itself is intact. This commonly occurs due to a lesion in the parietal lobe. Prosopagnosia is the inability to recognize faces.
  3. Unilateral inattention and neglect- Patients neglect one-half of their body. It occurs due to an injury to the inferior parietal lobule.

Lesions in the categorical hemisphere lead to

  1. Broca's aphasia is caused due to an injury in the inferior frontal gyrus. It causes nonfluent aphasia. Affected individuals have slow speech and difficulty in generating verbal or written words.
  2. Wernicke's aphasia is caused due to a lesion in the posterior end of the superior temporal gyrus. It produces a type of fluent aphasia in which speech itself is normal but it is full of jargon and neologisms that make little sense. The patient also fails to comprehend the meaning of spoken or written words, so other aspects of the use of language are compromised.
  3. Anomic aphasia- When a lesion damages the angular gyrus in the categorical hemisphere without affecting Wernicke or Broca areas, there is no difficulty with speech or the understanding of auditory information. But there is trouble understanding written language or pictures because visual information is not processed and transmitted to the Wernicke area.
  4. Global aphasia- In this, both understanding and speaking is impaired. It is also non-fluent aphasia.
  5. Acalculia- Impairment of mathematical ability. Occurs due to an impairment to the left frontal lobe.

There are two parietal lobes - the dominant side and the non-dominant side.

  • The functions of the dominant side of the parietal lobe are calculation, language, planned movement, appreciation of size, shape, weight, and texture. A lesion here causes dyscalculia, dysphasia, dyslexia, apraxia, agnosia, homonymous hemianopia.
  • The function of the non-dominant side is spatial orientation and constructional skills. Its lesion causes spatial disorientation, constructional apraxia, neglect of the non-dominant side, dressing apraxia, and homonymous hemianopia. 

The somatic sensory area and related parts of the posterior parietal lobe project to the premotor cortex. Some of these neurons are concerned with aiming and manipulating the hands at an object, whereas other neurons are concerned with hand-eye coordination. Neurons in this posterior parietal cortex contribute to the descending pathways involved in motor control.

Related Pearl: Aphasias and Related Conditions

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about Cobalt-60?

choices.text: It is used for gamma knife surgery
It is used in high dose-rate brachytherapy

questions.solution:
Cobalt 60 emits beta particles and gamma radiation. It doesn't emit alpha particles

Cobalt 60 is a radioactive metal commonly used in medical radiation therapy. Its mode of decay is via beta particles and gamma radiation. The half-life of cobalt-60 is 5.27 years.

Cobalt-60 isotope has traditionally been popular for teletherapy, although this use is decreasing. It has also been used in gamma knife surgeries. A newer use of the Cobalt 60 isotope has been in the field of high dose-rate brachytherapy.

questions.text: All of the following groups of drugs should be avoided in a diabetic patient on captopril to avoid hyperkalemia, except _______.
questions.solution:
All of the following groups of drugs should be avoided in a diabetic patient on captopril to avoid hyperkalemia, except calcium channel blockers.

Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors like captopril may cause hyperkalemia when taken along with K+-sparing diuretics and beta-receptor blockers (option A), especially in diabetics. Calcium channel blockers are not associated with the development of any clinically significant hypo- or hyperkalemia. Hence, they are used as fixed-dose combinations as well.

Hyperkalemia occurs due to the inhibition of angiotensin II-mediated aldosterone secretion. Decreased aldosterone levels result in decreased tubular excretion of potassium in the kidneys, leading to hyperkalemia.

Other common adverse effects of ACE inhibitors include:

  • Hypotension
  • Cough
  • Angioedema
  • Teratogenicity
  • Dysgeusia (alteration in or loss of taste)

Other options

Option C: The most critical adverse effect of renal sodium channel inhibitors, such as amiloride and triamterene, is hyperkalemia. Triamterene may exacerbate megaloblastosis in cirrhotic patients due to its weak folic acid antagonism. It can also reduce glucose tolerance, induce photosensitization, and is linked to interstitial nephritis and renal stones. Common side effects of amiloride include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and headache, while triamterene is more frequently associated with nausea, vomiting, leg cramps, and dizziness.

Option D: The principal risk of aldosterone antagonists, such as eplerenone and finerenone, is hyperkalemia. They can cause metabolic acidosis in cirrhotic patients. Spironolactone is associated with side effects such as gynecomastia, impotence, and gastrointestinal issues like gastric bleeding, and peptic ulcers.

questions.text: A patient who has had a good recovery following head injury, without any disability  should be assigned a Glasgow Outcome Score of _____.
questions.solution:
A patient who has had a good recovery following head injury, without any disability, should be assigned a Glasgow Outcome Score of 5.

The Glasgow Outcome Scale (GOS) is different from the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), and it is used to quantify the degree of recovery achieved after a head injury, especially for research purposes.

The scoring system is as follows:

Patient condition Score
Good recovery 5
Moderate disability 4
Severe disability 3
Persistent vegetative state 2
Dead 1

 

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: Following a Schiller test, you would biopsy the regions that are________.
questions.solution:
The abnormal cells remain unstained on performing Schiller's test. Hence, the unstained region should be biopsied. 

Schiller's test, also known as visual inspection with Lugol's iodine (VILI), involves painting the vagina with Lugol's iodine. It is used to detect any abnormal cytology in the vaginal epithelium. 

The normal vaginal and cervical epithelium contains glycogen and, therefore, it stains mahogany brown on being painted with Lugol's iodine. The abnormal cells remain unstained. These areas need to be biopsied and sent for histopathological examination.

questions.text:
If you fail to attend in obedience to a summon from the court, you would be liable to punishment under:

IPC- Indian Penal Code
questions.solution:
Non-attendance in obedience to a summons from the court is punishable with imprisonment of 6 months as per section 174 of IPC.

The punishment for IPC 174 is Simple Imprisonment for 1 Month or Fine or Both. It is non-cognizable and available offence.

Section 175 of IPC: Omission to produce document(s) to public servant by person legally bound to produce it. Punishable with six months imprisonment.

Section 176 of IPC: Omission to give notice or information to public servant by person legally bound to give it (imprisonment up to one month).

Section 177 of IPC: Furnishing false information is punishable with imprisonment of up to six months.

 

Section 172 of IPC: Absconding to avoid service of summons or other proceedings

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with painful lesions that appear as in the image below. What is the nature of the virus responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image showing confluent, red, pustular lesions in a single dermatome along with a crawling sensation, is highly suggestive of Herpes zoster infection. The causative agent, the varicella-zoster virus, is a double-stranded DNA virus. 

Initial infection with the virus causes chickenpox, associated with disseminated vesicular rash and fever. Upon resolution of the acute infection, the virus remains latent in a cranial nerve or dorsal root ganglia. Herpes zoster infection or shingles is a segmental eruption due to the reactivation of latent varicella-zoster virus from the dorsal root ganglia. An earlier infection with varicella is essential before zoster can occur. 

The first symptom of zoster is usually pain. It may also be accompanied by fever, headache, malaise, and tenderness localized to areas of one or more dorsal roots. The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and the nasopharynx. The thoracic dermatomes are most commonly affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.

Zoster is a self‐limiting infection, but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post‐herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is caused by the same type of hypersensitivity reaction as that involved in the Arthus reaction?
questions.solution:
Arthus reaction is characterized by a localized area of tissue necrosis due to immune-complex/type III hypersensitivity reaction–mediated vasculitis in the skin. Serum sickness is also due to type III hypersensitivity reaction.

This reaction can be produced experimentally by intracutaneous injection of antigen in a previously immunized animal that has circulating antibodies against the antigen. As the antigen diffuses into the vessel wall, it binds with the preformed antibody, and immune complexes are formed locally. These complexes precipitate in the vessel walls and cause fibrinoid necrosis.

Vascular dilatation, edema, smooth muscle contraction, mucus production, tissue injury, inflammation

(type II)

Production of IgG, IgM → binds to antigen on target cell or tissue → phagocytosis or lysis of target cell by activated complement or Fc receptors; recruitment of leukocytes

Phagocytosis and lysis of cells; inflammation;

(type III)

  • Arthus reaction

Deposition of antigen-antibody complexes → complement activation →recruitment of leukocytes by complement products and Fc receptors → release of enzymes and other toxic molecules

questions.text: On performing a per-vaginal examination of a woman about to deliver, mouth with hard alveolar margins, nose, malar eminence, and supraorbital ridges were palpable. This presentation is caused due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
The given features indicate face presentation. It is most likely to be caused due to an abnormal attitude of the fetus.

The relation of the different parts of the fetus to one another is called the attitude of the fetus. The universal attitude in a normal vertex presentation is that of flexion. Abnormal presentations such as brow or face may result due to deviation from this attitude of flexion.

Definitions of various terminologies used for the fetus in utero:

  • Lie: Relationship of the long axis of the fetus to the long axis of the maternal spine
  • Presentation: Part of the fetus occupying the lower pole of the pelvis
  • Presenting part: Part of the presentation that overlies the internal os
  • Attitude: The relation of the different parts of the fetus to one another
  • Position: Relation of the denominator to the different quadrants of the pelvis
Presentation Denominator
Breech Sacrum
Vertex Occiput
Face Mentum (chin)
Brow Frontal eminence
Shoulder Acromion

questions.text:
Match the following characteristic X-Ray appearances with their corresponding conditions.
  1. Large Bowel Obstruction
  2. Jejunal Obstruction
  3. Sigmoid Volvulus
  4. Caecal Volvulus
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-D, 2-C, 3-B, 4-A.

 In small bowel obstructions like jejunal obstruction, the obstructed bowel loops are central in location and lie transversely. The jejunal obstruction shows valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel). It gives it a ladder effect. The distended cecum may show the presence of gas shadow in the right iliac fossa.

In large bowel obstruction, the presence of haustrations is a feature. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. The given image shows haustrations in large bowel obstruction

On X-ray abdomen, the apex of the cecal volvulus points towards the left upper quadrant vs the apex pointing towards the right upper quadrant in sigmoid volvulus.

Other radiological findings in caecal volvulus include caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level, and absence of gas in the distal colon. CECT abdomen is the investigation of choice that shows a whirl sign (also seen in the midgut volvulus).

Sigmoid volvulus occurs when the sigmoid colon twists on the sigmoid mesocolon. X-ray abdomen shows a large, dilated loop of the colon, often with a few air-fluid levels. Specific signs include the coffee bean sign (seen below) and the absence of rectal gas. On X-ray abdomen, the apex of the sigmoid volvulus points towards the right upper quadrant.

questions.text: Anaphylactic transfusion reaction following the transfusion of blood products is most likely to occur in individuals with a deficiency of
questions.solution:
An anaphylactic transfusion reaction is most likely to occur in individuals with a deficiency of IgA

 IgA deficiency occurs with a frequency of 1:300 to 1:500 people.  IgG antibodies that recognize IgA in the infused blood product trigger the reaction. Fortunately, as most patients with IgA deficiency do not develop such antibodies, these severe reactions are rare.

Mild fever, hemolytic anemia

Coomb’s test positive

Additional transfusions if needed

Non-immune mediated transfusion reactions are as follows:

  • Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO)
  • Hypothermia
  • Electrolyte abnormality- hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia
  • Iron overload
  • Transient hypotension
  • Immunomodulation
  • Blood-borne infections

questions.text: During the examination of a gunshot victim, the skin around the entry wound shows marks from the grease, soot, and debris from the barrel of the gun. What is this referred to as?
questions.solution:
The skin around the entry wound showing marks from the grease, soot, and debris from the barrel of the gun is referred to as grease collar/ dirt collar/ bullet wipe.

While examining the clothing of a victim of a bullet injury, there is a deposition of various residues surrounding the entrance defect at various ranges, known as Bullet wipe. It helps in determining the wounds of inlet and outlet upon the body.

Bullet graze/ Bullet slap: the bullet just hits the skin only at an angle and goes off from the site, without any penetration or wound of entry. It produces an abrasion or a laceration depending on the thickness of the skin involved.

Bullet bruise: the bullet here just hits the skin only and drops down to the ground, without any penetration or wound of entry. It produces a bruise alone at the site of impact.

Fouling: refers to tiny lesions surrounding the entry wound which are caused by fragments of metal that are expelled by the discharge wither from the surface of the missile itself or from the interior of the barrel. A black ring around the bullet hole is seen in infrared photography.

Related Pearl: Difference between Wound of Entry and Exit

Characteristics

Wound of entry

Wound of exit

Size

Smaller than the diameter of the bullet.

In close discharge, skin is torn, hence size is increased.

Bigger than the diameter of the bullet.

Margin

Inverted

Everted

Soiling of wound

+ve

-ve

Abrasion collar

+ve

-ve

+ve

-ve

+ve

-ve

Bleeding

Less

More
