+ve

-ve

Dispersion of pallets (shotgun)

+ve

-ve

Protrusion of fat

-ve

+ve

Bright red (Carboxy Hb)

+ve (Near shot)

-ve

X-ray Metallic Ring

+ve

-ve

Muzzle impression

+ve (contact shot)

-ve

Blast effect

+ve (contact shot)

-ve

 

Related Pearl: Types of bullets:

1. Ricochet bullet: Bullet first strikes an intermediate object and then after being reflected strikes the target. It produces a key hole entry wound .

2. Yawning bullet: Travels in an irregular fashion.

3. Tandem (Piggy Back) Bullet Effect: Two bullets are ejected one after the other; first bullet failed to leave the barrel and is ejected by subsequently fired bullet. This occurs due to defect in the weapon or due to faulty ammunition or with loaded firearms unused for several years. Tandem cartridge (also called duplex cartridge) is a single cartridge containing two bullets. 

 

4. Frangible bullet: Fragments on hitting the target.

5. Dum Dum bullet: Tip is chiseled out, fragments extensively on impact.

6. Tumbling bullet:  Rotates end on end during its motion. This produces an atypical entry wound .  

7. Souvenir bullet:  Bullet left in the body for a long time and covered with dense fibrous connective tissue.

8. Tracer bullet: This type of bullet leaves a visible mark or trace while in flight so that the gunner can observe the strike of shot. Rear portion of bullet is filled with mixture of barium nitrate, strontium nitrate and powdered magnesium which is ignited by the burning powder. Mixture burns and sheds red sparks which makes the projectile visible to naked eye which enables shooter to make aiming corrections.

9. Incendiary bullet: It is filled with white phosphorous and ignites the target.

From left to right : Blank with frangible wooden bullet, ball, tracer and incendiary bullets

questions.text: Which of the following glycogen storage disorders does not involve the muscle?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, von Gierke's disease does not have muscle involvement.

von Gierke's disease is caused by the absence or deficiency of the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase in the liver, kidney, and intestinal mucosa. The clinical manifestations include:

  • Seizures
  • Doll-like facies (fat cheeks and relatively thin extremities)
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Growth retardation
  • Hypoglycemia 
  • Elevated blood uric acid levels 
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Elevated cholesterol and triglycerides
  • Neutropenia (specific to type Ib)

The management of the condition involves the maintenance of blood glucose levels by infusion of glucose or the use of uncooked cornstarch. Restriction of lactose, fructose, and sucrose is recommended. Supplementation and adequate intake of vitamins and minerals are ensured. Allopurinol is indicated for hyperuricemia if uncontrolled on dietary therapy.

Other options:

Option A: Pompe's disease is characterized by hypotonia (floppy infant), skeletal muscle weakness, hepatomegaly, cardiomyopathy, macroglossia, and cardiomegaly on chest X-ray. It occurs due to α-1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase) deficiency.

Option B: Andersen's disease is characterized by growth delay, hepatomegaly, and myopathy. There may be fasting intolerance and ketosis in the initial stages. Hypoglycemia usually appears late in the disease. It occurs due to a deficiency of glycogen branching enzyme.

Option C: McArdle's disease presents during late childhood or in the second decade of life. It is characterized by exercise intolerance associated with muscle cramps. Myoglobinuria secondary to rhabdomyolysis leads to the passage of burgundy-colored urine in some patients. It occurs due to a deficiency of muscle glycogen phosphorylase enzyme.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked by the red arrow in the given image?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the musculocutaneous nerve. 

The structure can be identified as the musculocutaneous nerve as it pierces the coracobrachialis muscle in its course and also supplies the biceps brachii. The root value of the musculocutaneous nerve is C5, C6, C7.

The musculocutaneous nerve supplies all the muscles of the anterior compartment of the arm, which include coracobrachialis, brachialis, and biceps brachii muscles.

  • Covered by prevertebral fascia extension called "axillary sheath"

  • Upper trunk: C5 and C6
  • Middle trunk: C7.
  • Lower trunk: C8 and T1

  • Anterior divisions - Forms lateral and medial cords supplying mainly flexors 
  • Posterior divisions - Forms posterior cord which suppy mainly extensors

  • Lateral cord: Formed by anterior divisions of the upper and middle trunks.
  • Posterior cord: Formed by all 3 posterior divisions 
  • Medial cord: Formed by anterior division of the lower trunk.

questions.text: Calcium disodium Ethylenediaminetetraacetic Acid is best suited for the management of:
questions.solution:
CaNa2EDTA (Calcium disodium Ethylenediaminetetraacetic Acid) is best suited for the management of acute lead poisoning.

It is not suitable for the management of chronic lead poisoning. In fact, IV administration can increase intracranial pressure in patients with lead encephalopathy and cerebral edema. The calcium salt of EDTA can be used in the management of heavy metal poisonings where the metal in question has a higher affinity for EDTA than calcium in vivo. Because of their lower affinity to EDTA, mercury and arsenic cannot be effectively chelated. 

As CaNa2EDTA mobilizes endogenous metallic cations like zinc, manganese, and iron, patients are to be prescribed a zinc supplementation course following therapy with EDTA. 

 

Related Pearl: Lead Poisoning/Plumbism/Saturnism

questions.text:
Which of the following medications may result in pill-induced esophagitis?
  1. Doxycycline
  2. Phenytoin
  3. Potassium chloride
  4. Ferrous sulfate
  5. Bisphosphonates
questions.solution:
All of the listed drugs may result in pill-induced esophagitis.

Pill-induced esophagitis is caused when the pill lodges within the lumen of the esophagus. This pill causes direct damage to the mucosa. The risk factors for pill-induced esophagitis include poor pill-taking habits, consuming inadequate liquids, and lying down immediately after consuming the pill. The most common site for pill-induced esophagitis is in the mid-esophagus, near the crossing of the aorta or carina. These structures externally compress the esophagus and prevent the movement of the pills.

Drugs causing esophagitis: 

  • Doxycycline
  • Tetracycline
  • Quinidine
  • Potassium chloride
  • Ferrous sulfate
  • Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
  • Bisphosphonates
  • Phenytoin

questions.text: Apneusis would occur in

choices.text: Complete transection above pons with cut vagi
Complete transection above pons with intact vagi
Mid pontine level lesion with intact vagi
Mid pontine level lesion with cut vagi

questions.solution:
Apneusis is seen in mid pontine level lesions with cut vagi.

At mid pontine level, the apneustic centre is intact while the pneumotaxic centre is separated. Concurrent removal of vagus inputs causes this kind of abnormal pattern of breathing characterized by deep, gasping inspiration with a pause at full inspiration followed by a brief insufficient release.

Regular breathing continues

Transection midway between pons and medulla

Irregular but rhythmic respiration

Irregular but rhythmic respiration

D

Complete transection below medulla

Spontaneous respiration ceases

Spontaneous respiration ceases

questions.text: In which stage of the demographic cycle will the demographic gap be negative?
questions.solution:
The demographic gap becomes negative in the declining phase of the demographic cycle. 

Demographic gap is the difference between the birth and the death rate.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

Stages of the demographic cycle include:

  • Stage 1 - High stationary 
    • High birth rates and high death rates render the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 2 - Early expanding 
    • The death rate declines and the birth rate remains unchanged
    • The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum
  • Stage 3 - Late expanding
    • Death rate declines further and birth rate falls
    • India is in this stage, currently
    • The demographic gap starts declining
  • Stage 4 - Low stationary 
    • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 5 - Declining 
    • The population begins to decline as the birth rate is lower than the death rate
    • The demographic gap is negative

questions.text: Cervical cancer that has both bladder and bowel involvement but no other distant metastases should be staged as ____.
questions.solution:
Cervical cancer that has both bladder and bowel involvement but no other distant metastases should be staged as Stage IV A.

Related Pearl: Staging of Carcinoma Cervix

Stage I - limited to the cervix

  • A: Microscopic lesion
    • A1 - stromal invasion <3mm depth
    • A2 - a stromal invasion of ≥3 and <5mm depth
  • B: Macroscopic lesion
    • B1 - stromal invasion ≥5mm depth & tumor size <2cm 
    • B2 - tumor size ≥2cm to <4cm 
    • B3 - tumor size ≥4cm 

Stage II - involves upper 2/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement
    • A1 - tumor size <4cm 
    • A2 - tumor size ≥4cm 
  • B: Extends to parametrium but not upto the pelvic wall.

Stage III - spreads to lower 1/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to lower 1/3 of the vagina
  • B: Extends to the pelvic wall (hydronephrosis/non-functioning kidney)
  • C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent
    • C1: pelvic lymph node involved
    • C2: para-aortic lymph node involved

Stage IV - metastasis

  • A: Bladder/bowel involvement (adjacent pelvic organs)
  • B: Distant metastasis

Note: The involvement of vascular/lymphatic spaces does not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

Stage IIIB is the most common stage of presentation.

questions.text: Which of the following forms of angiotensin is physiologically inactive?
questions.solution:
Angiotensin I is physiologically inactive.

The physiologically inactive decapeptide angiotensin I is converted to the pressor, aldosterone-stimulating octapeptide angiotensin II in the pulmonary circulation. The reaction occurs in other tissues as well, but it is particularly prominent in the lungs. Large amounts of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) responsible for this activation are located on the surface of endothelial cells in the pulmonary capillaries.

Angiotensin II metabolism leads to the production of angiotensin III and IV, which are also found to have physiological activity.

questions.text: Which of the following would be useful to demonstrate the Pulfrich phenomenon in a patient?

choices.text: Increasing the core body temperature by exercise

questions.solution:
Altered depth perception, especially for moving objects, is known as the Pulfrich phenomenon. An oscillating pendulum is best suited for demonstrating this phenomenon.

When a small target is oscillated to and fro within the plane facing the patient, he perceives it as moving in an elliptical path. This phenomenon is an indication of nerve dysfunction. It is seen in optic neuritis because there is a delay in visual information reaching the cortex via the affected optic nerve, which results in altered depth perception.

Passive neck flexion is useful for demonstrating Lhermitte’s sign. Here, passive neck flexion causes an electric shock-like sensation radiating to the spine and shoulders. This is a result of the increased sensitivity of the myelin to stretch or traction; it is also seen in MS.

An increase in core body temperature is useful for demonstrating the Uhthoff phenomenon. Episodic, transient obscuration of vision on exertion or on exposure to heat, which recovers on resting or moving away from the heat, in an isolated optic neuritis patient, is called Uhthoff phenomenon. It is commonly associated with multiple sclerosis (MS).

questions.text: A terrorist gets exposed to radiation after setting off his dirty bomb accidentally and ends up developing radiation sickness. What is this injury classified as?
questions.solution:
Radiation sickness is classified as quinary blast injury.

A dirty bomb uses conventional explosives to spread radioactive material across a wide area with potentially devastating results.

  • Inhalation injury

additions
  • Radiation sickness
  • Infection

questions.text: Which of the following is not an S-phase inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Vincristine is a vinca alkaloid that acts during the M phase of the cell cycle 

It causes microtubule disruptions, thereby preventing cellular replication.

Vincristine prevents the polymerization of the microtubular protein tubulin, causing metaphase arrest. It is very useful for inducing remission in childhood acute lymphoblastic leukaemia. Prominent adverse effects are peripheral neuropathy and reversible alopecia. It also causes ataxia, nerve palsies, autonomic dysfunction and seizures.

questions.text: In which of the following neonates, would HFNC be suitable?

choices.text: Neonate with recurrent spells of apnea
Preterm neonate needing weaning from CPAP

questions.solution:
Heated humidified High-Flow Nasal Cannula (HFNC) is indicated for weaning from CPAP in preterm neonates.

HFNC entails the administration of oxygen or blended oxygen and air to neonates via nasal cannula, at flows greater than 1 L/min. HFNC has gained popularity because of its ease of use, less nasal trauma, better tolerance, and most importantly, better access to caregiving. The best way to wean from CPAP is to take the neonate off CPAP and reinstate the therapy if indicated. But, HFNC can be used as an interim bridge to transition to room air. 

Contraindications for HFNC are:

  • Severe RDS
  • Recurrent apnea
  • Pneumothorax
  • Cranial and airway anomalies

Indications of HFNC include:

  • Alternative to CPAP for post-extubation support in preterm neonates
  • Alternative to CPAP in stable preterm neonates who are at risk of, or have established nasal trauma
  • Weaning from CPAP in preterm neonates.

questions.text:
Arrange the following muscarinic agonists in the ascending order of their duration of cycloplegic action.
  1. Atropine
  2. Cyclopentolate
  3. Tropicamide
  4. Scopolamine
questions.solution:
The respective durations of action of the muscarinic agents are:

  • Tropicamide - 6 hours
  • Cyclopentolate - ~24 hours
  • Scopolamine - Several days
  • Atropine - >1 week

 

Atropine is available as 1% solution & 1% ointment. It can be used for cycloplegia, mydriasis, cycloplegic retinoscopy, dilated funduscopic exam, and in iritis & uveitis. Known adverse effects include photosensitivity and blurred vision, which may last for more than a week. 

Tropicamide is available as 0.5% and 1% solutions. It can be used to produce cycloplegia & mydriasis. Though side effects are the same as that of atropine, they last only for a few hours and hence tropicamide is commonly used for OPD examination.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is likely to have the largest volume of distribution?

choices.text: Drug A- large molecular weight and extensively bound to albumin
Drug B- large and lipid-insoluble molecule
Drug C- small lipophilic molecule with a tendency for sequestration in adipocytes

questions.solution:
Among the given options, Drug C, which is a small lipophilic molecule with a tendency for sequestration in adipocytes, will have the highest volume of distribution.

The difference in the volume of distribution based on drug type:

  • Low Vd 
    • Restricted to the intravascular compartment 
    • Seen in drugs with high molecular weight (e.g., heparin) or high protein binding (e.g., warfarin - 9.8L)
  • Medium Vd 
    • Lipid-insoluble drugs (e.g., gentamicin - 20 L) do not enter the cells and are distributed in the extracellular fluid volume.
    • Small water-soluble molecules (e.g., ethanol - 42 L) are distributed in the total body water.
  • High Vd
    • Sequestered and accumulated in the tissues
    • Small lipophilic molecules (e.g., chloroquine - 13000 L)

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the procedure for the insertion of a chest drain?

choices.text: Skin, muscle and pleura should be penetrated perpendicularly to create a tract
A drain for pneumothorax and hemothorax should aim towards the apex of the lung
A drain for pleural effusion or empyema should be nearer the base of the lung
The drain should pass over the upper edge of the rib to avoid the neurovascular bundle that lies beneath the rib

questions.solution:
Skin, muscle, and pleura should be penetrated obliquely to create a tract oblique so that the skin incision and the hole in the parietal pleura do not overlie each other. This ensures that the drain is in a short tunnel, and reduces the chance of air entering.

 

The technique of drain insertion includes the following:

  • The area should be thoroughly sterilized before the procedure.
  • Adequate local anesthesia to include the pleura.
  • Sharp dissection should be done to cut only the skin.
  • Blunt dissection with artery forceps down through the muscle layers; which involves the serratus anterior and the intercostals.
  • An oblique tract is made so that the skin incision and the hole in the parietal pleura do not overlie each other and so that the drain is in a short tunnel, which reduces the chance of entraining air.
  • A drain for pneumothorax and hemothorax should aim towards the apex of the lung.
  • A drain for pleural effusion or empyema should be nearer the base.
  • The drain should pass over the upper edge of the rib to avoid injury to the neurovascular bundle that lies beneath the rib. 
  • A vertical mattress suture is inserted for later wound closure. This is important for pneumothorax management but not required if the drain is for empyema (provided there is the adherence of the pleura) because that tract should lie open.
  •  The drain should be connected to an underwater seal device which functions as a one-way valve.
  • Do not attach to a suction device at another end because it may worsen the air leak if the lung is fragile or might even cause a shift of mediastinum if the lung doesn't expand well
  • After completion, check the position of the drain by taking a chest radiograph.

 Triangle of safety: It is a safe site through which a chest tube can be inserted. It lies:

  • anterior to the midaxillary line
  • above the level of the nipple
  • below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle

questions.text:
Match the following MRI images with their respective imaging sequence.
  1. T1-weighted MRI
  2. T2-weighted MRI
  3. Susceptibility weighted MRI
  4. FLAIR
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-C, 2-D, 3-A, 4-B.

The simple way to classify the image would be using the following rule of thumb:

Sequence White Matter Grey Matter CSF
T1 Brighter Darker Dark
T2 Darker Brighter Bright
FLAIR Darker Brighter Dark

 

T1 weighting is one of the basic MRI pulse sequences. The difference in the appearance of various tissues is due to their different T1 relaxation times. CSF has a long T1 time and appears dark. T2 weighting is also a basic MRI pulse sequence. It is based on the T2 relaxation time of the tissues. CSF appears bright in these images.

The MRI image below is a susceptibility-weighted image(SWI) as it clearly demonstrates microhemorrhages as hypointense foci.

SWI is a form of MRI sequence that is especially sensitive to substances that distort the local magnetic field. Compounds with diamagnetic, paramagnetic, and ferromagnetic properties will interact with the local magnetic field and produce distraction. This would lead to a loss of signal in these areas.

Deoxyhemoglobin, hemosiderin, and ferritin are paramagnetic. Bone minerals and dystrophic calcifications are diamagnetic in nature. The main clinical use is the identification of microhemorrhages/blood products or calcium that are not detected in other MRI sequences.

Inversion recovery sequences:

This MRI sequence is used to selectively null certain tissues. It can be:

  • Short tau inversion recovery (STIR), where fat is nulled. Fluids appear bright and fat appears dark in these images.
  • Fluid attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) or double inversion recovery (DIR), where fluid is nulled. The fluid (CSF) normally appears dark and lesions appear to be brighter in these images.

FLAIR image-

Other imaging sequences:

Proton density image:

It is based on the number of nuclei in the area that is imaged. In a PD-weighted image, tissues with a higher density of protons produce stronger signals and appear brighter. PD weighted image can be identified by comparing fluid with the fat signal. Fluids in these images appear greyish white similar or the appearance of fat in the body.

 

Gradient echo sequences(GRE): 

It uses gradient fields to generate transverse magnetization. In areas of hemorrhage, the iron that is present in the hemoglobin, produces its own local magnetic field and dephases the spinning nuclei. This is useful to identify hemorrhagic contusions in the brain and pigmented villonodular synovitis.

questions.text:
In India, any of the following should be considered as evidence of an outbreak of polio except:

WPV: Wild Polio Virus

VDPV: Vaccine Derived Polio Virus.

cVDPV: circulating Vaccine Derived Polio Virus.

choices.text: Detection of VDPV in a case of Acute Flaccid Paralysis
Detection of a single case of WPV in a person with Acute Flaccid Paralysis
Detection of any cVDPV infected individuals
Detection of WPV infection in a healthy asymptomatic individual

questions.solution:
Detection of VDPV (Vaccine Derived Paralytic Polio) in a case of Acute Flaccid Paralysis (AFP) would be categorized as a polio event, and not as a polio outbreak. 

In India, where polio is not endemic, and has been eradicated, polio outbreak is defined based on the following specific evidence of transmission:

Human Detection of:

  • any WPV-infected individual(s) manifesting either as a case of AFP or even if asymptomatic and healthy (without documented exposure to WPV in a laboratory or vaccine production facility)
  • any cVDPV-infected individual(s)

Environmental Detection of:

  • 2 or more separate environmental samples positive for WPV with genetic sequencing information indicating sustained local transmission
  • A single environmental sample positive for WPV with follow-up evidence of virus excretion (and no documented exposure in a laboratory or vaccine production facility); OR
  • Any cVDPV positive environmental sample(s)

 

Polio Events have no evidence of polio transmission and are defined as

 

Human Detection of:

  • VDPV in: - single acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) case or asymptomatic person (e.g. contact), or - one or more persons, with no evidence of further community-level circulation (iVDPV or aVDPV isolates)
  • Type 2 Sabin or Sabin-like isolate from individual sample(s) more than four months after use of any type 2 containing OPV (i.e. mOPV2 or tOPV)
  • WPV1, WPV2, or WPV3 infected individual with suspected or documented type-specific virus exposure in a laboratory or vaccine production facility.

Environmental Detection of: 

  • WPV single environmental sample without follow-up evidence of virus excretion;
  • VDPV without evidence of further transmission, such as: - a single environmental sample without evidence of prolonged circulation; or - an aVDPV.
  • Type 2 Sabin or Sabin-like isolate from environmental sample(s) more than four months after use of any type 2 containing OPV (i.e. mOPV2 or tOPV).

questions.text: The structure marked in the given image is a branch of which of the following?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the anterior interventricular artery. The anterior interventricular artery is a branch of the left coronary artery.

The left coronary artery arises from the left aortic sinus (left posterior sinus) of the ascending aorta. It passes between the pulmonary trunk and the left auricle and then runs in the coronary sulcus. It divides into its two terminal branches in the coronary sulcus:

  • Anterior interventricular branch - also called the left anterior descending artery (LAD)
    • Its branches include the left conal artery, anterior ventricular branches, anterior septal perforating branches, and left diagonal artery.
  • Circumflex branch - It gives the left marginal artery, also called the obtuse marginal artery, supplying the left ventricle.

questions.text: The given image is a dissected specimen of the posterior surface of the knee. What is the nature of the gait associated with damage to the structure marked in the image below?
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the common peroneal nerve. It is also called the common fibular nerve. Damage to it would result in a high stepping gait.

The common peroneal nerve descends down obliquely along the lateral side of the popliteal fossa, until the fibular head. It lies medial to the biceps femoris. The common peroneal nerve is a component of the sciatic nerve. In the posterior thigh, it supplies the short head of the biceps femoris. It curves around the neck of the fibula deep to the peroneus longus and divides into superficial and deep peroneal nerves.

  • The superficial peroneal nerve innervates peroneus longus and peroneus brevis, which are the evertors of the foot, and to the skin over the dorsal area of the foot, except for the first webspace and lateral side of the little toe.
  • The deep peroneal nerve innervates all muscles of the anterior compartment, which are the dorsiflexors of the foot, extensor digitorum brevis, first two dorsal interossei muscles, and skin between the great and second toes.

Common peroneal nerve is more prone to injury as it lies superficial at the level of the lateral aspect of the neck of the fibula. The clinical features of common peroneal nerve injury include the following:

  • Foot drop (image below shows a foot drop in the right calf)
  • Weakness or paralysis of ankle dorsiflexion, toe extension, and eversion
  • A diminished sensation on the dorsum of the foot including the first dorsal web space
  • Plantar flexion, inversion, and ankle reflex are preserved

Other options:

  • Cautious gait is seen in persons with spinal TB; they will walk carefully with short steps to avoid pain resulting from movement.
  • Wide-stepping gait is a broad-based unstable gait and is indicative of cerebellar dysfunction.
  • Waddling gait is seen in developmental dysplasia of the hip and in proximal muscle weakness.

Related Pearl: Sciatic nerve divisions and supply

questions.text: You should perform a shake test prior to using all of the following vaccines, except ________.
questions.solution:
Only the injectable polio vaccine (IPV) is freeze sensitive, not the oral polio vaccine (OPV). Hence, a shake test is not relevant for OPV.

The shake test is done to check for damage to vaccines that are sensitive to freezing temperatures.

Steps to perform the shake test:

  • A frozen vaccine is used as a control vial, and the vial suspected to be damaged by freezing is taken as the test vial.
  • Both are shaken after thawing, and the rate of sedimentation is compared.
  • If the rate of sedimentation in the test vial is slower than that in the control vial, then it is usable and has not been damaged.

Some of the most widely used vaccines are freeze sensitive:

  • Hep B
  • Pentavalent
  • IPV
  • DPT 
  • TT
  • PCV

Vaccines like OPV and rotavirus vaccines do not lose their potency and efficacy on freezing. Hence, these vaccines can be used again once they liquefy.

questions.text:
During your school visit as the RBSK medical officer, you are asked for suggestions by the nutrition team working under the mid-day meal scheme. Which of the following suggestions should you give?
  1. Avoid sprouted pulse usage in single-dish meals
  2. Keep the cereal pulse ratio in meals as 3:1 to 5:1
  3. Do not mix the rice water left after cooking with the dal and ensure that it is always thrown away
  4. Encourage idli, dosa, dhokla, etc preparation as fermentation improves the nutritive value
  5. Cook with the lid on to avoid loss of nutrients
questions.solution:
The correct suggestions to give would be:

  1. Use sprouted pulses in single-dish meals as they have more nutrients
  2. Keep the cereal pulse ratio in meals as 3:1 to 5:1
  3. Always mix the rice water left after cooking with the dal, if these are cooked separately, and ensure that it is never thrown away.
  4. Encourage idli, dosa, dhokla, etc preparation as fermentation improves the nutritive value
  5. Cook with the lid on to avoid loss of nutrients.

 Other relevant suggestions:

  • Unpolished/parboiled rice should be used
  • Leafy vegetables should be washed thoroughly before cutting, not after
  • Wash the grains thoroughly and soak in just a sufficient amount of water required for cooking. Avoid overcooking
  • Avoid reheating of oil used for frying as it is harmful to the body
  • Do not throw away the leafy tops of carrot, radish, turnip, etc - utilize them properly in preparing the meal.
  • Use only iodized salt for cooking the mid-day meals

Under the Mid-Day Meal (MDM) scheme, supplementary nutrition provided must cover at least ½ of the total protein requirement and 1/3 of the total energy requirement for children in schools. The MDM scheme is also called School Lunch Programme and has been operational since 1961 in India. Currently, it functions under the broad coverage of the Minimum Needs Programme.

Some other principles of the MDM are:

  • The meal provided under the MDM should only be a supplement and not a substitute to home diets.
  • The cost of the meals should be reasonably low.
  • The meal should be easy to cook in schools.
  • Locally available foods must be used, as far as possible.
  • The menu should be regularly changed to avoid monotony.

questions.text: Laryngeal spasm is the primary cause of death in which of the following types of drowning?
questions.solution:
Laryngeal spasm is the primary cause of death in cases of dry drowning. 

Dry drowning occurs when an inrush of water into the nasopharynx/larynx in a submersion victim leads to an immediate sustained laryngeal spasm, resulting in death. In this type of drowning, water does not enter the lungs. Thick mucus may form a plug.

This type of drowning is usually seen in children and adults under the influence of alcohol/sedative-hypnotics and constitutes <20% of cases of immersion. 

Wet drowning occurs when water enters the lungs of a submersion victim. The person experiences severe chest pain and death occurs within minutes.

Hydrocution occurs when cold water stimulates the nerve endings on the body, eardrum, pharynx, etc in a person who falls/dives into water.

Secondary drowning is seen in resuscitated submersion victims who survive for 24 hours. Death may occur hours after resuscitation.

The table below summarizes the cause of death in different types of drowning:

Type of drowning  Cause of death

Wet drowning/
Primary drowning

Cardiac arrest/ ventricular fibrillation

Dry drowning

 Immediate laryngeal spasm/vagal inhibition

Hydrocution/
Immersion syndrome/ Submersion inhibition

Cardiac arrest due to vagal inhibition
Secondary drowning/
Post-immersion syndrome /
Near drowning

Hypoxemia leading to electrolyte imbalance, cerebral edema, pulmonary edema, sepsis, metabolic acidosis, etc.

 

Related Pearl: Difference between freshwater and seawater drowning.

  Freshwater drowning Seawater drowning
Mechanism of death Disruption of surfactant - causes surfactant denaturation Disruption of surfactant - causes dilution of surfactant

Hypervolemia

Hyponatremia

Hyperkalemia

Hypovolemia

Hypernatremia

More (8-12 minutes)

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding intention to treat analysis?

choices.text: Data from all participants is analyzed according to the group they were allocated to, regardless of whatever happened subsequently
Data from only those participants attending complete follow-up is analyzed according to the group they were allocated to
Data from patients who received the treatment is only analyzed
Data from control arm of the trial alone is analyzed

questions.solution:
In intention to treat analysis, data from all participants is analyzed according to the group they were allocated to, regardless of whatever happened subsequently.

It is a method that helps deal with the problem of participants for whom a complete set of data cannot be obtained. Intention to treat analysis resembles the real world where not all patients take the prescribed treatments perfectly. i.e., it avoids overoptimistic estimates of the efficacy of an intervention that results from the stringent removal of non-compliers by accepting that noncompliance and protocol deviations routinely occur, similar to actual clinical practice.

questions.text: Which of the following findings would you not expect to see in a patient with ulnar nerve palsy?
questions.solution:
A positive pen test is seen in median nerve palsy. It tests the abductor pollicis brevis. The hand must remain flat with the palm facing upwards; a pen is held above the palm and the patient is asked to touch the pen with his thumb - Positive sign is the inability to touch the pen.

Tests used in ulnar nerve injuries include:

  • Wartenberg's sign - Due to weakness of the palmar interossei muscles and unopposed action of the extensor digiti minimi, there is involuntary abduction of the little finger.
  • Positive Egawa's test - Due to weakness of dorsal interossei, side-to-side movements of the middle finger is weak.
  • Positive book test or Froment's sign - Due to weakness of adductor pollicis muscle, adduction of thumb is lost. When asked to hold a book, the patient tries to hold the book by using flexor pollicis longus muscle. This produces flexion at the inter-phalangeal joint while holding the book.

 

  • Card test - Inability to hold a card between the fingers due to loss of adduction by palmar interossei muscles.

questions.text: By what age would a normal child develop a vocabulary of 8-10 words?
questions.solution:
A normal child develops a vocabulary of 8-10 words by 18 months of age.

Related Pearl: Language milestones

 
Age Milestone
1 month Alerts to sound
2 months Coos (musical vowel sound)
4 months Laughs aloud
6 months Monosyllables sounds (ma, ba)
9 months Bisyllables (mama, baba)
12 months 1-2 words with meaning
18 months 8-10 word vocabulary
2 years 2-3 word sentences (uses pronouns like I, me, you)
3 years Asks questions and knows name and gender
4 years Sings songs, poems and tells stories
5 years Asks meaning of words

Related Pearl: Important developmental milestones at various ages

Developmental milestones 

At 1 year

  • Motor: Walks with support
  • Adaptive: Mature pincer grasp
  • Language: Speaks a few words
  • Social: Plays simple ball game
  • Domestic mimicry at 18 months

At 2 years

  • Motor: Walks up and downstairs, one step at a time
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 6 blocks 
  • Language: Simple sentences, a vocabulary of 50-100 words, uses pronouns at 2.5 yrs
  • Social: Asks for food and starts toilet training, listens to stories

At 3 years

  • Motor: Rides tricycle
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 9 blocks, handedness is established
  • Language: Knows full name, age, gender
  • Social: Plays simple games and engages in parallel play with other children

At 4 years

  • Motor: Hops
  • Adaptive: Draws square and constructs a bridge with blocks
  • Language: Tells stories
  • Social: Goes to the toilet alone
 At 5 years
  • Motor: Skips
  • Adaptive: Draws a triangle
  • Language: Asks the meaning of words, names 4 colors
  • Social: Dresses and undresses

questions.text: Which of the following is a glomerulus-like structure composed of a central blood vessel enveloped by tumor cells within a space that is also lined by tumor cells?
questions.solution:
The Schiller-Duval body is a glomerulus-like structure composed of a central blood vessel enveloped by tumor cells within a space that is also lined by tumor cells.

The image below shows Schiller-Duval body, which is pathognomic of endodermal sinus tumor. 

Other options:-

Option A: Call-Exner bodies are small, distinctive, gland-like structures filled with an acidophilic material similar to immature follicles. 

The images below show Call-Exner bodies, which are pathognomic of granulosa cell tumours. Granulosa cells with pale, grooved, “coffee bean” nuclei are seen.

Option C: Walthard cell rests are benign clusters of epithelial cells resembling transitional cells. 

The image below shows Walthard cell rests and coffee bean nuclei, which are pathognomic of Brenner's tumour.

Option D: Hobnail cells are clear cells showing large dark nuclei protruding into the lumen. 

The image below shows the hobnail cell, which is the pathognomic of a clear-cell ovarian tumour. 

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

questions.text: Data from 6 sets of studies comparing the association of "average hours of near work" with "incidence of convergence insufficiency" is plotted and the following scattergrams are obtained. Which of the following scattergrams indicate a positive correlation?
questions.solution:
Scattergrams 1 & 2 indicate a positive correlation as they have a positive slope.
 
Scattergrams 3, 4, & 6 indicate negative correlation while scattergram 5 indicates no correlation.

Related Pearl: Correlation

Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables in terms of a correlation coefficient. It is represented by r.

  • Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).
  • Value (size) of the coefficient: Indicates the strength of relationship
  • Sign of the coefficient: Indicates direction of relationship

Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak.

The data is plotted in a scattergram as shown in the examples given below

Examples:

Types of correlation coefficients

  1. Pearson coefficient
  2. Spearman coefficient

Coefficient of Determination (CD) =  r2

It is simply the percentage variability in one factor due to change in another variable.

questions.text: An infant is brought with the following lesion on the scalp. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows cup‐shaped crusts/scutula around hair follicles, which is suggestive of favus.

Kerion is a severe inflammatory type of tinea capitis. The most common causative organisms of kerion are Trichophyton verrucosum and Trichophyton mentagrophytes. In severe cases, there may be pus along with sinus formation. It presents as an inflammatory mass with thick crusting and matting of hair.

Note: Scarring alopecia is seen in favus and kerion while non-scarring alopecia is seen in ectothrix and endothrix.

Ectothrix is a mild inflammatory type in which dull grey-coated broken hairs are seen.

Endothrix is a non-inflammatory type in which black dots form around swollen hair shafts. 

Tinea capitis is of four types: 

Type of Infection  Causative fungus 
Endothrix (infection inside shaft)
  • Trichophyton tonsurans
  • T. violaceum
  • T. schoenleinii
  • T. yaoundei
  • T. soudanense
Ectothrix (infection outside shaft)
  • Microsporum audouinii
  • M.canis
  • M.equinum
  • M.ferrugineum
Favus 
  • T. schoenleinii
Kerion 
  • T. verrucosum
  • T. mentagrophytes

Other Options:

Option D: Seborrheic dermatitis, or cradle cap in infants, presents with greasy, yellow scales, often without hair loss. Below is an image of the same.

questions.text: Which of the following contraceptives would be least suitable for a patient who has had intercourse 48 hours prior but wants to avoid pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Centchroman would be least suitable for a patient who has had intercourse 48 hours prior but wants to avoid pregnancy. It has to be taken within 24 hours of intercourse.

Centchroman is administered as two tablets of 60 mg taken twice over 24 hours and within 24 hours of intercourse. It acts by preventing the implantation of the blastocyst in the endometrium. It is the only contraceptive that neither suppresses ovulation nor interferes with the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis.

The various emergency contraceptive methods, along with their mechanism of action, have been described below:

  • An intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) prevents the implantation of a fertilized ovum. It does so by acting as a foreign body within the uterine cavity. This leads to increased contractility, and tubal peristalsis, and promotes leukocytic infiltration in the endometrium so that the fertilized egg is unable to implant. 
  • An IUCD such as Copper T (Option C) can be used for emergency contraception if inserted within 5 days of coitus. The administration of postcoital contraceptive agents that interfere with postovulatory events that can lead to pregnancy is known as the emergency contraception method. They are used to prevent pregnancy after unprotected intercourse.
  • Ulipristal (Option A) is given as a 30 mg tablet and should be taken within 5 days. It is a synthetic progesterone hormone receptor modulator. The drug attaches to the progesterone receptor, delays ovulation and suppresses endometrium, thereby preventing implantation.
  • Levonorgestrel (LNG) (Option D) is administered as a single 1.5 mg tablet within 72 hours of coitus. It can also be administered as two tablets of 0.75 mg strength, taken 12 hours apart. LNG prevents ovulation and causes desynchronization of the endometrium through its receptors (luteal phase deficiency).
  • Ethinyl estradiol is administered as two oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) containing 50 mcg each within 72 hours of coitus, followed by the 2 tablets after 12 hours. Alternatively, four OCPs of 30 or 35 mcg of ethinyl estradiol, followed by 4 tablets after 12 hours, can be used. The hormone may delay ovulation if taken soon after intercourse, bringing about cervical mucus changes and endometrial atrophy.
  • Mifepristone is administered as a single 200 mg tablet within 72 hours. It is a steroid with an affinity for progesterone receptors. It prevents fertilization by blocking the action of progesterone on the endometrium. This leads to sloughing and shedding of decidua, thus preventing implantation.

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

Related Pearl: Classification Of Contraceptives Based On Effectiveness

questions.text: Mannitol use is best suited for the management of which of the following patients?

choices.text: 61-year-old patient with glioma associated cerebral edema
59-year-old man with congestive cardiac failure and a high intraocular pressure not responding to other treatment
48-year-old lady with anuria due to severe renal disease and a raised ICT
22-year-old patient with active cranial bleed and increased ICT

questions.solution:
Mannitol is indicated in patients with cerebral edema due to mass lesions

Therapeutic use of mannitol:

1. Reduction of intracranial pressure and brain mass
2. Reduction of high intraocular pressure when the pressure cannot be lowered by other means

Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic. It acts by extracting water from the intracellular compartments, which results in the expansion of the extracellular fluid. This results in volume overload and frank pulmonary edema in patients with cardiac failure.


Contraindications of mannitol:

  • Well-established anuria due to severe renal disease
  • Severe pulmonary congestion or frank pulmonary edema
  • Active intracranial bleeding except during craniotomy
  • Severe dehydration
  • Progressive heart failure or pulmonary congestion after institution of mannitol

questions.text: While assessing a patient with an elbow injury, the senior resident asks you to comment on the three-point-bony relationship/ triangle sign. The three points that you should consider for this do not include _______.
questions.solution:
The three bony points in the elbow that should be considered in the triangle sign are

  • Tip of the medial epicondyle,
  • Tip of the lateral epicondyle, and
  • Olecranon process of the ulna.

Related Pearl: Three point bony relationship in elbow:

The three bony points in the elbow are :

  • Tip of the medial epicondyle
  • Tip of the lateral epicondyle
  • Olecranon

When the elbow is in 90 degrees of flexion, these points form an isosceles triangle. When the elbow is extended, they lie transversely in a straight line.

The three-point bony relationship is maintained in the case of supracondylar fracture of the humerus as the fracture occurs above the level of these bony landmarks.

Conditions where it is distorted:

  • Fracture medial condyle and epicondyle
  • Fracture lateral condyle and epicondyle
  • Intercondylar fracture of humerus
  • Fracture olecranon
  • Elbow dislocation

questions.text: Detection of products of dead cells by inflammasome induces secretion of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Detection of products of dead cells by inflammasome induces secretion of interleukin-1 (IL-1).

Cytoplasmic innate immune receptors recognize microbial products that entered the infected cells and activate the multiprotein complex called the inflammasome. Inflammasome activates caspase 1 and helps in the release of the biologically activated forms of IL-1. Along with caspase 1, caspases 4 and 5 also induce cell death. Unlike classical apoptosis, pyroptosis is characterized by the release of inflammatory mediators. 

Apoptosis: The intrinsic mitochondrial and extrinsic death receptor-initiated pathways converge to activate a caspase cascade that mediates the final phase of apoptosis. The intrinsic pathway activates caspase 9, whereas the extrinsic pathway activates caspases 8 and 10. These caspases then activate caspase 3 and caspase 6. Activated caspases cause DNA degradation and nuclei fragmentation.

Ferroptosis is an iron-dependent distinct pathway of cell death induced by lipid peroxidation. The widespread peroxidation disrupts membrane function, which leads to the loss of plasma membrane permeability and results in cell death resembling necrosis. 

Necroptosis, as the name suggests, has features similar to necrosis and apoptosis. Like necrosis, it is characterized by loss of ATP, cellular and organelle swelling, the release of lysosomal enzymes, and rupture of the plasma membrane. However, like apoptosis, this is programmed cell death. Ligation of TNFR1 initiates necroptosis. This is a caspase-independent programmed cell death.

questions.text: What does Cantlie's line represent?
questions.solution:
Cantlie’s line is another name for the main portal fissure which extends from the midpoint of the gallbladder fossa at the inferior margin of the liver to the midpoint of the inferior vena cava. It divides the liver into the right and left hemiliver. It contains the middle hepatic vein.

Umbilical fissure - It separates segment 3 from segment 4, within the left medial sector. It is marked by the attachment of the falciform ligament.

Venous fissure - It is a direct continuation of the umbilical fissure on the undersurface of the liver. It contains the ligamentum venosum (obliterated ductus venosus).

Fissure of Ganz - It lies on the undersurface of the right lobe of the liver behind the gallbladder fossa. It is also called Rouviere’s sulcus. It marks the division of the portal pedicle to the right posterior sector.

Couinaud's classification divides the liver into 4 sectors based on supply by portal venous branches. These sectors are further divided into 2 segments based on vascular biliary sheath supplying it. It is but however, a functional or physiological classification. For surgery, based on the hepatic veins draining the liver part, it is divided by 3 major portal fissures not visible on the liver surface but present within the liver parenchyma.

  • The main portal fissure called Cantlie's line divides the liver into right and left hemi-liver. It contains the middle hepatic vein.
  • The left portal fissure divides the left hemi-liver into medial (anterior) and lateral (posterior) segments. It contains the left hepatic vein.
  • The right portal fissure divides the right hemi-liver into medial (anterior) and lateral (posterior) segments. It contains the right hepatic vein.

Related Pearl: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

Other segments:

Liver sections

Couinaud's Segments

Right anterior sections

Segments V,VIII

Right Posterior sections

Segments VI, VII

Left medial sections

Segment IV (quadrate lobe)

Left lateral sections

Segment II, III

questions.text:
Contributory negligence would be applicable in which of the following situations:
  1. Patient refuses treatment
  2. Against the doctor's advice, the patient leaves the hospital
  3. The patient fails to seek further care even though the symptoms persist
  4. The doctor fails to give proper instructions to the patient
  5. The patient fails to give a proper history
questions.solution:
The doctor cannot plead contributory negligence if he fails to give proper instructions.

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. 

Defenses Against Negligence

  • No duty is owed to the plaintiff
  • Duty discharged according to prevailing standards
  • Misadventure - may be therapeutic, diagnostic, and experimental
  • Error of judgment
  • Contributory negligence - the absence of ordinary care on the part of the patient or his personal attendant

 

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text: Tullio phenomenon refers to

choices.text: Rotation of patients on being asked to close their eyes and to step in place for 20-30 seconds.
Increased swaying of the patient on standing erect with the eyes closed
Exposure to loud sound precipitating nystagmus and vertigo
Exposure to increased pressure of the external auditory canal precipitating nystagmus and vertigo

questions.solution:
Exposure to loud sound precipitating nystagmus and vertigo is known as Tullio phenomenon. It is typically associated with superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome, but it is not specific to it. 

Superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome occurs due to the third window effect created by the thin/ dehiscent wall of the superior semicircular canal. This causes endolymph in the labyrinthine system to move with sound or pressure, causing an activation of the vestibular system. It is usually diagnosed in middle-aged individuals, and no racial or sexual predominance is seen. 

Patients present with noise or pressure-induced dizziness. Some may complain of chronic imbalance. As a result, the patient adopts avoidance of noisy environments. Also, some may have gaze-evoked tinnitus or hyperacusis. Patients with SCDS usually have a normal gait test, Romberg's test, Fukuda test, and Dix-Hallpike maneuver, but the fistula test is positive (Hennebert Sign). In addition, the Barany noise box can be used for inducing vertigo. Noncontrast HRCT of the temporal bone can demonstrate the defect, and the condition is usually treated by surgery if there are severe disabling symptoms. Else, conservative medical management is done. 

Fukuda test: Patients are asked to close their eyes and to step in place for 20-30 seconds. Unilateral loss of vestibular functions manifests as rotation of the patient. This test is nonspecific and the results are typically normal in patients with SCDS.

Increased swaying of the patient on standing erect with the eyes closed, is a positive Romberg sign. Romberg test is usually abnormal in patients with a central pathologic condition. Patients with SCDS demonstrate normal Romberg test results. It is used to evaluate peripheral sensation, dorsal column function, and midline cerebellar function.

questions.text: Ethmoidal bullectomy would entail the removal of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The image above shows the computed tomography (CT) scan of the osteomeatal complex in the coronal plane. The structure marked as 2 is the ethmoidal bulla, and the same is removed in ethmoidal bullectomy.

This step should be performed carefully so as to avoid damage to the medial orbital wall, skull base, or anterior ethmoidal artery.

The structure marked as 1 is the uncinate process which is removed in infundibulotomy. Infundibulotomy, also known as uncinectomy, is the first surgical step in functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) to approach the middle meatus.

The structure marked as 3 is the middle turbinate

The structure marked as 4 is the medial wall of the maxillary sinus.

The following image gives an explanation of these structures.

Important steps in FESS:

  1. Uncinectomy or Infundibulotomy
  2. Identification and enlargement of the maxillary ostium
  3. Bullectomy
  4. Penetration of basal lamella and posterior ethmoidal cells
  5. Clearance of frontal recess and frontal sinusotomy
  6. Sphenoidotomy
  7. Nasal packing

Indications of FESS:

  • Chronic bacterial sinusitis, refractory to medical treatment.
  • Recurrent acute bacterial sinusitis.
  • Polypoid rhinosinusitis.
  • Fungal sinusitis with a fungal ball.
  • Antrochoanal polyp.
  • Mucocele of fronto-ethmoid or sphenoid sinus.
  • Endoscopic septoplasty.
  • Epistaxis control by endoscopic cautery.
  • Foreign body removal from the nose or sinus.

questions.text:
Match the following
  1. Joule Burns
  2. Filigree Burns
  3. Scald injury
  4. Frost bite
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-B, 2-C, 3-A, 4-D.

Arborescent burns/ Filigree burns / Lichtenberg's flowers are superficial, thin, irregular, and tortuous markings on the skin that are indicative of a lightning strike. They resemble the branches of a tree and are usually found over the skin of the shoulders or the flanks.

Scalding is due to exposure to wet heat like hot water or steam. It is an injury that results from the application of liquid above 60°C or from steam i.e moist heat. Redness appears immediately followed by blistering in a few minutes. Removal of the blistered skin leaves a raw, pink surface. Blisters are surrounded by a hyperaemic zone. Scalds appear soddened and bleached but the hair does not get singed. The skin does not get blackened or charred.

Scald injuries are limited to the area of contact and are more severe at the initial point of contact. It can occur through clothing, which worsens damage due to a longer period of contact with the hot liquid and a reduced cooling effect of evaporation.

It can be 

  • Immersion burns: Accidental or deliberate immersion in hot liquid, usually water.  
  • Splash or spill burns: Usually accidental.  
  • Steam burns: Exposure to superheated steam.

Clinical degree of scalding:

  • Erythema (reddening)
  • Vesication (blister formation)
  • Necrosis of the dermis when deeper layers of skin are involved

Joule burns or electric marks occur due to contact with electricity and are found at the point of entry of the current. They are observed as round or oval, shallow craters, having a ridge of skin around their circumference. The floor is lined with pale flattened skin. 

Frost Bite occurs when the body is exposed to cold temperatures. Here, tissue damage results from severe environmental cold exposure or from direct contact with a very cold object. Tissue injury results from both freezing and vascular stasis. It usually affects the distal aspects of the extremities or exposed parts of the face, such as the ears, nose, chin, and cheeks.

Clinical features include decreased sensation (especially for pain, and temperature sensations) in the acral tips and extremities. The affected area appears waxy, mottled, or violaceous. Patients may have a wood-like sensation in the affected area.

Treatment:

  • Initial treatment is by rapid rewarming (or thawing), which is accomplished by immersion of the affected part in a water bath at temperatures of 37°–40°C (99°–104°F) for 30–60 minutes. Rewarming by exercise, rubbing, or friction is not advised. 
  • Analgesics such as ibuprofen are often required during rewarming.
  • Antithrombotics, thrombolytic, and vasodilators such as prostacyclin can be given to improve circulation after rewarming.
  • Frost bites are associated with an increased risk of infections and tetanus. Therefore, the injured area should be cleaned with soap or antiseptic, and sterile dressings should be applied. Tetanus prophylaxis must be given, but, empirical antibiotics are not recommended.
  • The patient must be monitored for the development of compartment syndrome.
  • Elective late amputation after imaging may be required in severe cases.

Image showing frostbite of the toes:

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the ocular condition seen in the image below?

choices.text: Meta­plasia of the conjunctival epithelium is seen
The retinal mani­festations of the underlying deficiency respond faster to treatment than these spots
Improvement of these spots is seen within 2 weeks of therapy
Typical foamy appearance is due to gas produced by Corynebacterium xerosis

questions.solution:
The given image depicts Bitot's spots, characteristically seen in deficiency of vitamin A. Bitot's spots are seen as white patches of keratinized epithelium on the sclera. It is more commonly bilateral and on the temporal side.

Vitamin A is essential for normal epithelial development. Its deficiency causes Bitot’s spots through meta­plasia of the conjunctival epithelium and tangles of keratin admixed with Corynebacterium xerosis. These Corynebacterium dwell in the stratum corneum of the conjunc­tiva and the typical foamy appearance of the Bitot spot lesion is due to gas produced by these bacteria. Histologically, Bitot’s spots show kerati­nization, irregular maturation, inflam­matory infiltration, and accumulation of gram-positive bacilli.

Bitot’s spots improve within 2 weeks of high-dose vitamin A therapy. But, the retinal mani­festations due to vitamin A deficiency are slower to respond to treatment. Night blindness and dark adaptation problems often persist for 4 weeks.

Vitamin A deficiency arises primarily due to inadequate amounts of vitamin A in the diet. It can present as night blindness, conjunctival xerosis, Bitot's spots, and keratomalacia. In later stages, it can lead to xerophthalmia. It also increases the risk of developing measles, diarrhea, and dysentery. Skin manifestations include xerosis, scaling, and dermomalacia. Phrynoderma may also be seen as keratotic follicular papules affecting the thighs and upper arms. It is shown in the image below.

In patients above the age of 1 year, vitamin A deficiency is treated with 200,000 IU of vitamin A orally or 100,000 IU by intramuscular route. It should be repeated the next day and four weeks later.

Vitamin A is a fat-soluble vitamin that plays an essential role in vision, reproduction, and maintenance of epithelial integrity. The various forms of vitamin A include retinol (storage form), retinal, retinoic acid, and beta-carotene. It is stored in the liver perisinusoidal stellate (Ito) cells as retinyl ester (retinyl palmitate).

 

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

 

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text:
Arrange the following patients in descending order of treatment priority as per the triage system.
  1. A young man with tension pneumothorax
  2. A middle-aged man with a simple fracture of the ulna
  3. A middle-aged woman with a degloving injury of the left leg
  4. A teenage girl with severe brain injury and major chest wall and abdominal injuries
questions.solution:
Option C is the correct sequence of triage colour coding.

  • A young man with tension pneumothorax - Red - Highest priority
  • A middle-aged woman with a degloving injury of the left leg - Yellow - Medium priority
  • A middle-aged man with a simple fracture of the ulna - Green - Low priority
  • A teenage girl with severe brain injury and major chest wall and abdominal injuries - Black - Least priority

Triage is used to classify the priority of treatment. It is carried out at the disaster site to determine the priority for immediate medical attention, transportation, and admission to the hospital.

Triage includes rapid classification of the injured based on their injuries and the chances of survival with prompt medical intervention. It provides maximum benefit to the greatest number of injured in a disaster situation. Higher priority is given to victims whose prognosis would be good with simple medical care. Lower priority is given to moribund patients who would have questionable benefits even with medical attention.

Priority Color Medical need Clinical status
First (I) Red Immediate Critical, but likely to survive if the treatment is given early
Second (II) Yellow Urgent Critical, likely to survive if the treatment is given within hours
Third (III) Green Non-urgent Stable, likely to survive even if treatment is delayed for hours to days
Last (0) Black Unsalvageable Not breathing, pulseless, so severely injured that no medical care is likely to help

Note:

In the event of a disaster, mass casualty or epidemic, hospitals face a significant demand or a surge for healthcare services that often outpaces the supply of available resources. Reverse triage is implemented during these surge periods.

By identifying and discharging low-risk patients, reverse triage allows faster and more efficient treatment of critically ill patients. It also helps minimize mortality and morbidity for the greatest number of patients while treating the largest number of patients in the shortest period of time.

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text: Permanent impairment of fingerprint pattern is least likely to occur in case of
questions.solution:
Permanent impairment of the fingerprint pattern occurs in electric injury, leprosy, and after exposure to radiation.

First-degree burns cannot cause permanent damage to the fingerprints. Even the burnt skin of the fingers on healing shows its original pattern.

Interestingly, rickets, acromegaly and infantile paralysis (polio) may result in the widening of the distance between the ridges but the pattern is not altered.

questions.text: What is the definitive treatment for patients with hepatorenal syndrome?
questions.solution:
The definitive treatment for patients with hepatorenal syndrome is orthotopic liver transplantation.

The hepatorenal syndrome is a form of functional renal failure without renal pathology that occurs in patients with advanced cirrhosis or acute liver failure. 

There is an increased splanchnic production of vasodilators (nitric oxide) in patients with cirrhosis and portal hypertension. Splanchnic vasodilation leads to systemic arterial underfilling, resulting in the activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). RAAS activation causes renal vasoconstriction, which leads to decreased renal perfusion, resulting in hepatorenal syndrome.

International Ascites Club’s Diagnostic Criteria of Hepatorenal Syndrome:

Major criteria

  • Chronic or acute liver disease with advanced hepatic failure and portal hypertension
  • Low GFR: serum creatinine level of >133 μmol/L or 24-h creatinine clearance of <40 mL/min
  • Absence of shock
  • Absence of gastrointestinal or renal fluid losses
  • No sustained improvement in renal function, following diuretic withdrawal and expansion of plasma volume with 1.5 L of isotonic saline
  • Proteinuria of <0.5 g/day and no ultrasonographic evidence of obstructive uropathy or parenchymal renal disease

Additional criteria

  • Urine volume of <0.5 L/day
  • Urine sodium concentration of <10 mmol/L
  • Urine osmolality > plasma osmolality
  • Urine red blood cells at <50 per high-power field
  • Serum sodium concentration of <130 mmol/L

Treatment:

The definitive treatment is liver transplantation. 

Pharmacotherapy mainly consists of drugs that cause splanchnic vasoconstriction. They include vasopressin analogs (ornipressin, terlipressin), somatostatin analogs (octreotide), and alpha-adrenergic agonists (midodrine). Plasma volume expanders are also effective in the treatment of hepatorenal syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the states of ion channels during the absolute refractory period of an action potential?

choices.text: Both Na+ & K+ channels are closed
Na+ channel closed, K+ channel open
Na+ channel open, K+ channel closed
Na+ channels reset, K+ channels remain open

questions.solution:
During the absolute refractory period, the Na+ channel is closed and the K+ channels are open.

Both channels are closed in the resting phase, while the Na+ channel alone opens in the depolarisation phase.

The sequence of events during the action potential occurs in the following sequence:

1. Resting-state: Both channels are closed

2. Na+ channels open in response to depolarizing stimulus. Sodium enters the cell. The membrane reaches threshold potential.

3. The sodium influx causes the opening of more Na+ channels through a positive feedback mechanism. Rapid depolarization occurs.

4. Sodium conductance decreases.

5. Na+ channels close and K+ channels open. Repolarization occurs.

6. Sodium channels are reset and are ready to respond to another depolarizing stimulus (relative refractory period). During this phase, the K+ channels remain open and slowly return to the closed state causing after-hyperpolarization.

7. Both channels are closed. The membrane returns to RMP.

Related Pearl: Absolute and relative refractory period

Types of refractory periods

Absolute refractory period

Relative  refractory period

Property

No stimulus, no matter how strong, will  not excite the nerve

 Stronger than normal stimuli can cause excitation 
 Period Period from the time the firing level is reached until repolarization is about one-third complete Begins at the end of the Absolute refractory period to the start of after-depolarization 
 Basis Closure of the Inactivation Gates of the Na+ channel in response to depolarization  

Na+ channels are reset and can open upon arrival of a stronger stimuli

K+ channel remain open

questions.text:
Match the following clinical descriptions with their respective names.
  1. Deja vu
  2. Deja entendu
  3. Deja pense
  4. Jamais vu

 

  1. The illusion that what one is hearing one has heard previously 
  2. A thought that has never been entertained before is incorrectly regarded as a repetition of a previous thought
  3. Illusion of visual recognition in which a new situation is incorrectly regarded as a repetition of a previous experience
  4. False feeling of unfamiliarity with a real situation that one has previously experienced
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pairs:

  1. The illusion that what one is hearing one has heard previously: Deja entendu
  2. A thought which has never been  entertained before is incorrectly regarded as a repetition of a previous thought: Deja pense
  3. Illusion of visual recognition in which a new situation is incorrectly regarded as a repetition of a previous experience: Deja vu
  4. False feeling of unfamiliarity with a real situation that one has previously experienced: Jamais vu

 

All of the above are part of paramnestic disorders. They are characterized by a disturbance of memory and a resultant confusion between fantasy and reality. They are seen in dreams, in some types of schizophrenia, and in some organic mental disorders. They may occasionally occur in normal persons.

questions.text:
Which of the following symptoms are part of voiding LUTS?
  1. Hesitancy
  2. Reduced stream
  3. Postmicturitional dribbling
  4. Nocturia
  5. Straining
questions.solution:
Hesitancy, reduced stream, and straining are voiding LUTS.

Voiding LUTS- This is commonly seen in bladder outlet obstruction. Symptoms related to voiding LUTS are:

  • Hesitancy- difficulty in initiating micturition
  • Reduced stream
  • Straining- muscular effort is needed to initiate or improve the urinary stream

Storage LUTS- This occurs due to the failure of the bladder to act as a urine reservoir. It is commonly seen in the overactive bladder or bladder neuropathy. Symptoms related to storage LUTS are:

  • Frequency- Increased frequency of voiding
  • Nocturia- a patient has to wake up at least once at night to void
  • Urgency- the sudden uncontrollable desire to pass urine
  • Urge incontinence- a large volume of involuntary urine leakage preceded by urgency

Post-micturitional LUTS- This is also caused due to bladder outlet obstruction. Symptoms related to post micturitional LUTS are:

  • Incomplete emptying- a sensation that the bladder is full still remains after micturition
  • Post micturition dribble- Involuntary passage of urine after the patient has finished passing urine.

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the solutions in increasing order of their osmolarity.
  1. Normal saline
  2. Ringer lactate
  3. 5% dextrose in water
  4. 3% NaCl
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of increasing osmolarity is 5D<RL<NS<3%NaCl

  1. Normal saline: 308 mOsmol/L
  2. Ringer lactate: 273 mOsm/L
  3. 5% dextrose in water: 252 mOsmol/L
  4. 3% NaCl: 1027 mOsmol/L

 

5% dextrose (D5W solution):

  • It contains 50g/L glucose. 
  • Soon after infusion, the dextrose is taken up into the cell, leaving behind free water.
  • It is used for the replacement of pure water deficits and as a maintenance fluid for patients on sodium restriction.
  • The predominant effect of D5W is cellular swelling and hemolysis due to hypotonicity.

Normal saline:

  • 0.9% NaCl is isotonic normal saline, but this solution is neither chemically nor physiologically normal.
  • It contains 9 g of NaCl per liter.
  • Due to the high chloride concentration, excessive infusion can lead to hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis.

Ringer lactate:

  • It is also known as Hartman’s solution. 
  • It is isotonic and is the most physiological solution.
  • It should not be used as a diluent fluid for transfusion of PRBCs as it can precipitate and form clots.

Hypertonic saline:

  • It is available as 1.8%, 3%, and 7.5% NaCl.
  • It is particularly useful in the treatment of hyponatremia, volume resuscitation, and increased ICP.
