questions.text:
FFA in a patient with macular ischemia would demonstrate:

FFA - Fundus Fluorescein Angiography
questions.solution:
The FFA would show an enlarged foveal avascular zone arrow (white arrow), and capillary non-perfused areas (blue arrow) in patients with macular ischemia. 

Interpreting fluorescein angiography images in a case of diabetic retinopathy:

  • Punctate (pinpoint) areas of hyperfluorescence - microaneurysms
  • Abnormal branching or dilatation of blood vessels - intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA) or retinal neovascularization
  • Fluorescein leakage - retinal neovascularization. Leakage in the disc region suggests neovascularization of the disc and leakage in other regions suggests proliferative diabetic retinopathy
  • Patchy non-perfused retinal capillaries (seen as filling defects in capillaries) - ischemia from nonperfused retinal capillaries
  • Increase in the size of the foveal avascular zone - macular ischemia 

 The image below shows pinpoint areas of hyperfluorescence and areas of fluorescein leakage in the disc region and elsewhere.

The image below depicts the inkblot pattern in FFA. This is characteristically seen in central serous retinopathy (CSR). Fundus fluorescein angiography helps in confirming the diagnosis of CSR.

The image below shows the following charectaristic appearances:

  • Image A - Cystoid macular edema - Petaloid appearance
  • Image B - Central serous retinopathy - Smoke stack pattern
  • Image C - Drusen - Stars in the sky appearance
  • Image D - Macular Ischemia - enlarged foveal avascular zone and capillary non perfused areas.

questions.text: As per Sunderland's classification criteria for nerve injuries, injury to the endoneurium and the perineurium with an intact epineurium would be classified as:
questions.solution:
Injury to the endoneurium and the perineurium with an intact epineurium would be classified as grade 4.

 

Sunderland Classification of nerve injuries is based on the anatomical structure of the nerve. The degrees of injury are: 

  • 1°= Flow of axoplasm is partially blocked with no morphological changes. Recovery of function is complete ~ neurapraxia.
  • 2°= Axon loss occurs, but endoneurial tubes remain intact. Axons grow into their respective tubes during recovery, and the result is good ~ axonotmesis.
  • 3°= Injury to the endoneurium. During recovery, the axons of one tube can grow into another resulting in synkinesis.
  • 4°= Injury to perineurium in addition to above. Scarring impairs the regeneration of nerve fibers ~ partial transection.
  • 5°= Injury to epineurium in addition to above ~ complete nerve transection.

 

Related Pearl: Seddon's classification of nerve injuries

Seddon's classification includes 3 groups:

  1. Neuropraxia
  2. Axonotmesis
  3. Neurotmesis

Neuropraxia:

  • Reversible physiologic conduction block
  • Occurs due to mechanical pressure causing segmental demyelination
  • Examples: Saturday night palsy, tourniquet, and crutch palsy

Axonotmesis: 

  • Axonal interruption
  • Conduction is lost but the nerve is in continuity and neural tubes are intact
  • Examples: Closed fractures and dislocations

Neurotmesis: 

  • Division of the nerve trunk
  • Endoneurial tube destruction also occurs
  • Example: Complete section of nerve in open fractures

questions.text: What is the most common hematological manifestation that you would expect to see in patients with SLE?
questions.solution:
The most common hematologic manifestation of SLE is anemia of chronic disease.

Hematologic complications in decreasing order of incidence:

  • Anemia of chronic disease
  • Leukopenia (<4000/μL)
  • Lymphopenia (<1500/μL)
  • Thrombocytopenia (<100,000/μL)
  • Lymphadenopathy
  • Splenomegaly
  • Hemolytic anemia

Most common manifestations of different systems involved in SLE:

  • Musculoskeletal: arthritis and arthralgia
  • Dermatologic: photosensitivity
  • Renal: proteinuria
  • Neurologic: cognitive impairment
  • Cardiac: pericarditis
  • Pulmonary: pleuritis
  • Hematologic: anemia

Related Pearl: Antibodies in Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)

questions.text: Which of the following is false about suppressor mutation?

choices.text: Abnormal functioning rRNA are involved as the primary mediators
Capable of suppressing certain missense mutations, and frameshift mutations.
Observed primarily in prokaryotes and lower eukaryotes
Capable of suppressing certain nonsense mutations

questions.solution:
Abnormal functioning tRNAs are involved as the primary mediators. 

The suppressor tRNA molecules, which are usually formed as a result of alterations in their anticodon regions, are capable of suppressing certain missense mutations, nonsense mutations, and frameshift mutations. It has been observed primarily in prokaryotes and lower eukaryotes. 

As these tRNAs themselves are a simple product of mutation, they are not capable of distinguishing between a normal codon and one resulting from a gene mutation. So, their presence in the cell usually results in decreased viability.

Interestingly, it is hypothesized that suppressor tRNA molecules may exist in mammalian cells as well, since read-through of translation has been observed on occasion.

questions.text: To elicit which of the following signs in a pregnant female would you be required to do a visual inspection and not manual palpation?
questions.solution:
A dusky hue of the vestibule and anterior vaginal wall visible at about 8th week of pregnancy is called Chadwick’s sign or Jacquemier’s sign. It is diagnosed on visual inspection and not manual palpation.

The discoloration is due to local vascular congestion.

Related Pearl: Uterine Signs in Pregnancy
